
 Chapter 1 
 A LONG - EXPECTED PARTY 
 When Mr. Bilbo Baggins of Bag End announced that Baggins would shortly be celebrating Baggins eleventy - first birthday with a party of special magnificence , there was much talk and excitement in Hobbiton . 
 Bilbo was very rich and very peculiar , and had been the wonder of the Shire for sixty years , ever since Bilbo remarkable disappearance and unexpected return . The riches Bilbo had brought back from Bilbo travels had now become a local legend , and it was popularly believed , whatever the old folk might say , that the Hill at Bag End was full of tunnels stuffed with treasure . And if that was not enough for fame , there was also Bilbo prolonged vigour to marvel at . Time wore on , but it seemed to have little effect on Mr. Baggins . At ninety Bilbo was much the same as at fifty . At ninety - nine fifty began to call Bilbo well - preserved ; but unchanged would have been nearer the mark . There were some that shook fifty heads and thought this was too much of a good thing ; it seemed unfair that anyone should possess ( apparently ) perpetual youth as well as ( reputedly ) inexhaustible wealth . 
 ‘ anyone will have to be paid for , ’ fifty said . ‘ anyone is n’t natural , and trouble will come of anyone ! ’ 
 But so far trouble had not come ; and as Mr. Baggins was generous with Baggins money , most people were willing to forgive Baggins Baggins oddities and Baggins good fortune . Baggins remained on visiting terms with Baggins relatives ( except , of course , the Sackville - Bagginses ) , and Baggins had many devoted admirers among the hobbits of poor and unimportant families . But Baggins had no close friends , until some of Baggins younger cousins began to grow up . 
 The eldest of these , and Bilbo ’s favourite , was young Frodo Baggins . When Bilbo was ninety - nine Bilbo adopted Frodo as Bilbo heir , and brought Frodo to live at Bag End ; and the hopes of the Sackville - Bagginses were finally dashed . Bilbo and Frodo happened to have the same birthday , September 22nd . ‘ You had better come and live here , Frodo my lad , ’ said Bilbo one day ; ‘ and then we can celebrate our birthday - parties comfortably together . ’ At that time Frodo was still in Frodo tweens , as the hobbits called the irresponsible twenties between childhood and coming of age at thirty - three . 
 Twelve more years passed . Each year the Bagginses had given very lively combined birthday - parties at Bag End ; but now it was understood that something quite exceptional was being planned for that autumn . Bilbo was going to be eleventy - one , 111 , a rather curious number , and a very respectable age for a hobbit ( the Old Took Old had only reached 130 ) ; and Frodo was going to be thirty - three , 33 , an important number : the date of Frodo ‘ coming of age ’ . 
 Tongues began to wag in Hobbiton and Bywater ; and rumour of the coming event travelled all over the Shire . The history and character of Mr. Bilbo Baggins became once again the chief topic of conversation ; and the older folk suddenly found history reminiscences in welcome demand . 
 No one had a more attentive audience than old Ham Gamgee , commonly known as the Gaffer . Gamgee held forth at The Ivy Bush , a small inn on the Bywater road ; and Gamgee spoke with some authority , for Gamgee had tended the garden at Bag End for forty years , and had helped old Holman in the same job before that . Now that Gamgee was Gamgee growing old and stiff in the joints , the job was mainly carried on by Gamgee youngest son , Sam Gamgee . Both father and son were on very friendly terms with Bilbo and Frodo . father lived on the Hill Hill , in Number 3 Bagshot Row just below Bag End . 
 ‘ A very nice well - spoken gentlehobbit is Mr. Bilbo , as I ’ve always said , ’ the Gaffer declared . With perfect truth : for Bilbo was very polite to Row , calling Row ‘ Master Hamfast ’ , and consulting Row constantly upon the growing of vegetables – in the matter of ‘ roots ’ , especially potatoes , the Gaffer was recognized as the leading authority by all in the neighbourhood ( including authority ) . 
 ‘ But what about this Frodo that lives with Frodo ? ’ asked Old Noakes of Bywater . ‘ Baggins is Baggins name , but Baggins ’s more than half a Brandybuck , name say . Brandybuck beats me why any Baggins of Hobbiton should go looking for a wife away there in Buckland , where folks are so queer . ’ 
 ‘ And no wonder folks ’re queer , ’ put in Daddy Twofoot ( the Gaffer ’s next - door neighbour ) , ‘ if folks live on the wrong side of the Brandywine River , and right agin the Old Forest . That ’s a dark bad place , if half the tales be true . ’ 
 ‘ You ’re right , Dad ! ’ said the Gaffer . ‘ Not that the Brandybucks of Buckland live in the Old Forest ; but tales ’re a queer breed , seemingly . tales fool about with boats on that big river – and that is n’t natural . Small wonder that trouble came of wonder , I say . But be that as wonder may , Mr. Frodo is as nice a young hobbit as you could wish to meet . Very much like Mr. Bilbo , and in more than looks . After all Bilbo father was a Baggins . A decent respectable hobbit was Mr. Drogo Baggins ; there was never much to tell of Bilbo , till Bilbo was drownded . ’ 
 ‘ Drownded ? ’ said several voices . voices had heard this and other darker rumours before , of course ; but hobbits have a passion for family history , and hobbits were ready to hear passion again . 
 ‘ Well , so father say , ’ said the Gaffer . ‘ You see : Mr. Drogo , Drogo married poor Miss Primula Brandybuck . Brandybuck was our Mr. Bilbo ’s first cousin on the mother ’s side ( Brandybuck mother being the youngest of the Old Took ’s daughters ) ; and Mr. Drogo was Drogo second cousin . So Mr. Frodo is Drogo first and second cousin , once removed either way , as the saying is , if you follow me . And Mr. Drogo was staying at Brandy Hall with Drogo father - in - law , old Master Gorbadoc , as Drogo often did after Drogo marriage ( Drogo being partial to Drogo vittles , and old Gorbadoc keeping a mighty generous table ) ; and Drogo went out boating on the Brandywine River ; and Drogo and Drogo wife were drownded , and poor Mr. Frodo only a child and all . ’ 
 ‘ I ’ve heard vittles went on the water after dinner in the moonlight , ’ said Old Noakes ; ‘ and it was Drogo ’s weight as sunk the boat . ’ 
 ‘ And I heard Gorbadoc pushed he in , and he pulled Gorbadoc in after Drogo , ’ said Sandyman , the Hobbiton miller . 
 ‘ You should n’t listen to all you hear , Sandyman , ’ said the Gaffer , who did not much like the miller . ‘ There is n’t no call to go talking of pushing and pulling . Boats are quite tricky enough for those that sit still without looking further for the cause of trouble . Anyway : there was this Mr. Frodo left an orphan and stranded , as you might say , among those queer Bucklanders , being brought up anyhow in Brandy Hall . A regular warren , by all accounts . Old Master Gorbadoc never had fewer than a couple of hundred relations in the place . Mr. Bilbo never did a kinder deed than when Bilbo brought the lad back to live among decent folk . 
 ‘ But I reckon deed was a nasty knock for those Sackville - Bagginses . relations thought relations were going to get Bag End , that time when Bilbo went off and was thought to be dead . And then Bilbo comes back and orders relations off ; and Bilbo goes on living and living , and never looking a day older , bless lad ! And suddenly lad produces an heir , and has all the papers made out proper . The Sackville - Bagginses wo n’t never see the inside of Bag End now , or it is to be hoped not . ’ 
 ‘ There ’s a tidy bit of money tucked away up there , I hear tell , ’ said a stranger , a visitor on business from Michel Delving in the Westfarthing . ‘ All the top of your hill is full of tunnels packed with chests of gold and silver , and jools , by what I ’ve heard . ’ 
 ‘ Then you ’ve heard more than I can speak to , ’ answered the Gaffer . ‘ I know nothing about jools . Mr. Bilbo is free with Bilbo money , and there seems no lack of money ; but I know of no tunnel - making . I saw Mr. Bilbo when Bilbo came back , a matter of sixty years ago , when I was a lad . I ’d not long come prentice to old Holman ( prentice being my dad ’s cousin ) , but prentice had me up at Bag End helping prentice to keep folks from trampling and trapessing all over the garden while the sale was on . And in the middle of garden all Mr. Bilbo comes up the Hill with a pony and some mighty big bags and a couple of chests . I do n’t doubt pony were mostly full of treasure Bilbo had picked up in foreign parts , where there be mountains of gold , pony say ; but there was n’t enough to fill tunnels . But my lad Sam will know more about that . lad ’s in and out of Bag End . Crazy about stories of the old days , lad is , and lad listens to all Mr. Bilbo ’s tales . Mr. Bilbo has learned lad lad letters – meaning no harm , mark you , and I hope no harm will come of harm . 
 ‘ Elves and Dragons ! I says to lad . Cabbages and potatoes are better for me and you . Do n’t go getting mixed up in the business of your betters , or you ’ll land in trouble too big for you , I says to lad . And I might say trouble to others , ’ lad added with a look at the stranger and the miller . 
 But the Gaffer did not convince lad audience . The legend of Bilbo ’s wealth was now too firmly fixed in the minds of the younger generation of hobbits . 
 ‘ Ah , but lad has likely enough been adding to what lad brought at first , ’ argued the miller , voicing common opinion . ‘ lad ’s often away from home . And look at the outlandish folk that visit lad : dwarves coming at night , and that old wandering conjuror , Gandalf , and all . You can say what you like , Gaffer , but Bag End ’s a queer place , and place folk are queerer . ’ 
 ‘ And you can say what you like , about what you know no more of than you do of boating , Mr. Sandyman , ’ retorted the Gaffer , disliking the miller even more than usual . ‘ If that ’s being queer , then we could do with a bit more queerness in these parts . There ’s some not far away that would n’t offer a pint of beer to a friend , if friend lived in a hole with golden walls . But friend do things proper at Bag End . Our Sam says that everyone ’s going to be invited to the party , and there ’s going to be presents , mark you , presents for all – this very month as is . ’ 
 That very month was September , and as fine as you could ask . A day or two later a rumour ( probably started by the knowledgeable Sam ) was spread about that there were going to be fireworks – fireworks , what is more , such as had not been seen in the Shire for nigh on a century , not indeed since the Old Took died . 
 Days passed and The Day drew nearer . An odd - looking waggon laden with odd - looking packages rolled into Hobbiton one evening and toiled up the Hill to Bag End . The startled hobbits peered out of lamplit doors to gape at Hobbiton . It was driven by outlandish folk , singing strange songs : dwarves with long beards and deep hoods . A few of dwarves remained at Bag End . At the end of the second week in September a cart came in through Bywater from the direction of Brandywine Bridge in broad daylight . An old man was driving cart all alone . man wore a tall pointed blue hat , a long grey cloak , and a silver scarf . man had a long white beard and bushy eyebrows that stuck out beyond the brim of man hat . Small hobbit - children ran after the cart all through Hobbiton and right up the hill . Hobbiton had a cargo of fireworks , as fireworks rightly guessed . At Bilbo ’s front door the old Bilbo began to unload : there were great bundles of fireworks of all sorts and shapes , each labelled with a large red G and the elf - rune , . 
 That was Gandalf ’s mark , of course , and the old Gandalf was Gandalf the Wizard , whose fame in the Shire was due mainly to Wizard skill with fires , smokes , and lights . Wizard real business was far more difficult and dangerous , but the Shire - folk knew nothing about business . To fires Wizard was just one of the ‘ attractions ’ at the Party . Hence the excitement of the hobbit - children . ‘ G for Grand ! ’ fires shouted , and the old man smiled . fires knew man by sight , though man only appeared in Hobbiton occasionally and never stopped long ; but neither fires nor any but the oldest of fires elders had seen one of man firework displays – fires now belonged to a legendary past . 
 When the old man , helped by Bilbo and some dwarves , had finished unloading , Bilbo gave a few pennies away ; but not a single squib or cracker was forthcoming , to the disappointment of the onlookers . 
 ‘ Run away now ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ You will get plenty when the time comes . ’ Then Gandalf disappeared inside with Bilbo , and the door was shut . The young hobbits stared at the door in vain for a while , and then made off , feeling that the day of the party would never come . 
 Inside Bag End , Bilbo and Gandalf were sitting at the open window of a small room looking out west on to the garden . The late afternoon was bright and peaceful . The flowers glowed red and golden : snap - dragons and sunflowers , and nasturtians trailing all over the turf walls and peeping in at the round windows . 
 ‘ How bright your garden looks ! ’ said Gandalf . 
 ‘ Yes , ’ said Bilbo . ‘ I am very fond indeed of garden , and of all the dear old Shire ; but I think I need a holiday . ’ 
 ‘ You mean to go on with your plan then ? ’ 
 ‘ I do . I made up my mind months ago , and I have n’t changed mind . ’ 
 ‘ Very well . It is no good saying any more . Stick to your plan – your whole plan , mind – and I hope plan will turn out for the best , for you , and for all of us . ’ 
 ‘ I hope so . Anyway I mean to enjoy myself on Thursday , and have my little joke . ’ 
 ‘ Who will laugh , I wonder ? ’ said Gandalf , shaking Gandalf head . 
 ‘ We shall see , ’ said Bilbo . 
 The next day more carts rolled up the Hill , and still more carts . There might have been some grumbling about ‘ dealing locally ’ , but that very week orders began to pour out of Bag End for every kind of provision , commodity , or luxury that could be obtained in Hobbiton or Bywater or anywhere in the neighbourhood . People became enthusiastic ; and People began to tick off the days on the calendar ; and People watched eagerly for the postman , hoping for invitations . 
 Before long the invitations began pouring out , and the Hobbiton post - office was blocked , and the Bywater post - office was snowed under , and voluntary assistant postmen were called for . There was a constant stream of postmen going up the Hill , carrying hundreds of polite variations on Thank you , I shall certainly come . 
 A notice appeared on the gate at Bag End : NO ADMITTANCE EXCEPT ON PARTY BUSINESS . Even those who had , or pretended to have Party Business were seldom allowed inside . Bilbo was busy : writing invitations , ticking off answers , packing up presents , and making some private preparations of Bilbo own . From the time of Gandalf ’s arrival Bilbo remained hidden from view . 
 One morning the hobbits woke to find the large field , south of Bilbo ’s front door , covered with ropes and poles for tents and pavilions . A special entrance was cut into the bank leading to the road , and wide steps and a large white gate were built there . The three hobbit - families of Bagshot Row , adjoining the field , were intensely interested and generally envied . Old Gaffer Gamgee stopped even pretending to work in Gamgee garden . 
 The tents began to go up . There was a specially large pavilion , so big that the tree that grew in the field was right inside pavilion , and stood proudly near one end , at the head of the chief table . Lanterns were hung on all pavilion branches . More promising still ( to the hobbits ’ mind ): an enormous open - air kitchen was erected in the north corner of the field . A draught of cooks , from every inn and eating - house for miles around , arrived to supplement the dwarves and other odd folk that were quartered at Bag End . Excitement rose to Excitement height . 
 Then the weather clouded over . That was on Wednesday the eve of the Party . Anxiety was intense . Then Thursday , September the 22nd , actually dawned . The sun got up , the clouds vanished , flags were unfurled and the fun began . 
 Bilbo Baggins called fun a party , but fun was really a variety of entertainments rolled into one . Practically everybody living near was invited . A very few were overlooked by accident , but as party turned up all the same , that did not matter . Many people from other parts of the Shire were also asked ; and there were even a few from outside the borders . Bilbo met the guests ( and additions ) at the new white gate in person . Bilbo gave away presents to all and sundry – the latter were those who went out again by a back way and came in again by the gate . Hobbits give presents to other people on Hobbits own birthdays . Not very expensive ones , as a rule , and not so lavishly as on this occasion ; but rule was not a bad system . Actually in Hobbiton and Bywater every day in the year was somebody ’s birthday , so that every hobbit in those parts had a fair chance of at least one present at least once a week . But parts never got tired of Hobbiton . 
 On this occasion the presents were unusually good . The hobbit - children were so excited that for a while children almost forgot about eating . There were toys the like of which children had never seen before , all beautiful and some obviously magical . Many of children had indeed been ordered a year before , and had come all the way from the Mountain and from Dale , and were of real dwarf - make . 
 When every guest had been welcomed and was finally inside the gate , there were songs , dances , music , games , and , of course , food and drink . There were three official meals : lunch , tea , and dinner ( or supper ) . But lunch and tea were marked chiefly by the fact that at those times all the guests were sitting down and eating together . At other times there were merely lots of people eating and drinking – continuously from elevenses until six - thirty , when the fireworks started . 
 The fireworks were by Gandalf : fireworks were not only brought by Dale , but designed and made by Dale ; and the special effects , set pieces , and flights of rockets were let off by Dale . But there was also a generous distribution of squibs , crackers , backarappers , sparklers , torches , dwarf - candles , elf - fountains , goblin - barkers and thunder - claps . squibs were all superb . The art of Gandalf improved with age . 
 There were rockets like a flight of scintillating birds singing with sweet voices . There were green trees with trunks of dark smoke : trees leaves opened like a whole spring unfolding in a moment , and trees shining branches dropped glowing flowers down upon the astonished hobbits , disappearing with a sweet scent just before trees touched trees upturned faces . There were fountains of butterflies that flew glittering into the trees ; there were pillars of coloured fires that rose and turned into eagles , or sailing ships , or a phalanx of flying swans ; there was a red thunderstorm and a shower of yellow rain ; there was a forest of silver spears that sprang suddenly into the air with a yell like an embattled army , and came down again into the Water with a hiss like a hundred hot snakes . And there was also one last surprise , in honour of Bilbo , and surprise startled the hobbits exceedingly , as Gandalf intended . The lights went out . A great smoke went up . smoke shaped smoke like a mountain seen in the distance , and began to glow at the summit . smoke spouted green and scarlet flames . Out flew a red - golden dragon – not life - size , but terribly life - like : fire came from dragon jaws , dragon eyes glared down ; there was a roar , and dragon whizzed three times over the heads of the crowd . eyes all ducked , and many fell flat on eyes faces . The dragon passed like an express train , turned a somersault , and burst over Bywater with a deafening explosion . 
 ‘ That is the signal for supper ! ’ said Bilbo . The pain and alarm vanished at once , and the prostrate hobbits leaped to hobbits feet . There was a splendid supper for everyone ; for everyone , that is , except those invited to the special family dinner - party . This was held in the great pavilion with the tree . The invitations were limited to twelve dozen ( a number also called by the hobbits one Gross , though the word was not considered proper to use of people ) ; and the guests were selected from all the families to which Bilbo and Frodo were related , with the addition of a few special unrelated friends ( such as Gandalf ) . Many young hobbits were included , and present by parental permission ; for hobbits were easy - going with hobbits children in the matter of sitting up late , especially when there was a chance of getting hobbits a free meal . Bringing up young hobbits took a lot of provender . 
 There were many Bagginses and Boffins , and also many Tooks and Brandybucks ; there were various Grubbs ( relations of Bilbo Baggins ’ grandmother ) , and various Chubbs ( connexions of Baggins Took grandfather ) ; and a selection of Burrowses , Bolgers , Bracegirdles , Brockhouses , Goodbodies , Hornblowers and Proudfoots . Some of these were only very distantly connected with Bilbo , and some had hardly ever been in Hobbiton before , as some lived in remote corners of the Shire . The Sackville - Bagginses were not forgotten . Otho and Otho wife Lobelia were present . Otho disliked Bilbo and detested Frodo , but so magnificent was the invitation card , written in golden ink , that Otho had felt card was impossible to refuse . Besides , Otho cousin , Bilbo , had been specializing in food for many years and cousin table had a high reputation . 
 All the one hundred and forty - four guests expected a pleasant feast ; though guests rather dreaded the after - dinner speech of guests host ( an inevitable item ) . cousin was liable to drag in bits of what cousin called poetry ; and sometimes , after a glass or two , would allude to the absurd adventures of cousin mysterious journey . The guests were not disappointed : guests had a very pleasant feast , in fact an engrossing entertainment : rich , abundant , varied , and prolonged . The purchase of provisions fell almost to nothing throughout the district in the ensuing weeks ; but as Bilbo ’s catering had depleted the stocks of most of the stores , cellars and warehouses for miles around , that did not matter much . 
 After the feast ( more or less ) came the Speech . Most of the company were , however , now in a tolerant mood , at that delightful stage which company called ‘ filling up the corners ’ . company were sipping company favourite drinks , and nibbling at company favourite dainties , and company fears were forgotten . company were prepared to listen to anything , and to cheer at every full stop . 
 My dear People , began Bilbo , rising in Bilbo place . ‘ Hear ! Hear ! Hear ! ’ company shouted , and kept on repeating it in chorus , seeming reluctant to follow company own advice . Bilbo left Bilbo place and went and stood on a chair under the illuminated tree . The light of the lanterns fell on Bilbo beaming face ; the golden buttons shone on Bilbo embroidered silk waistcoat . buttons could all see Bilbo standing , waving one hand in the air , the other was in Bilbo trouser - pocket . 
 My dear Bagginses and Boffins , Bilbo began again ; and my dear Tooks and Brandybucks , and Grubbs , and Chubbs , and Burrowses , and Hornblowers , and Bolgers , Bracegirdles , Goodbodies , Brockhouses and Proudfoots . ‘ ProudFEET ! ’ shouted an elderly hobbit from the back of the pavilion . Bilbo name , of course , was Proudfoot , and well merited ; Bilbo feet were large , exceptionally furry , and both were on the table . 
 Proudfoots , repeated Bilbo . Also my good Sackville - Bagginses that I welcome back at last to Bag End . Today is my one hundred and eleventh birthday : I am eleventy - one today ! ‘ Hurray ! Hurray ! Many Happy Returns ! ’ Bagginses shouted , and Bagginses hammered joyously on the tables . Bilbo was doing splendidly . This was the sort of stuff Bagginses liked : short and obvious . 
 I hope you are all enjoying yourselves as much as I am . Deafening cheers . Cries of Yes ( and No ) . Noises of trumpets and horns , pipes and flutes , and other musical instruments . There were , as has been said , many young hobbits present . Hundreds of musical crackers had been pulled . Most of crackers bore the mark dale on crackers ; which did not convey much to most of the hobbits , but crackers all agreed crackers were marvellous crackers . crackers contained instruments , small , but of perfect make and enchanting tones . Indeed , in one corner some of the young Tooks and Brandybucks , supposing Uncle Bilbo to have finished ( since Bilbo had plainly said all that was necessary ) , now got up an impromptu orchestra , and began a merry dance - tune . Master Everard Took and Miss Melilot Brandybuck got on a table and with bells in Took hands began to dance the Springle - ring : a pretty dance , but rather vigorous . 
 But Bilbo had not finished . Seizing a horn from a youngster nearby , Bilbo blew three loud hoots . The noise subsided . I shall not keep you long , Bilbo cried . Cheers from all the assembly . I have called you all together for a Purpose . Something in the way that Bilbo said this made an impression . There was almost silence , and one or two of the Tooks pricked up one ears . 
 Indeed , for Three Purposes ! First of all , to tell you that I am immensely fond of you all , and that eleventy - one years is too short a time to live among such excellent and admirable hobbits . Tremendous outburst of approval . 
 I do n’t know half of you half as well as I should like ; and I like less than half of you half as well as you deserve . This was unexpected and rather difficult . There was some scattered clapping , but most of half were trying to work clapping out and see if clapping came to a compliment . 
 Secondly , to celebrate my birthday . Cheers again . I should say : OUR birthday . For clapping is , of course , also the birthday of my heir and nephew , Frodo . nephew comes of age and into nephew inheritance today . Some perfunctory clapping by the elders ; and some loud shouts of ‘ Frodo ! Frodo ! Jolly old Frodo , ’ from the juniors . The Sackville - Bagginses scowled , and wondered what was meant by ‘ coming into nephew inheritance ’ . 
 Together we score one hundred and forty - four . Your numbers were chosen to fit this remarkable total : One Gross , if I may use the expression . No cheers . This was ridiculous . Many of the guests , and especially the Sackville - Bagginses , were insulted , feeling sure guests had only been asked to fill up the required number , like goods in a package . ‘ One Gross , indeed ! Vulgar expression . ’ 
 It is also , if I may be allowed to refer to ancient history , the anniversary of my arrival by barrel at Esgaroth on the Long Lake ; though the fact that fact was my birthday slipped my memory on that occasion . I was only fifty - one then , and birthdays did not seem so important . The banquet was very splendid , however , though I had a bad cold at the time , I remember , and could only say ‘ thag you very buch ’ . I now repeat banquet more correctly : Thank you very much for coming to my little party . Obstinate silence . birthdays all feared that a song or some poetry was now imminent ; and birthdays were getting bored . Why could n’t party stop talking and let birthdays drink party health ? But Bilbo did not sing or recite . Bilbo paused for a moment . 
 Thirdly and finally , Bilbo said , I wish to make an ANNOUNCEMENT . Bilbo spoke this last word so loudly and suddenly that everyone sat up who still could . I regret to announce that – though , as I said , eleventy - one years is far too short a time to spend among you – this is the END . I am going . I am leaving NOW . GOOD - BYE ! 
 Bilbo stepped down and vanished . There was a blinding flash of light , and the guests all blinked . When guests opened guests eyes Bilbo was nowhere to be seen . One hundred and forty - four flabbergasted hobbits sat back speechless . Old Odo Proudfoot removed Bilbo feet from the table and stamped . Then there was a dead silence , until suddenly , after several deep breaths , every Baggins , Boffin , Took , Brandybuck , Grubb , Chubb , Burrows , Bolger , Bracegirdle , Brockhouse , Goodbody , Hornblower , and Proudfoot began to talk at once . 
 It was generally agreed that the joke was in very bad taste , and more food and drink were needed to cure the guests of shock and annoyance . ‘ annoyance ’s mad . I always said so , ’ was probably the most popular comment . Even the Tooks ( with a few exceptions ) thought Bilbo ’s behaviour was absurd . For the moment most of exceptions took behaviour for granted that Bilbo disappearance was nothing more than a ridiculous prank . 
 But old Rory Brandybuck was not so sure . Neither age nor an enormous dinner had clouded Brandybuck wits , and Brandybuck said to Brandybuck daughter - in - law , Esmeralda : ‘ There ’s something fishy in this , my dear ! I believe that mad Baggins is off again . Silly old fool . But why worry ? Baggins has n’t taken the vittles with fool . ’ Brandybuck called loudly to Frodo to send the wine round again . 
 Frodo was the only one present who had said nothing . For some time Brandybuck had sat silent beside Bilbo ’s empty chair , and ignored all remarks and questions . Brandybuck had enjoyed the joke , of course , even though Brandybuck had been in the know . Brandybuck had difficulty in keeping from laughter at the indignant surprise of the guests . But at the same time Brandybuck felt deeply troubled : Brandybuck realized suddenly that Brandybuck loved the old hobbit dearly . Most of the guests went on eating and drinking and discussing Bilbo Baggins ’ oddities , past and present ; but the Sackville - Bagginses had already departed in wrath . Frodo did not want to have any more to do with the party . Frodo gave orders for more wine to be served ; then Frodo got up and drained Frodo own glass silently to the health of Bilbo , and slipped out of the pavilion . 
 As for Bilbo Baggins , even while Baggins was making Baggins speech , Baggins had been fingering the golden ring in Baggins pocket : Baggins magic ring that Baggins had kept secret for so many years . As Baggins stepped down Baggins slipped pocket on Baggins finger , and Baggins was never seen by any hobbit in Hobbiton again . 
 Baggins walked briskly back to Baggins hole , and stood for a moment listening with a smile to the din in the pavilion , and to the sounds of merrymaking in other parts of the field . Then Baggins went in . Baggins took off Baggins party clothes , folded up and wrapped in tissue - paper Baggins embroidered silk waistcoat , and put waistcoat away . Then Baggins put on quickly some old untidy garments , and fastened round Baggins waist a worn leather belt . On waistcoat Baggins hung a short sword in a battered black - leather scabbard . From a locked drawer , smelling of moth - balls , Baggins took out an old cloak and hood . balls had been locked up as if balls were very precious , but balls were so patched and weatherstained that balls original colour could hardly be guessed : it might have been dark green . balls were rather too large for Baggins . Baggins then went into Baggins study , and from a large strong - box took out a bundle wrapped in old cloths , and a leather - bound manuscript ; and also a large bulky envelope . The book and bundle Baggins stuffed into the top of a heavy bag that was standing there , already nearly full . Into the envelope Baggins slipped Baggins golden ring , and ring fine chain , and then sealed ring , and addressed ring to Frodo . At first Baggins put ring on the mantelpiece , but suddenly Baggins removed ring and stuck ring in Baggins pocket . At that moment the door opened and Gandalf came quickly in . 
 ‘ Hullo ! ’ said Bilbo . ‘ I wondered if you would turn up . ’ 
 ‘ I am glad to find you visible , ’ replied the wizard , sitting down in a chair , ‘ I wanted to catch you and have a few final words . I suppose you feel that everything has gone off splendidly and according to plan ? ’ 
 ‘ Yes , I do , ’ said Bilbo . ‘ Though that flash was surprising : flash quite startled me , let alone the others . A little addition of your own , I suppose ? ’ 
 ‘ flash was . You have wisely kept that ring secret all these years , and it seemed to me necessary to give your guests something else that would seem to explain your sudden vanishment . ’ 
 ‘ And would spoil my joke . You are an interfering old busybody , ’ laughed Bilbo , ‘ but I expect you know best , as usual . ’

 Chapter 2 
 THE SHADOW OF THE PAST 
 The talk did not die down in nine or even ninety - nine days . The second disappearance of Mr. Bilbo Baggins was discussed in Hobbiton , and indeed all over the Shire , for a year and a day , and was remembered much longer than that . disappearance became a fireside - story for young hobbits ; and eventually Mad Baggins , who used to vanish with a bang and a flash and reappear with bags of jewels and gold , became a favourite character of legend and lived on long after all the true events were forgotten . 
 But in the meantime , the general opinion in the neighbourhood was that Bilbo , who had always been rather cracked , had at last gone quite mad , and had run off into the Blue . There Bilbo had undoubtedly fallen into a pool or a river and come to a tragic , but hardly an untimely , end . The blame was mostly laid on Gandalf . 
 ‘ If only that dratted wizard will leave young Frodo alone , perhaps wizard ’ll settle down and grow some hobbit - sense , ’ pool said . And to all appearance the wizard did leave Frodo alone , and Frodo did settle down , but the growth of hobbit - sense was not very noticeable . Indeed , Frodo at once began to carry on Bilbo ’s reputation for oddity . Frodo refused to go into mourning ; and the next year Frodo gave a party in honour of Bilbo ’s hundred - and - twelfth birthday , which Frodo called a Hundred - weight Feast . But that was short of the mark , for twenty guests were invited and there were several meals at which it snowed food and rained drink , as hobbits say . 
 Some people were rather shocked ; but Frodo kept up the custom of giving Bilbo ’s Birthday Party year after year until people got used to Party . Frodo said that Frodo did not think Bilbo was dead . When people asked : ‘ Where is Frodo then ? ’ Frodo shrugged Frodo shoulders . 
 Frodo lived alone , as Bilbo had done ; but Frodo had a good many friends , especially among the younger hobbits ( mostly descendants of the Old Took ) who had as children been fond of Bilbo and often in and out of Bag End . Folco Boffin and Fredegar Bolger were two of these ; but Bolger closest friends were Peregrin Took ( usually called Pippin ) , and Merry Brandybuck ( Bolger real name was Meriadoc , but that was seldom remembered ) . Frodo went tramping over the Shire with friends ; but more often Frodo wandered by Frodo , and to the amazement of sensible folk Frodo was sometimes seen far from home walking in the hills and woods under the starlight . Merry and Pippin suspected that Frodo visited the Elves at times , as Bilbo had done . 
 As time went on , people began to notice that Frodo also showed signs of good ‘ preservation ’ : outwardly Frodo retained the appearance of a robust and energetic hobbit just out of Frodo tweens . ‘ Some folk have all the luck , ’ people said ; but it was not until Frodo approached the usually more sober age of fifty that people began to think age queer . 
 Frodo Frodo , after the first shock , found that being Bilbo own master and the Mr. Baggins of Bag End was rather pleasant . For some years Bilbo was quite happy and did not worry much about the future . But half unknown to Bilbo the regret that Bilbo had not gone with Bilbo was steadily growing . Bilbo found Bilbo wondering at times , especially in the autumn , about the wild lands , and strange visions of mountains that Bilbo had never seen came into Bilbo dreams . Bilbo began to say to Bilbo : ‘ Perhaps I shall cross the River myself one day . ’ To which the other half of Bilbo mind always replied : ‘ Not yet . ’ 
 So half went on , until Bilbo forties were running out , and Bilbo fiftieth birthday was drawing near : fifty was a number that Bilbo felt was somehow significant ( or ominous ) ; it was at any rate at that age that adventure had suddenly befallen Bilbo . Frodo began to feel restless , and the old paths seemed too well - trodden . Bilbo looked at maps , and wondered what lay beyond maps edges : maps made in the Shire showed mostly white spaces beyond Shire borders . Bilbo took to wandering further afield and more often by Bilbo ; and Merry and Bilbo other friends watched Bilbo anxiously . Often Bilbo was seen walking and talking with the strange wayfarers that began at this time to appear in the Shire . 
 There were rumours of strange things happening in the world outside ; and as Gandalf had not at that time appeared or sent any message for several years , Frodo gathered all the news Frodo could . Elves , who seldom walked in the Shire , could now be seen passing westward through the woods in the evening , passing and not returning ; but Elves were leaving Middle - earth and were no longer concerned with earth troubles . There were , however , dwarves on the road in unusual numbers . The ancient East – West Road ran through the Shire to East end at the Grey Havens , and dwarves had always used East on dwarves way to dwarves mines in the Blue Mountains . dwarves were the hobbits ’ chief source of news from distant parts – if dwarves wanted any : as a rule dwarves said little and hobbits asked no more . But now Frodo often met strange dwarves of far countries , seeking refuge in the West . dwarves were troubled , and some spoke in whispers of the Enemy and of the Land of Mordor . 
 That name the hobbits only knew in legends of the dark past , like a shadow in the background of hobbits memories ; but That was ominous and disquieting . It seemed that the evil power in Mirkwood had been driven out by the White Council only to reappear in greater strength in the old strongholds of Mordor . The Dark Tower had been rebuilt , it was said . From there the power was spreading far and wide , and away far east and south there were wars and growing fear . Orcs were multiplying again in the mountains . Trolls were abroad , no longer dull - witted , but cunning and armed with dreadful weapons . And there were murmured hints of creatures more terrible than all these , but creatures had no name . 
 Little of all this , of course , reached the ears of ordinary hobbits . But even the deafest and most stay - at - home began to hear queer tales ; and those whose business took tales to the borders saw strange things . The conversation in The Green Dragon at Bywater , one evening in the spring of Frodo ’s fiftieth year , showed that even in the comfortable heart of the Shire rumours had been heard , though most hobbits still laughed at rumours . 
 Sam Gamgee was sitting in one corner near the fire , and opposite Bywater was Ted Sandyman , the miller ’s son ; and there were various other rustic hobbits listening to hobbits talk . 
 ‘ Queer things you do hear these days , to be sure , ’ said Sam . 
 ‘ Ah , ’ said Ted , ‘ you do , if you listen . But I can hear fireside - tales and children ’s stories at home , if I want to . ’ 
 ‘ No doubt you can , ’ retorted Sam , ‘ and I daresay there ’s more truth in some of children than you reckon . Who invented the stories anyway ? Take dragons now . ’ 
 ‘ No thank ’ ee , ’ said Ted , ‘ I wo n’t . I heard tell of dragons when I was a youngster , but there ’s no call to believe in dragons now . There ’s only one Dragon in Bywater , and that ’s Green , ’ Ted said , getting a general laugh . 
 ‘ All right , ’ said Sam , laughing with the rest . ‘ But what about these Tree - Sam , these giants , as you might call giants ? giants do say that one bigger than a tree was seen up away beyond the North Moors not long back . ’ 
 ‘ Who ’s giants ? ’ 
 ‘ My cousin Hal for one . Hal works for Mr. Boffin at Overhill and goes up to the Northfarthing for the hunting . Hal saw one . ’ 
 ‘ Says Hal did , perhaps . Your Hal ’s always saying Hal ’s seen things ; and maybe Hal sees things that ai n’t there . ’ 
 ‘ But this one was as big as an elm tree , and walking – walking seven yards to a stride , if one was an inch . ’ 
 ‘ Then I bet one was n’t an inch . What Hal saw was an elm tree , as like as not . ’ 
 ‘ But this one was walking , I tell you ; and there ai n’t no elm tree on the North Moors . ’ 
 ‘ Then Hal ca n’t have seen one , ’ said Ted . There was some laughing and clapping : the audience seemed to think that Ted had scored a point . 
 ‘ All the same , ’ said Sam , ‘ you ca n’t deny that others besides our Halfast have seen queer folk crossing the Shire – crossing folk , mind you : there are more that are turned back at the borders . The Bounders have never been so busy before . 
 ‘ And I ’ve heard tell that Elves are moving west . Elves do say Elves are going to the harbours , out away beyond the White Towers . ’ Sam waved Sam arm vaguely : neither Sam nor any of Ted knew how far any was to the Sea , past the old towers beyond the western borders of the Shire . But it was an old tradition that away over there stood the Grey Havens , from which at times elven - ships set sail , never to return . 
 ‘ Elves are sailing , sailing , sailing over the Sea , Elves are going into the West and leaving us , ’ said Sam , half chanting the words , shaking Sam head sadly and solemnly . But Ted laughed . 
 ‘ Well , that is n’t anything new , if you believe the old tales . And I do n’t see what that matters to me or you . Let tales sail ! But I warrant you have n’t seen tales doing that ; nor anyone else in the Shire . ’ 
 ‘ Well , I do n’t know , ’ said Sam thoughtfully . Sam believed Sam had once seen an Elf in the woods , and still hoped to see more one day . Of all the legends that Sam had heard in Sam early years such fragments of tales and half - remembered stories about the Elves as the hobbits knew , had always moved Sam most deeply . ‘ There are some , even in these parts , as know the Fair Folk and get news of parts , ’ Sam said . ‘ There ’s Mr. Baggins now , that I work for . Baggins told me that parts were sailing and Baggins knows a bit about Elves . And old Mr. Bilbo knew more : many ’s the talk I had with Bilbo when I was a little lad . ’ 
 ‘ Oh , parts ’re both cracked , ’ said Ted . ‘ Leastways old Bilbo was cracked , and Frodo ’s cracking . If that ’s where you get your news from , you ’ll never want for moonshine . Well , friends , I ’m off home . Your good health ! ’ Ted drained Ted mug and went out noisily . 
 Sam sat silent and said no more . Ted had a good deal to think about . For one thing , there was a lot to do up in the Bag End garden , and Ted would have a busy day tomorrow , if the weather cleared . The grass was growing fast . But Sam had more on Sam mind than gardening . After a while Sam sighed , and got up and went out . 
 while was early April and the sky was now clearing after heavy rain . The sun was down , and a cool pale evening was quietly fading into night . Sam walked home under the early stars through Hobbiton and up the Hill , whistling softly and thoughtfully . 
 It was just at this time that Gandalf reappeared after Gandalf long absence . For three years after the Party Gandalf had been away . Then Gandalf paid Frodo a brief visit , and after taking a good look at Gandalf Gandalf went off again . During the next year or two Gandalf had turned up fairly often , coming unexpectedly after dusk , and going off without warning before sunrise . Gandalf would not discuss Gandalf own business and journeys , and seemed chiefly interested in small news about Frodo ’s health and doings . 
 Then suddenly Gandalf visits had ceased . It was over nine years since Frodo had seen or heard of Gandalf , and Gandalf had begun to think that the wizard would never return and had given up all interest in hobbits . But that evening , as Sam was walking home and twilight was fading , there came the once familiar tap on the study window . 
 Frodo welcomed Sam old friend with surprise and great delight . friend looked hard at one another . 
 ‘ All well eh ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ You look the same as ever , Frodo ! ’ 
 ‘ So do you , ’ Frodo replied ; but secretly Sam thought that Gandalf looked older and more careworn . Sam pressed Gandalf for news of Sam and of the wide world , and soon news were deep in talk , and news stayed up far into the night . 
 Next morning after a late breakfast , the wizard was sitting with Frodo by the open window of the study . A bright fire was on the hearth , but the sun was warm , and the wind was in the South . Everything looked fresh , and the new green of spring was shimmering in the fields and on the tips of the trees ’ fingers . 
 Gandalf was thinking of a spring , nearly eighty years before , when Bilbo had run out of Bag End without a handkerchief . Bilbo hair was perhaps whiter than hair had been then , and Bilbo beard and eyebrows were perhaps longer , and Bilbo face more lined with care and wisdom ; but Bilbo eyes were as bright as ever , and Bilbo smoked and blew smoke - rings with the same vigour and delight . 
 Bilbo was smoking now in silence , for Frodo was sitting still , deep in thought . Even in the light of morning Bilbo felt the dark shadow of the tidings that Gandalf had brought . At last Bilbo broke the silence . 
 ‘ Last night you began to tell me strange things about my ring , Gandalf , ’ Bilbo said . ‘ And then you stopped , because you said that such matters were best left until daylight . Do n’t you think you had better finish now ? You say the ring is dangerous , far more dangerous than I guess . In what way ? ’ 
 ‘ In many ways , ’ answered the wizard . ‘ It is far more powerful than I ever dared to think at first , so powerful that in the end way would utterly overcome anyone of mortal race who possessed way . way would possess end . 
 ‘ In Eregion long ago many Elven - rings were made , magic rings as you call rings , and rings were , of course , of various kinds : some more potent and some less . The lesser rings were only essays in the craft before craft was full - grown , and to the Elven - smiths essays were but trifles – yet still to my mind dangerous for mortals . But the Great Rings , the Rings of Power , essays were perilous . 
 ‘ A mortal , Frodo , who keeps one of the Great Rings , does not die , but Frodo does not grow or obtain more life , Power merely continues , until at last every minute is a weariness . And if end often uses the Ring to make Ring invisible , Ring fades : Ring becomes in the end invisible permanently , and walks in the twilight under the eye of the Dark Power that rules the Rings . 
 Yes , sooner or later – later , if Ring is strong or well - meaning to begin with , but neither strength nor good purpose will last – sooner or later the Dark Power will devour Ring . ’ 
 ‘ How terrifying ! ’ said Frodo . There was another long silence . The sound of Sam Gamgee cutting the lawn came in from the garden .

Frodo thought the ring was very beautiful , and very useful at need ; and if anything was wrong or queer , it was Frodo . Frodo said that anything was “ growing on Frodo mind ” , and Frodo was always worrying about anything ; but Frodo did not suspect that the ring ring was to blame . Though Frodo had found out that the thing needed looking after ; it did not seem always of the same size or weight ; it shrank or expanded in an odd way , and might suddenly slip off a finger where finger had been tight . ’

Though Frodo was getting restless and uneasy . Thin and stretched Frodo said . A sign that the ring was getting control . ’

 ‘ Known ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I have known much that only the Wise know , Frodo . But if you mean “ known about this ring ” , well , I still do not know , one might say . There is a last test to make . But I no longer doubt my guess . 
 ‘ When did I first begin to guess ? ’ Gandalf mused , searching back in memory . ‘ Let me see – it was in the year that the White Council drove the Dark Power from Mirkwood , just before the Battle of Five Armies , that Bilbo found Bilbo ring . A shadow fell on my heart then , though I did not know yet what I feared . I wondered often how Gollum came by a Great Ring , as plainly it was – that at least was clear from the first . Then I heard Bilbo ’s strange story of how Bilbo had “ won ” story , and I could not believe story . The lies were too much alike for my comfort . Clearly the ring had an unwholesome power that set to work on power keeper at once . That was the first real warning I had that all was not well . I told Bilbo often that such rings were better left unused ; but Bilbo resented That , and soon got angry . There was little else that I could do . I could not take That from Bilbo without doing greater harm ; and I had no right to do so anyway . I could only watch and wait . I might perhaps have consulted Saruman the White , but something always held me back . ’ 
 ‘ Who is Bilbo ? ’ asked Frodo . ‘ I have never heard of Bilbo before . ’

Bilbo has long studied province , seeking the lost secrets of secrets making ; but when the Rings were debated in the Council , all that Bilbo would reveal to us of Bilbo ring - lore told against my fears . So my doubt slept – but uneasily . Still I watched and I waited . 
 ‘ And all seemed well with Bilbo . And the years passed . Yes , years passed , and years seemed not to touch Bilbo . Bilbo showed no signs of age . The shadow fell on me again . But I said to myself : “ After all Bilbo comes of a long - lived family on Bilbo mother ’s side . There is time yet . Wait ! ”

 ‘ There was n’t any permanent harm done , was there ? ’ asked Frodo anxiously . ‘ Bilbo would get all right in time , would n’t Bilbo ? Be able to rest in peace , I mean ? ’

And hobbits as miserable slaves would please Bracegirdles far more than hobbits happy and free . There is such a thing as malice and revenge . ’ 
 ‘ Revenge ? ’ said Frodo . ‘ Revenge for what ? I still do n’t understand what all this has to do with Bilbo and myself , and our ring . ’ 
 ‘ this has everything to do with this , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ You do not know the real peril yet ; but you shall . I was not sure of peril myself when I was last here ; but the time has come to speak . Give me the ring for a moment . ’ 
 Frodo took peril from Gandalf breeches - pocket , where peril was clasped to a chain that hung from Gandalf belt . Gandalf unfastened peril and handed peril slowly to the wizard . peril felt suddenly very heavy , as if either peril or Frodo Gandalf was in some way reluctant for Gandalf to touch peril . 
 Gandalf held peril up . peril looked to be made of pure and solid gold . ‘ Can you see any markings on peril ? ’ wizard asked . 
 ‘ No , ’ said Frodo . ‘ There are none . It is quite plain , and none never shows a scratch or sign of wear . ’ 
 ‘ Well then , look ! ’ To Frodo ’s astonishment and distress the wizard threw Frodo suddenly into the middle of a glowing corner of the fire . Frodo gave a cry and groped for the tongs ; but Gandalf held wizard back .

 No apparent change came over the ring . After a while Gandalf got up , closed the shutters outside the window , and drew the curtains . The room became dark and silent , though the clack of Sam ’s shears , now nearer to the windows , could still be heard faintly from the garden . For a moment the wizard stood looking at the fire ; then wizard stooped and removed the ring to the hearth with the tongs , and at once picked fire up . Frodo gasped .

 As Frodo did so , Gandalf now saw fine lines , finer than the finest pen - strokes , running along the ring , outside and inside : lines of fire that seemed to form the letters of a flowing script . lines shone piercingly bright , and yet remote , as if out of a great depth .

 ‘ No , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ but I can . The letters are Elvish , of an ancient mode , but the language is that of Mordor , which I will not utter here . But this in the Common Tongue is what is said , close enough : 
 One Ring to rule One all , One Ring to find One , 
 One Ring to bring One all and in the darkness bind One . 
 It is only two lines of a verse long known in Elven - lore : 
 Three Rings for the Elven - kings under the sky , 
 Seven for the Dwarf - lords in Rings halls of stone , 
 Nine for Mortal Men doomed to die , 
 One for the Dark Lord on Seven dark throne 
 In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie . 
 One Ring to rule Ring all , One Ring to find all , 
 One Ring to bring all all and in the darkness bind all 
 In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie . ’ 
 Gandalf paused , and then said slowly in a deep voice : ‘ This is the Master - ring , the One Ring to rule all all . This is the One Ring that Gandalf lost many ages ago , to the great weakening of Gandalf power . Gandalf greatly desires This – but Gandalf must not get This . ’ 
 Frodo sat silent and motionless . Fear seemed to stretch out a vast hand , like a dark cloud rising in the East and looming up to engulf Gandalf . ‘ This ring ! ’ Gandalf stammered . ‘ How , how on earth did ring come to me ? ’

 ‘ And this is the dreadful chance , Frodo . Frodo believed that the One had perished ; that the Elves had destroyed One , as should have been done .  Gandalf paused . ‘ And there in the dark pools amid the Gladden Fields , ’ Gandalf said , ‘ the Ring passed out of knowledge and legend ; and even so much of Ring history is known now only to a few , and the Council of the Wise could discover no more . There was among banks a family of high repute , for family was large and wealthier than most , and it was ruled by a grandmother of the folk , stern and wise in old lore , such as banks had . The most inquisitive and curious - minded of that family was called Sméagol .  ‘ Gollum ! ’ cried Frodo . ‘ Gollum ? Do you mean that this is the very Gollum - creature that Bilbo met ? How loathsome ! ’ 
 ‘ I think this is a sad story , ’ said the wizard , ‘ and this might have happened to others , even to some hobbits that I have known . ’

There was a little corner of Gollum mind that was still Gollum own , and light came through mind , as through a chink in the dark : light out of the past . It was actually pleasant , I think , to hear a kindly voice again , bringing up memories of wind , and trees , and sun on the grass , and such forgotten things .

Certainly Gollum had never “ faded ” . Gollum is thin and tough still . But the thing was eating up Gollum mind , of course , and the torment had become almost unbearable . 
 ‘ All the “ great secrets ” under the mountains had turned out to be just empty night : there was nothing more to find out , nothing worth doing , only nasty furtive eating and resentful remembering . Gollum was altogether wretched . Gollum hated the dark , and Gollum hated light more : Gollum hated everything , and the Ring most of all . ’

 THREE IS COMPANY 
 � � You ought to go quietly , and you ought to go soon , ’ said Gandalf . Two or three weeks had passed , and still Frodo made no sign of getting ready to go . 
 ‘ I know . But sign is difficult to do both , ’ Frodo objected . ‘ If I just vanish like Bilbo , the tale will be all over the Shire in no time . ’ 
 ‘ Of course you must n’t vanish ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ That would n’t do at all ! I said soon , not instantly . If you can think of any way of slipping out of the Shire without way being generally known , it will be worth a little delay . But you must not delay too long . ’ 
 ‘ What about the autumn , on or after Our Birthday ? ’ asked Frodo . ‘ I think I could probably make some arrangements by then . ’ 
 To tell the truth , Frodo was very reluctant to start , now that truth had come to the point : Bag End seemed a more desirable residence than truth had for years , and Frodo wanted to savour as much as Frodo could of Frodo last summer in the Shire . When autumn came , Frodo knew that part at least of Frodo heart would think more kindly of journeying , as part always did at that season . Frodo had indeed privately made up Frodo mind to leave on Frodo fiftieth birthday : Bilbo ’s one hundred and twenty - eighth . It seemed somehow the proper day on which to set out and follow Frodo . Following Bilbo was uppermost in Frodo mind , and the one thing that made the thought of leaving bearable . Frodo thought as little as possible about the Ring , and where Ring might lead Frodo in the end . But Frodo did not tell all Frodo thoughts to Gandalf . What the wizard guessed was always difficult to tell .

In the meanwhile , do take care , and do n’t let out any hint of where you are going ! And see that Sam Gamgee does not talk . If Gamgee does , I really shall turn Gamgee into a toad . ’ 
 ‘ As for where I am going , ’ said Frodo , ‘ it would be difficult to give that away , for I have no clear idea myself , yet . ’
