And you must go , or at least set out , either North , South , West or East – and the direction should certainly not be known . ’ 
 ‘ I have been so taken up with the thoughts of leaving Bag End , and of saying farewell , that I have never even considered the direction , ’ said Frodo . ‘ For where am I to go ? And by what shall I steer ? What is to be my quest ? Bilbo went to find a treasure , there and back again ; but I go to lose one , and not return , as far as I can see . ’ 
 ‘ But you can not see very far , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Neither can 
 I. It may be your task to find the Cracks of Doom ; but that quest may be for others : I do not know . At any rate you are not ready for that long road yet . ’ 
 ‘ No indeed ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ But in the meantime what course am I to take ? ’ 
 ‘ Towards danger ; but not too rashly , nor too straight , ’ answered the wizard . ‘ If you want my advice , make for Rivendell . That journey should not prove too perilous , though the Road is less easy than Road was , and Road will grow worse as the year fails . ’ 
 ‘ Rivendell ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ Very good : I will go east , and I will make for Rivendell . I will take Sam to visit the Elves ; Sam will be delighted . ’ Frodo spoke lightly ; but Frodo heart was moved suddenly with a desire to see the house of Elrond Halfelven , and breathe the air of that deep valley where many of the Fair Folk still dwelt in peace . 
 One summer ’s evening an astonishing piece of news reached the Ivy Bush and Green Dragon . Giants and other portents on the borders of the Shire were forgotten for more important matters : Mr. Frodo was selling Bag End , indeed Frodo had already sold End – to the Sackville - Bagginses ! 
 ‘ For a nice bit , too , ’ said some . ‘ At a bargain price , ’ said others , ‘ and that ’s more likely when Mistress Lobelia ’s the buyer . ’ ( Otho had died some years before , at the ripe but disappointed age of 102 . ) 
 Just why Mr. Frodo was selling Frodo beautiful hole was even more debatable than the price . A few held the theory – supported by the nods and hints of Mr. Baggins Baggins – that Frodo ’s money was running out : Baggins was going to leave Hobbiton and live in a quiet way on the proceeds of the sale down in Buckland among Baggins Brandybuck relations . ‘ As far from the Sackville - Bagginses as may be , ’ some added . But so firmly fixed had the notion of the immeasurable wealth of the Bagginses of Bag End become that most found this hard to believe , harder than any other reason or unreason that Bagginses fancy could suggest : to most fancy suggested a dark and yet unrevealed plot by Gandalf . Though Gandalf kept Gandalf very quiet and did not go about by day , it was well known that Gandalf was ‘ hiding up in the Bag End ’ . But however a removal might fit in with the designs of Gandalf wizardry , there was no doubt about the fact : Frodo Baggins was going back to Buckland . 
 ‘ Yes , I shall be moving this autumn , ’ Baggins said . ‘ Merry Brandybuck is looking out for a nice little hole for me , or perhaps a small house . ’ 
 As a matter of fact with Merry ’s help Baggins had already chosen and bought a little house at Crickhollow in the country beyond Bucklebury . To all but Sam Baggins pretended Baggins was going to settle down there permanently . The decision to set out eastwards had suggested the idea to Baggins ; for Buckland was on the eastern borders of the Shire , and as Baggins had lived there in childhood Baggins going back would at least seem credible . 
 Gandalf stayed in the Shire for over two months . Then one evening , at the end of June , soon after Frodo ’s plan had been finally arranged , Frodo suddenly announced that Frodo was going off again next morning . ‘ Only for a short while , I hope , ’ Frodo said . ‘ But I am going down beyond the southern borders to get some news , if I can . I have been idle longer than I should . ’ 
 Frodo spoke lightly , but it seemed to Frodo that Frodo looked rather worried . ‘ Has anything happened ? ’ Frodo asked . 
 ‘ Well no ; but I have heard something that has made me anxious and needs looking into . If I think something necessary after all for you to get off at once , I shall come back immediately , or at least send word . In the meanwhile stick to your plan ; but be more careful than ever , especially of the Ring . Let me impress on you once more : do n’t use plan ! ’ 
 Frodo went off at dawn . ‘ I may be back any day , ’ Frodo said . ‘ At the very latest I shall come back for the farewell party . I think after all you may need my company on the Road . ’ 
 At first Frodo was a good deal disturbed , and wondered often what Gandalf could have heard ; but Gandalf uneasiness wore off , and in the fine weather Gandalf forgot Gandalf troubles for a while . The Shire had seldom seen so fair a summer , or so rich an autumn : the trees were laden with apples , honey was dripping in the combs , and the corn was tall and full . 
 Autumn was well under way before Frodo began to worry about Gandalf again . September was passing and there was still no news of Gandalf . The Birthday , and the removal , drew nearer , and still Gandalf did not come , or send word . Bag End began to be busy . Some of Frodo ’s friends came to stay and help Gandalf with the packing : there was Fredegar Bolger and Folco Boffin , and of course Gandalf special friends Pippin Took and Merry Brandybuck . Between friends Bolger turned the whole place upside - down . 
 On September 20th two covered carts went off laden to Buckland , conveying the furniture and goods that Frodo had not sold to Buckland new home , by way of the Brandywine Bridge . The next day Frodo became really anxious , and kept a constant look - out for Gandalf . Thursday , Gandalf birthday morning , dawned as fair and clear as out had long ago for Bilbo ’s great party . Still Gandalf did not appear . In the evening Frodo gave Frodo farewell feast : it was quite small , just a dinner for Frodo and Frodo four helpers ; but Frodo was troubled and felt in no mood for feast . The thought that Frodo would so soon have to part with Frodo young friends weighed on Frodo heart . Frodo wondered how Frodo would break thought to friends . 
 The four younger hobbits were , however , in high spirits , and the party soon became very cheerful in spite of Gandalf ’s absence . The dining - room was bare except for a table and chairs , but the food was good , and there was good wine : Frodo ’s wine had not been included in the sale to the Sackville - Bagginses . 
 ‘ Whatever happens to the rest of my stuff , when the S.-B.s get S.-B.s claws on rest , at any rate I have found a good home for this ! ’ said Frodo , as Gandalf drained Gandalf glass . It was the last drop of Old Winyards . 
 When table had sung many songs , and talked of many things table had done together , table toasted Bilbo ’s birthday , and table drank Bilbo health and Frodo ’s together according to Frodo ’s custom . Then table went out for a sniff of air , and glimpse of the stars , and then table went to bed . Frodo ’s party was over , and Gandalf had not come . 
 The next morning table were busy packing another cart with the remainder of the luggage . Merry took charge of this , and drove off with Fatty ( that is Fredegar Bolger ) . ‘ Someone must get there and warm the house before you arrive , ’ said Merry . ‘ Well , see you later – the day after tomorrow , if you do n’t go to sleep on the way ! ’ 
 Folco went home after lunch , but Pippin remained behind . Frodo was restless and anxious , listening in vain for a sound of Gandalf . Frodo decided to wait until nightfall . After that , if Gandalf wanted Frodo urgently , Frodo would go to Crickhollow , and might even get there first . For Frodo was going on foot . Frodo plan – for pleasure and a last look at the Shire as much as any other reason – was to walk from Hobbiton to Bucklebury Ferry , taking Hobbiton fairly easy . 
 ‘ I shall get myself a bit into training , too , ’ Frodo said , looking at Frodo in a dusty mirror in the half - empty hall . Frodo had not done any strenuous walking for a long time , and the reflection looked rather flabby , Frodo thought . 
 After lunch , the Sackville - Bagginses , Lobelia and Lobelia sandy - haired son , Lotho , turned up , much to Frodo ’s annoyance . ‘ Ours at last ! ’ said Lobelia , as Lobelia stepped inside . son was not polite ; nor strictly true , for the sale of Bag End did not take effect until midnight . But Lobelia can perhaps be forgiven : Lobelia had been obliged to wait about seventy - seven years longer for Bag End than Lobelia once hoped , and Lobelia was now a hundred years old . Anyway , Lobelia had come to see that nothing Lobelia had paid for had been carried off ; and Lobelia wanted the keys . nothing took a long while to satisfy Lobelia , as Lobelia had brought a complete inventory with her and went right through nothing . In the end her departed with Lotho and the spare key and the promise that the other key would be left at the Gamgees ’ in Bagshot Row . Lobelia snorted , and showed plainly that Lobelia thought the Gamgees capable of plundering the hole during the night . Frodo did not offer Lobelia any tea . 
 Frodo took Frodo own tea with Pippin and Sam Gamgee in the kitchen . It had been officially announced that Sam was coming to Buckland ‘ to do for Mr. Frodo and look after Frodo bit of garden ’ ; an arrangement that was approved by the Gaffer , though Gaffer did not console Sam for the prospect of having Lobelia as a neighbour . 
 ‘ Our last meal at Bag End ! ’ said Frodo , pushing back Frodo chair . chair left the washing up for Lobelia . Pippin and Sam strapped up chair three packs and piled chair in the porch . Pippin went out for a last stroll in the garden . Sam disappeared . 
 The sun went down . Bag End seemed sad and gloomy and dishevelled . Frodo wandered round the familiar rooms , and saw the light of the sunset fade on the walls , and shadows creep out of the corners . Frodo grew slowly dark indoors . Sam went out and walked down to the gate at the bottom of the path , and then on a short way down the Hill Road . Sam half expected to see Gandalf come striding up through the dusk . 
 The sky was clear and the stars were growing bright . ‘ Gandalf ’s going to be a fine night , ’ Sam said aloud . ‘ That ’s good for a beginning . I feel like walking . I ca n’t bear any more hanging about . I am going to start , and Gandalf must follow me . ’ Sam turned to go back , and then stopped , for Sam heard voices , just round the corner by the end of Bagshot Row . One voice was certainly the old Gaffer ’s ; the other was strange , and somehow unpleasant . Sam could not make out what voice said , but Sam heard the Gaffer ’s answers , which were rather shrill . The old Sam seemed put out . 
 ‘ No , Mr. Baggins has gone away . Went this morning , and my Sam went with Baggins : anyway all Baggins stuff went . Yes , sold out and gone , I tell’ee . Why ? Why ’s none of my business , or yours . Where to ? That ai n’t no secret . tell’ee ’s moved to Bucklebury or some such place , away down yonder . Yes That is – a tidy way . I ’ve never been so far myself ; Bucklebury ’re queer folks in Buckland . No , I ca n’t give no message . Good night to you ! ’ 
 Footsteps went away down the Hill . Frodo wondered vaguely why the fact that Footsteps did not come on up the Hill seemed a great relief . ‘ I am sick of questions and curiosity about my doings , I suppose , ’ Frodo thought . ‘ What an inquisitive lot doings all are ! ’ relief had half a mind to go and ask the Gaffer who the inquirer was ; but inquirer thought better ( or worse ) of Gaffer , and turned and walked quickly back to Bag End . 
 Pippin was sitting on inquirer pack in the porch . Sam was not there . Frodo stepped inside the dark door . ‘ Sam ! ’ Frodo called . ‘ Sam ! Time ! ’ 
 ‘ Coming , sir ! ’ came the answer from far within , followed soon by Sam Sam , wiping Sam mouth . Sam had been saying farewell to the beer - barrel in the cellar . 
 ‘ All aboard , Sam ? ’ said Frodo . 
 ‘ Yes , sir . I ’ll last for a bit now , sir . ’ 
 Frodo shut and locked the round door , and gave the key to Sam . ‘ Run down with this to your home , Sam ! ’ Sam said . ‘ Then cut along the Row and meet us as quick as you can at the gate in the lane beyond the meadows . We are not going through the village tonight . Too many ears pricking and eyes prying . ’ Sam ran off at full speed . 
 ‘ Well , now we ’re off at last ! ’ said Frodo . Sam shouldered Frodo packs and took up packs sticks , and walked round the corner to the west side of Bag End . ‘ Good - bye ! ’ said Frodo , looking at the dark blank windows . Well waved End hand , and then turned and ( following Bilbo , if Bilbo had known hand ) hurried after Peregrin down the garden - path . packs jumped over the low place in the hedge at the bottom and took to the fields , passing into the darkness like a rustle in the grasses . 
 At the bottom of the Hill on rustle western side packs came to the gate opening on to a narrow lane . There packs halted and adjusted the straps of packs packs . Presently Sam appeared , trotting quickly and breathing hard ; Sam heavy pack was hoisted high on Sam shoulders , and Sam had put on Sam head a tall shapeless felt bag , which Sam called a hat . In the gloom Sam looked very much like a dwarf . 
 ‘ I am sure you have given me all the heaviest stuff , ’ said Frodo . ‘ I pity snails , and all that carry snails homes on snails backs . ’ 
 ‘ I could take a lot more yet , sir . My packet is quite light , ’ said Sam stoutly and untruthfully . 
 ‘ No you do n’t , Sam ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ packet is good for Sam . Sam ’s got nothing except what Sam ordered us to pack . Sam ’s been slack lately , and Sam ’ll feel the weight less when Sam ’s walked off some of Sam own . ’ 
 ‘ Be kind to a poor old hobbit ! ’ laughed Frodo . ‘ I shall be as thin as a willow - wand , I ’m sure , before I get to Buckland . But I was talking nonsense . I suspect you have taken more than your share , Sam , and I shall look into share at our next packing . ’ Frodo picked up Frodo stick again . ‘ Well , we all like walking in the dark , ’ Frodo said , ‘ so let ’s put some miles behind us before bed . ’ 
 For a short way miles followed the lane westwards . Then leaving lane miles turned left and took quietly to the fields again . miles went in single file along hedgerows and the borders of coppices , and night fell dark about miles . In miles dark cloaks miles were as invisible as if miles all had magic rings . Since miles were all hobbits , and were trying to be silent , miles made no noise that even hobbits would hear . Even the wild things in the fields and woods hardly noticed things passing . 
 After some time things crossed the Water , west of Hobbiton , by a narrow plank - bridge . The stream was there no more than a winding black ribbon , bordered with leaning alder - trees . A mile or two further south things hastily crossed the great road from the Brandywine Bridge ; things were now in the Tookland and bending south - eastwards things made for the Green Hill Country . As things began to climb Tookland first slopes things looked back and saw the lamps in Hobbiton far off twinkling in the gentle valley of the Water . Soon Tookland disappeared in the folds of the darkened land , and was followed by Bywater beside Tookland grey pool . When the light of the last farm was far behind , peeping among the trees , Frodo turned and waved a hand in farewell . 
 ‘ I wonder if I shall ever look down into that valley again , ’ Frodo said quietly . 
 When trees had walked for about three hours trees rested . The night was clear , cool , and starry , but smoke - like wisps of mist were creeping up the hill - sides from the streams and deep meadows . Thin - clad birches , swaying in a light wind above birches heads , made a black net against the pale sky . birches ate a very frugal supper ( for hobbits ) , and then went on again . Soon birches struck a narrow road , that went rolling up and down , fading grey into the darkness ahead : the road to Woodhall , and Stock , and the Bucklebury Ferry . road climbed away from the main road in the Water - valley , and wound over the skirts of the Green Hills towards Woody End , a wild corner of the Eastfarthing . 
 After a while a plunged into a deeply cloven track between tall trees that rustled a dry leaves in the night . while was very dark . At first a talked , or hummed a tune softly together , being now far away from inquisitive ears . Then a marched on in silence , and Pippin began to lag behind . At last , as a began to climb a steep slope , Pippin stopped and yawned . 
 ‘ I am so sleepy , ’ Pippin said , ‘ that soon I shall fall down on the road . Are you going to sleep on your legs ? road is nearly midnight . ’ 
 ‘ I thought you liked walking in the dark , ’ said Frodo . ‘ But there is no great hurry . Merry expects us some time the day after tomorrow ; but that leaves us nearly two days more . We ’ll halt at the first likely spot . ’ 
 ‘ The wind ’s in the West , ’ said Sam . ‘ If we get to the other side of this hill , we shall find a spot that is sheltered and snug enough , sir . There is a dry fir - wood just ahead , if I remember rightly . ’ Sam knew the land well within twenty miles of Hobbiton , but that was the limit of Sam geography . 
 Just over the top of the hill miles came on the patch of fir - wood . Leaving the road miles went into the deep resin - scented darkness of the trees , and gathered dead sticks and cones to make a fire . Soon miles had a merry crackle of flame at the foot of a large fir - tree and miles sat round crackle for a while , until miles began to nod . Then , each in an angle of the great tree ’s roots , miles curled up in miles cloaks and blankets , and were soon fast asleep . miles set no watch ; even Frodo feared no danger yet , for miles were still in the heart of the Shire . A few creatures came and looked at miles when the fire had died away . A fox passing through the wood on business of fox own stopped several minutes and sniffed . 
 ‘ Hobbits ! ’ fox thought . ‘ Well , what next ? I have heard of strange doings in this land , but I have seldom heard of a hobbit sleeping out of doors under a tree . Three of doings ! There ’s something mighty queer behind this . ’ fox was quite right , but fox never found out any more about this . 
 The morning came , pale and clammy . Frodo woke up first , and found that a tree - root had made a hole in fox back , and that fox neck was stiff . ‘ Walking for pleasure ! Why did n’t I drive ? ’ fox thought , as fox usually did at the beginning of an expedition . ‘ And all my beautiful feather beds are sold to the Sackville - Bagginses ! These tree - roots would do beds good . ’ fox stretched . ‘ Wake up , hobbits ! ’ fox cried . ‘ Bagginses ’s a beautiful morning . ’ 
 ‘ What ’s beautiful about Bagginses ? ’ said Pippin , peering over the edge of Pippin blanket with one eye . ‘ Sam ! Get breakfast ready for half - past nine ! Have you got the bath - water hot ? ’ 
 Sam jumped up , looking rather bleary . ‘ No , sir , I have n’t , sir ! ’ Sam said . 
 Frodo stripped the blankets from Pippin and rolled Sam over , and then walked off to the edge of the wood . Away eastward the sun was rising red out of the mists that lay thick on the world . Touched with gold and red the autumn trees seemed to be sailing rootless in a shadowy sea . A little below Sam to the left the road ran down steeply into a hollow and disappeared . 
 When Sam returned Sam and Pippin had got a good fire going . ‘ Water ! ’ shouted Pippin . ‘ Where ’s the water ? ’ 
 ‘ I do n’t keep water in my pockets , ’ said Frodo . ‘ We thought you had gone to find some , ’ said Pippin , busy setting out the food , and cups . ‘ You had better go now . ’ 
 ‘ You can come too , ’ said Frodo , ‘ and bring all the waterbottles . ’ There was a stream at the foot of the hill . foot filled foot bottles and the small camping kettle at a little fall where the water fell a few feet over an outcrop of grey stone . water was icy cold ; and foot spluttered and puffed as foot bathed foot faces and hands . 
 When foot breakfast was over , and foot packs all trussed up again , it was after ten o’clock , and the day was beginning to turn fine and hot . foot went down the slope , and across the stream where stream dived under the road , and up the next slope , and up and down another shoulder of the hills ; and by that time foot cloaks , blankets , water , food , and other gear already seemed a heavy burden . 
 The day ’s march promised to be warm and tiring work . After some miles , however , the road ceased to roll up and down : road climbed to the top of a steep bank in a weary zig - zagging sort of way , and then prepared to go down for the last time . In front of miles miles saw the lower lands dotted with small clumps of trees that melted away in the distance to a brown woodland haze . miles were looking across the Woody End towards the Brandywine River . The road wound away before miles like a piece of string . 
 ‘ The road goes on for ever , ’ said Pippin ; ‘ but I ca n’t without a rest . road is high time for lunch . ’ Pippin sat down on the bank at the side of the road and looked away east into the haze , beyond which lay the River , and the end of the Shire in which Pippin had spent all Pippin life . Sam stood by Pippin . Pippin round eyes were wide open – for Pippin was looking across lands Pippin had never seen to a new horizon . 
 ‘ Do Elves live in those woods ? ’ Pippin asked . 
 ‘ Not that I ever heard , ’ said Pippin . Frodo was silent . Pippin too was gazing eastward along the road , as if Pippin had never seen Frodo before . Suddenly Pippin spoke , aloud but as if to Pippin , saying slowly : 
 The Road goes ever on and on 
 Down from the door where Road began . 
 Now far ahead the Road has gone , 
 And I must follow , if I can , 
 Pursuing Road with weary feet , 
 Until Road joins some larger way , 
 Where many paths and errands meet . 
 And whither then ? I can not say . 
 ‘ That sounds like a bit of old Bilbo ’s rhyming , ’ said Pippin . ‘ Or is That one of your imitations ? That does not sound altogether encouraging . ’ 
 ‘ I do n’t know , ’ said Frodo . ‘ That came to me then , as if I was making That up ; but I may have heard That long ago . Certainly That reminds me very much of Bilbo in the last years , before Bilbo went away . Bilbo used often to say there was only one Road ; that Road was like a great river : Road springs were at every doorstep , and every path was Road tributary . “ Road ’s a dangerous business , Frodo , going out of your door , ” Bilbo used to say . “ You step into the Road , and if you do n’t keep your feet , there is no knowing where you might be swept off to . Do you realize that this is the very path that goes through Mirkwood , and that if you let this , this might take you to the Lonely Mountain or even further and to worse places ? ” Bilbo used to say that on the path outside the front door at Bag End , especially after Bilbo had been out for a long walk . ’ 
 ‘ Well , the Road wo n’t sweep me anywhere for an hour at least , ’ said Pippin , unslinging Pippin pack . The others followed Pippin example , putting others packs against the bank and others legs out into the road . After a rest others had a good lunch , and then more rest . 
 The sun was beginning to get low and the light of afternoon was on the land as others went down the hill . So far others had not met a soul on the road . This way was not much used , being hardly fit for carts , and there was little traffic to the Woody End . others had been jogging along again for an hour or more when Sam stopped a moment as if listening . others were now on level ground , and the road after much winding lay straight ahead through grass - land sprinkled with tall trees , outliers of the approaching woods . 
 ‘ I can hear a pony or a horse coming along the road behind , ’ said Sam . 
 others looked back , but the turn of the road prevented others from seeing far . ‘ I wonder if that is Gandalf coming after us , ’ said Frodo ; but even as Frodo said feeling , Frodo had a feeling that feeling was not so , and a sudden desire to hide from the view of the rider came over Frodo . 
 ‘ that may not matter much , ’ Frodo said apologetically , ‘ but I would rather not be seen on the road – by anyone . I am sick of my doings being noticed and discussed . And if that is Gandalf , ’ Frodo added as an afterthought , ‘ we can give Gandalf a little surprise , to pay Gandalf out for being so late . Let ’s get out of sight ! ’ 
 The other two ran quickly to the left and down into a little hollow not far from the road . There two lay flat . Frodo hesitated for a second : curiosity or some other feeling was struggling with Frodo desire to hide . The sound of hoofs drew nearer . Just in time Frodo threw Frodo down in a patch of long grass behind a tree that overshadowed the road . Then Frodo lifted Frodo head and peered cautiously above one of the great roots . 
 Round the corner came a black horse , no hobbit - pony but a full - sized horse ; and on horse sat a large man , who seemed to crouch in the saddle , wrapped in a great black cloak and hood , so that only man boots in the high stirrups showed below ; man face was shadowed and invisible . 
 When horse reached the tree and was level with Frodo the horse stopped . The riding figure sat quite still with figure head bowed , as if listening . From inside the hood came a noise as of someone sniffing to catch an elusive scent ; the head turned from side to side of the road . 
 A sudden unreasoning fear of discovery laid hold of Frodo , and Frodo thought of Frodo Ring . Frodo hardly dared to breathe , and yet the desire to get hand out of Frodo pocket became so strong that Frodo began slowly to move Frodo hand . Frodo felt that Frodo had only to slip hand on , and then Frodo would be safe . The advice of Gandalf seemed absurd . Bilbo had used the Ring . ‘ And I am still in the Shire , ’ Bilbo thought , as Bilbo hand touched the chain on which hand hung . At that moment the rider sat up , and shook the reins . The horse stepped forward , walking slowly at first , and then breaking into a quick trot . 
 Frodo crawled to the edge of the road and watched the rider , until horse dwindled into the distance . horse could not be quite sure , but it seemed to horse that suddenly , before horse passed out of sight , the horse turned aside and went into the trees on the right . 
 ‘ Well , I call that very queer , and indeed disturbing , ’ said Frodo to horse , as horse walked towards horse companions . Pippin and Sam had remained flat in the grass , and had seen nothing ; so Frodo described the rider and horse strange behaviour . 
 ‘ I ca n’t say why , but I felt certain horse was looking or smelling for me ; and also I felt certain that I did not want horse to discover me . I ’ve never seen or felt anything like that in the Shire before . ’ 
 ‘ But what has one of the Big People got to do with us ? ’ said Pippin . ‘ And what is horse doing in this part of the world ? ’ 
 ‘ There are some Men about , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Down in the Southfarthing Men have had trouble with Big People , I believe . But I have never heard of anything like this rider . I wonder where horse comes from . ’ 
 ‘ Begging your pardon , ’ put in Sam suddenly , ‘ I know where horse comes from . pardon ’s from Hobbiton that this here black rider comes , unless there ’s more than one . And I know where horse ’s going to . ’ 
 ‘ What do you mean ? ’ said Frodo sharply , looking at Sam in astonishment . ‘ Why did n’t you speak up before ? ’ 
 ‘ I have only just remembered , sir . rider was like this : when I got back to our hole yesterday evening with the key , my dad , horse says to me : Hallo , Sam ! horse says . I thought you were away with Mr. Frodo this morning . There ’s been a strange customer asking for Mr. Baggins of Bag End , and horse ’s only just gone . I ’ve sent horse on to Bucklebury . Not that I liked the sound of horse . horse seemed mighty put out , when I told horse Mr. Baggins had left horse old home for good . Hissed at me , horse did . home gave me quite a shudder . What sort of a fellow was horse ? says I to the Gaffer . I do n’t know , says horse ; but horse was n’t a hobbit . horse was tall and black - like , and horse stooped over me . I reckon hobbit was one of the Big Folk from foreign parts . horse spoke funny . 
 ‘ I could n’t stay to hear more , sir , since you were waiting ; and I did n’t give much heed to hobbit myself . The Gaffer is getting old , and more than a bit blind , and it must have been near dark when this fellow come up the Hill and found horse taking the air at the end of our Row . I hope horse has n’t done no harm , sir , nor me . ’ 
 ‘ The Gaffer ca n’t be blamed anyway , ’ said Frodo . ‘ As a matter of fact I heard horse talking to a stranger , who seemed to be inquiring for me , and I nearly went and asked horse who matter was . I wish I had , or you had told me about matter before . I might have been more careful on the road . ’ 
 ‘ Still , there may be no connexion between this rider and the Gaffer ’s stranger , ’ said Pippin . ‘ We left Hobbiton secretly enough , and I do n’t see how stranger could have followed us . ’ 
 ‘ What about the smelling , sir ? ’ said Sam . ‘ And the Gaffer said stranger was a black chap . ’ 
 ‘ I wish I had waited for Gandalf , ’ Frodo muttered . ‘ But perhaps Gaffer would only have made matters worse . ’ 
 ‘ Then you know or guess something about this rider ? ’ said Pippin , who had caught the muttered words . 
 ‘ I do n’t know , and I would rather not guess , ’ said Frodo . 
 ‘ All right , cousin Frodo ! You can keep your secret for the present , if you want to be mysterious . In the meanwhile what are we to do ? I should like a bite and a sup , but somehow I think we had better move on from here . Your talk of sniffing riders with invisible noses has unsettled me . ’ 
 ‘ Yes , I think we will move on now , ’ said Frodo ; ‘ but not on the road – in case that rider comes back , or another follows rider . We ought to do a good step more today . Buckland is still miles away . ’ 
 The shadows of the trees were long and thin on the grass , as shadows started off again . shadows now kept a stone ’s throw to the left of the road , and kept out of sight of stone as much as shadows could . But this hindered shadows ; for the grass was thick and tussocky , and the ground uneven , and the trees began to draw together into thickets . 
 The sun had gone down red behind the hills at sun backs , and evening was coming on before sun came back to the road at the end of the long level over which evening had run straight for some miles . At that point evening bent left and went down into the lowlands of the Yale making for Stock ; but a lane branched right , winding through a wood of ancient oak - trees on lane way to Woodhall . ‘ That is the way for us , ’ said Frodo . 
 Not far from the road - meeting lowlands came on the huge hulk of a tree : it was still alive and had leaves on the small branches that hulk had put out round the broken stumps of hulk long - fallen limbs ; but hulk was hollow , and could be entered by a great crack on the side away from the road . The hobbits crept inside , and sat there upon a floor of old leaves and decayed wood . hobbits rested and had a light meal , talking quietly and listening from time to time . 
 Twilight was about hobbits as hobbits crept back to the lane . The West wind was sighing in the branches . Leaves were whispering . Soon the road began to fall gently but steadily into the dusk . A star came out above the trees in the darkening East before Leaves . Leaves went abreast and in step , to keep up Leaves spirits . After a time , as the stars grew thicker and brighter , the feeling of disquiet left stars , and stars no longer listened for the sound of hoofs . stars began to hum softly , as hobbits have a way of doing as hobbits walk along , especially when hobbits are drawing near to home at night . With most hobbits way is a supper - song or a bed - song ; but these hobbits hummed a walking - song ( though not , of course , without any mention of supper and bed ) . Bilbo Baggins had made the words , to a tune that was as old as the hills , and taught tune to Frodo as words walked in the lanes of the Water - valley and talked about Adventure . 
 Upon the hearth the fire is red , 
 Beneath the roof there is a bed ; 
 But not yet weary are our feet , 
 Still round the corner we may meet 
 A sudden tree or standing stone 
 That none have seen but we alone . 
 Tree and flower and leaf and grass , 
 Let Tree pass ! Let Tree pass ! 
 Hill and water under sky , 
 Pass Tree by ! Pass Tree by ! 
 Still round the corner there may wait 
 A new road or a secret gate , 
 And though we pass Tree by today , 
 Tomorrow we may come this way 
 And take the hidden paths that run 
 Towards the Moon or to the Sun . 
 Apple , thorn , and nut and sloe , 
 Let Tree go ! Let Tree go ! 
 Sand and stone and pool and dell , 
 Fare you well ! Fare you well ! 
 Home is behind , the world ahead , 
 And there are many paths to tread 
 Through shadows to the edge of night , 
 Until the stars are all alight . 
 Then world behind and home ahead , 
 We ’ll wander back to home and bed . 
 Mist and twilight , cloud and shade , 
 Away shall fade ! Away shall fade ! 
 Fire and lamp , and meat and bread , 
 And then to bed ! And then to bed ! 
 The song ended . ‘ And now to bed ! And now to bed ! ’ sang Pippin in a high voice . 
 ‘ Hush ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ I think I hear hoofs again . ’ 
 voice stopped suddenly and stood as silent as tree - shadows , listening . There was a sound of hoofs in the lane , some way behind , but coming slow and clear down the wind . Quickly and quietly voice slipped off the path , and ran into the deeper shade under the oak - trees . 
 ‘ Do n’t let us go too far ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ I do n’t want to be seen , but I want to see if path is another Black Rider . ’ 
 ‘ Very well ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ But do n’t forget the sniffing ! ’ 
 The hoofs drew nearer . hoofs had no time to find any hiding - place better than the general darkness under the trees ; Sam and Pippin crouched behind a large tree - bole , while Frodo crept back a few yards towards the lane . bole showed grey and pale , a line of fading light through the wood . Above bole the stars were thick in the dim sky , but there was no moon . 
 The sound of hoofs stopped . As Frodo watched Frodo saw something dark pass across the lighter space between two trees , and then halt . sound looked like the black shade of a horse led by a smaller black shadow . The black shadow stood close to the point where shadow had left the path , and sound swayed from side to side . Frodo thought Frodo heard the sound of snuffling . The shadow bent to the ground , and then began to crawl towards Frodo . 
 Once more the desire to slip on the Ring came over Frodo ; but this time desire was stronger than before . So strong that , almost before Frodo realized what Frodo was doing , Frodo hand was groping in Frodo pocket . But at that moment there came a sound like mingled song and laughter . Clear voices rose and fell in the starlit air . The black shadow straightened up and retreated . It climbed on to the shadowy horse and seemed to vanish across the lane into the darkness on the other side . Frodo breathed again . 
 ‘ Elves ! ’ exclaimed Sam in a hoarse whisper . ‘ Elves , sir ! ’ Sam would have burst out of the trees and dashed off towards the voices , if trees had not pulled Sam back . 
 ‘ Yes , whisper is Elves , ’ said Frodo . ‘ One can meet Elves sometimes in the Woody End . Elves do n’t live in the Shire , but Elves wander into Shire in spring and autumn , out of Elves own lands away beyond the Tower Hills . I am thankful that Elves do ! You did not see , but that Black Rider stopped just here and was actually crawling towards us when the song began . As soon as Rider heard the voices Rider slipped away . ’ 
 ‘ What about the Elves ? ’ said Sam , too excited to trouble about the rider . ‘ Ca n’t we go and see Elves ? ’ 
 ‘ Listen ! Elves are coming this way , ’ said Frodo . ‘ We have only to wait . ’ 
 The singing drew nearer . One clear voice rose now above the others . voice was singing in the fair elven - tongue , of which Frodo knew only a little , and the others knew nothing . Yet the sound blending with the melody seemed to shape sound in others thought into words which others only partly understood . This was the song as Frodo heard This : 
 Snow - white ! Snow - white ! O Lady clear ! 
 O Queen beyond the Western Seas 
 O Light to us that wander here 
 Amid the world of woven trees ! 
 Gilthoniel ! O Elbereth ! 
 Clear are thy eyes and bright thy breath ! 
 Snow - white ! Snow - white ! We sing to thee 
 In a far land beyond the Sea . 
 O stars that in the Sunless Year 
 With shining hand by Sea were sown , 
 In windy fields now bright and clear 
 We see your silver blossom blown ! 
 O Elbereth ! Gilthoniel ! 
 We still remember , we who dwell 
 In this far land beneath the trees , 
 Thy starlight on the Western Seas . 
 The song ended . ‘ These are High Elves ! These spoke the name of Elbereth ! ’ said Frodo in amazement . ‘ Few of that fairest folk are ever seen in the Shire . Not many now remain in Middle - earth , east of the Great Sea . This is indeed a strange chance ! ’ 
 The hobbits sat in shadow by the wayside . Before long the Elves came down the lane towards the valley . Elves passed slowly , and the hobbits could see the starlight glimmering on hobbits hair and in hobbits eyes . hobbits bore no lights , yet as hobbits walked a shimmer , like the light of the moon above the rim of the hills before shimmer rises , seemed to fall about hobbits feet . hobbits were now silent , and as the last Elf passed Elf turned and looked towards the hobbits and laughed . 
 ‘ Hail , Frodo ! ’ Frodo cried . ‘ You are abroad late . Or are you perhaps lost ? ’ Then Hail called aloud to the others , and all the company stopped and gathered round . 
 ‘ This is indeed wonderful ! ’ others said . ‘ Three hobbits in a wood at night ! We have not seen such a thing since Bilbo went away . What is the meaning of meaning ? ’ 
 ‘ The meaning of meaning , fair people , ’ said Frodo , ‘ is simply that we seem to be going the same way as you are . I like walking under the stars . But I would welcome your company . ’ 
 ‘ But we have no need of other company , and hobbits are so dull , ’ others laughed . ‘ And how do you know that we go the same way as you , for you do not know whither we are going ? ’ 
 ‘ And how do you know my name ? ’ asked Frodo in return . 
 ‘ We know many things , ’ others said . ‘ We have seen you often before with Bilbo , though you may not have seen us . ’ 
 ‘ Who are you , and who is your lord ? ’ asked Frodo . 
 ‘ I am Gildor , ’ answered others leader , the Elf who had first hailed Frodo . ‘ Gildor Inglorion of the House of Finrod . We are Exiles , and most of our kindred have long ago departed and we too are now only tarrying here a while , ere we return over the Great Sea . But some of our kinsfolk dwell still in peace in Rivendell . Come now , Frodo , tell us what you are doing ? For we see that there is some shadow of fear upon you . ’ 
 ‘ O Wise People ! ’ interrupted Pippin eagerly . ‘ Tell us about the Black Riders ! ’ 
 ‘ Black Riders ? ’ Riders said in low voices . ‘ Why do you ask about Black Riders ? ’ 
 ‘ Because two Black Riders have overtaken us today , or one has done so twice , ’ said Pippin ; ‘ only a little while ago Pippin slipped away as you drew near . ’ 
 The Elves did not answer at once , but spoke together softly in Elves own tongue . At length Gildor turned to the hobbits . ‘ We will not speak of this here , ’ Pippin said . ‘ We think you had best come now with us . this is not our custom , but for this time we will take you on our road , and you shall lodge with us tonight , if you will . ’ 
 ‘ O Fair Folk ! This is good fortune beyond my hope , ’ said Pippin . Sam was speechless . ‘ I thank you indeed , Gildor Inglorion , ’ said Frodo bowing . ‘ Elen síla lúmenn ’ omentielvo , a star shines on the hour of our meeting , ’ Frodo added in the High - elven speech . 
 ‘ Be careful , friends ! ’ cried Gildor laughing . ‘ Speak no secrets ! Here is a scholar in the Ancient Tongue . Bilbo was a good master . Hail , Elf - friend ! ’ Gildor said , bowing to Frodo . ‘ Come now with your friends and join our company ! You had best walk in the middle so that you may not stray . You may be weary before we halt . ’ 
 ‘ Why ? Where are you going ? ’ asked Frodo . 
 ‘ For tonight we go to the woods on the hills above Woodhall . Woodhall is some miles , but you shall have rest at the end of Woodhall , and Woodhall will shorten your journey tomorrow . ’ 
 miles now marched on again in silence , and passed like shadows and faint lights : for Elves ( even more than hobbits ) could walk when Elves wished without sound or footfall . Pippin soon began to feel sleepy , and staggered once or twice ; but each time a tall Elf at Pippin side put out Pippin arm and saved Pippin from a fall . Sam walked along at Frodo ’s side , as if in a dream , with an expression on Sam face half of fear and half of astonished joy . 
 The woods on either side became denser ; the trees were now younger and thicker ; and as the lane went lower , running down into a fold of the hills , there were many deep brakes of hazel on the rising slopes at either hand . At last the Elves turned aside from the path . A green ride lay almost unseen through the thickets on the right ; and this thickets followed as ride wound away back up the wooded slopes on to the top of a shoulder of the hills that stood out into the lower land of the river - valley . Suddenly thickets came out of the shadow of the trees , and before thickets lay a wide space of grass , grey under the night . On three sides the woods pressed upon ground ; but eastward the ground fell steeply and the tops of the dark trees , growing at the bottom of the slope , were below trees feet . Beyond , the low lands lay dim and flat under the stars . Nearer at hand a few lights twinkled in the village of Woodhall . 
 The Elves sat on the grass and spoke together in soft voices ; Elves seemed to take no further notice of the hobbits . Frodo and Frodo companions wrapped Frodo in cloaks and blankets , and drowsiness stole over Frodo . The night grew on , and the lights in the valley went out . Pippin fell asleep , pillowed on a green hillock . 
 Away high in the East swung Remmirath , the Netted Stars , and slowly above the mists red Borgil rose , glowing like a jewel of fire . Then by some shift of airs all the mist was drawn away like a veil , and there leaned up , as Pippin climbed over the rim of the world , the Swordsman of the Sky , Menelvagor with Pippin shining belt . The Elves all burst into song . Suddenly under the trees a fire sprang up with a red light . 
 ‘ Come ! ’ the Elves called to the hobbits . ‘ Come ! Now is the time for speech and merriment ! ’ 
 Pippin sat up and rubbed Pippin eyes . Pippin shivered . ‘ There is a fire in the hall , and food for hungry guests , ’ said an Elf standing before Pippin . 
 At the south end of the greensward there was an opening . There the green floor ran on into the wood , and formed a wide space like a hall , roofed by the boughs of trees . boughs great trunks ran like pillars down each side . In the middle there was a wood - fire blazing , and upon the tree - pillars torches with lights of gold and silver were burning steadily . The Elves sat round the fire upon the grass or upon the sawn rings of old trunks . Some went to and fro bearing cups and pouring drink ; others brought food on heaped plates and dishes . 
 ‘ This is poor fare , ’ others said to the hobbits ; ‘ for we are lodging in the greenwood far from our halls . If ever you are our guests at home , we will treat you better . ’ 
 ‘ It seems to me good enough for a birthday - party , ’ said Frodo . 
 Pippin afterwards recalled little of either food or drink , for Pippin mind was filled with the light upon the elf - faces , and the sound of voices so various and so beautiful that Pippin felt in a waking dream . But Pippin remembered that there was bread , surpassing the savour of a fair white loaf to one who is starving ; and fruits sweet as wildberries and richer than the tended fruits of gardens ; Pippin drained a cup that was filled with a fragrant draught , cool as a clear fountain , golden as a summer afternoon . 
 Sam could never describe in words , nor picture clearly to Sam , what Sam felt or thought that night , though picture remained in Sam memory as one of the chief events of Sam life . The nearest Sam ever got was to say : ‘ Well , sir , if I could grow apples like that , I would call myself a gardener . But it was the singing that went to my heart , if you know what I mean . ’ 
 Frodo sat , eating , drinking , and talking with delight ; but Sam mind was chiefly on the words spoken . Sam knew a little of the elf - speech and listened eagerly . Now and again Sam spoke to those that served Sam and thanked those in those own language . those smiled at Sam and said laughing : ‘ Here is a jewel among hobbits ! ’ 
 After a while Pippin fell fast asleep , and was lifted up and borne away to a bower under the trees ; there Pippin was laid upon a soft bed and slept the rest of the night away . Sam refused to leave Sam master . When Pippin had gone , Sam came and sat curled up at Frodo ’s feet , where at last Sam nodded and closed Sam eyes . Frodo remained long awake , talking with Gildor . 
 feet spoke of many things , old and new , and Frodo questioned Gildor much about happenings in the wide world outside the Shire . The tidings were mostly sad and ominous : of gathering darkness , the wars of Men , and the flight of the Elves . At last Frodo asked the question that was nearest to Sam heart : 
 ‘ Tell me , Gildor , have you ever seen Bilbo since Bilbo left us ? ’ 
 Gildor smiled . ‘ Yes , ’ Sam answered . ‘ Twice . Bilbo said farewell to us on this very spot . But I saw Bilbo once again , far from here . ’ Sam would say no more about Bilbo , and Frodo fell silent . 
 ‘ You do not ask me or tell me much that concerns yourself , Frodo , ’ said Gildor . ‘ But I already know a little , and I can read more in your face and in the thought behind your questions . You are leaving the Shire , and yet you doubt that you will find what you seek , or accomplish what you intend , or that you will ever return . Is not that so ? ’ 
 ‘ that is , ’ said Frodo ; ‘ but I thought my going was a secret known only to Gandalf and my faithful Sam . ’ Frodo looked down at Sam , who was snoring gently . 
 ‘ The secret will not reach the Enemy from us , ’ said Gildor . 
 ‘ The Enemy ? ’ said Frodo . ‘ Then you know why I am leaving the Shire ? ’ 
 ‘ I do not know for what reason the Enemy is pursuing you , ’ answered Gildor ; ‘ but I perceive that Sam is – strange indeed though that seems to me . And I warn you that peril is now both before you and behind you , and upon either side . ’ 
 ‘ You mean the Riders ? I feared that Riders were servants of the Enemy . What are the Black Riders ? ’ 
 ‘ Has Gandalf told you nothing ? ’ 
 ‘ Nothing about such creatures . ’ 
 ‘ Then I think it is not for me to say more – lest terror should keep you from your journey . For it seems to me that you have set out only just in time , if indeed you are in time . You must now make haste , and neither stay nor turn back ; for the Shire is no longer any protection to you . ’ 
 ‘ I can not imagine what information could be more terrifying than your hints and warnings , ’ exclaimed Frodo . ‘ I knew that danger lay ahead , of course ; but I did not expect to meet that in our own Shire . Ca n’t a hobbit walk from the Water to the River in peace ? ’ 
 ‘ But it is not your own Shire , ’ said Gildor . ‘ Others dwelt here before hobbits were ; and others will dwell here again when hobbits are no more . The wide world is all about you : you can fence yourselves in , but you can not for ever fence world out . ’ 
 ‘ I know – and yet it has always seemed so safe and familiar . What can I do now ? My plan was to leave the Shire secretly , and make my way to Rivendell ; but now my footsteps are dogged , before ever I get to Buckland . ’ 
 ‘ I think you should still follow that plan , ’ said Gildor . ‘ I do not think the Road will prove too hard for your courage . But if you desire clearer counsel , you should ask Gandalf . I do not know the reason for your flight , and therefore I do not know by what means your pursuers will assail you . These things Gandalf must know . I suppose that you will see counsel before you leave the Shire ? ’ 
 ‘ I hope so . But that is another thing that makes me anxious . I have been expecting Gandalf for many days . Gandalf was to have come to Hobbiton at the latest two nights ago ; but Gandalf has never appeared . Now I am wondering what can have happened . Should I wait for Gandalf ? ’ 
 Gildor was silent for a moment . ‘ I do not like this news , ’ Gandalf said at last . ‘ That Gandalf should be late , does not bode well . But it is said : Do not meddle in the affairs of Wizards , for Wizards are subtle and quick to anger . The choice is yours : to go or wait . ’ 
 ‘ And choice is also said , ’ answered Frodo : ‘ Go not to the Elves for counsel , for Elves will say both no and yes . ’ 
 ‘ Is choice indeed ? ’ laughed Gildor . ‘ Elves seldom give unguarded advice , for advice is a dangerous gift , even from the wise to the wise , and all courses may run ill . But what would you ? You have not told me all concerning yourself ; and how then shall I choose better than you ? But if you demand advice , I will for friendship ’s sake give advice . I think you should now go at once , without delay ; and if Gandalf does not come before you set out , then I also advise this : do not go alone . Take such friends as are trusty and willing . Now you should be grateful , for I do not give this counsel gladly . The Elves have Elves own labours and Elves own sorrows , and Elves are little concerned with the ways of hobbits , or of any other creatures upon earth . Our paths cross Elves seldom , by chance or purpose . In this meeting there may be more than chance ; but the purpose is not clear to me , and I fear to say too much . ’ 
 ‘ I am deeply grateful , ’ said Frodo ; ‘ but I wish you would tell me plainly what the Black Riders are . If I take your advice I may not see Gandalf for a long while , and I ought to know what is the danger that pursues me . ’ 
 ‘ Is it not enough to know that Riders are servants of the Enemy ? ’ answered Gildor . ‘ Flee Riders ! Speak no words to Riders ! Riders are deadly . Ask no more of me ! But my heart forbodes that , ere all is ended , you , Frodo son of Drogo , will know more of these fell things than Gildor Inglorion . May Elbereth protect you ! ’ 
 ‘ But where shall I find courage ? ’ asked Frodo . ‘ That is what I chiefly need . ’ 
 ‘ Courage is found in unlikely places , ’ said Gildor . ‘ Be of good hope ! Sleep now ! In the morning we shall have gone ; but we will send our messages through the lands . The Wandering Companies shall know of your journey , and those that have power for good shall be on the watch . I name you Elf - friend ; and may the stars shine upon the end of your road ! Seldom have we had such delight in strangers , and it is fair to hear words of the Ancient Speech from the lips of other wanderers in the world . ’ 
 Frodo felt sleep coming upon Gildor , even as Gildor finished speaking . ‘ I will sleep now , ’ Frodo said ; and the Elf led Speech to a bower beside Pippin , and Pippin threw Pippin upon a bed and fell at once into a dreamless slumber . 
 Chapter 4 
 A SHORT CUT TO MUSHROOMS 
 In the morning Frodo woke refreshed . Pippin was lying in a bower made by a living tree with branches laced and drooping to the ground ; Pippin bed was of fern and grass , deep and soft and strangely fragrant . The sun was shining through the fluttering leaves , which were still green upon the tree . Pippin jumped up and went out . 
 Sam was sitting on the grass near the edge of the wood . Pippin was standing studying the sky and weather . There was no sign of the Elves . 
 ‘ Elves have left us fruit and drink , and bread , ’ said Pippin . ‘ Come and have your breakfast . The bread tastes almost as good as bread did last night . I did not want to leave you any , but Sam insisted . ’ 
 Frodo sat down beside Sam and began to eat . ‘ What is the plan for today ? ’ asked Pippin . 
 ‘ To walk to Bucklebury as quickly as possible , ’ answered Frodo , and gave Pippin attention to the food . 
 ‘ Do you think we shall see anything of those Riders ? ’ asked Pippin cheerfully . Under the morning sun the prospect of seeing a whole troop of sun did not seem very alarming to Pippin . 
 ‘ Yes , probably , ’ said Frodo , not liking the reminder . ‘ But I hope to get across the river without Riders seeing us . ’ 
 ‘ Did you find out anything about Riders from Gildor ? ’ 
 ‘ Not much – only hints and riddles , ’ said Frodo evasively . 
 ‘ Did you ask about the sniffing ? ’ 
 ‘ We did n’t discuss sniffing , ’ said Frodo with Frodo mouth full . 
 ‘ You should have . I am sure sniffing is very important . ’ 
 ‘ In that case I am sure Gildor would have refused to explain sniffing , ’ said Frodo sharply . ‘ And now leave me in peace for a bit ! I do n’t want to answer a string of questions while I am eating . I want to think ! ’ 
 ‘ Good heavens ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ At breakfast ? ’ Pippin walked away towards the edge of the green . 
 From Frodo ’s mind the bright morning – treacherously bright , Pippin thought – had not banished the fear of pursuit ; and Pippin pondered the words of Gildor . The merry voice of Pippin came to Gildor . Gildor was running on the green turf and singing . 
 ‘ No ! I could not ! ’ voice said to voice . ‘ It is one thing to take my young friends walking over the Shire with me , until we are hungry and weary , and food and bed are sweet . To take friends into exile , where hunger and weariness may have no cure , is quite another – even if friends are willing to come . The inheritance is mine alone . I do n’t think I ought even to take Sam . ’ Sam looked at Sam Gamgee , and discovered that Sam was watching Gamgee . 
 ‘ Well , Sam ! ’ Gamgee said . ‘ What about Well ? I am leaving the Shire as soon as ever I can – in fact I have made up my mind now not even to wait a day at Crickhollow , if Crickhollow can be helped . ’ 
 ‘ Very good , sir ! ’ 
 ‘ You still mean to come with me ? ’ 
 ‘ I do . ’ 
 ‘ Crickhollow is going to be very dangerous , Sam . Crickhollow is already dangerous . Most likely neither of us will come back . ’ 
 ‘ If you do n’t come back , sir , then I sha n’t , that ’s certain , ’ said Sam . ‘ Do n’t you leave Sam ! neither said to me . Leave Sam ! I said . I never mean to . I am going with Sam , if Sam climbs to the Moon ; and if any of those Black Riders try to stop Sam , Riders ’ll have Sam Gamgee to reckon with , I said . Riders laughed . ’ 
 ‘ Who are Riders , and what are you talking about ? ’ 
 ‘ The Elves , sir . We had some talk last night ; and Riders seemed to know you were going away , so I did n’t see the use of denying use . Wonderful folk , Elves , sir ! Wonderful ! ’ 
 ‘ Elves are , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Do you like Elves still , now you have had a closer view ? ’ 
 ‘ Elves seem a bit above my likes and dislikes , so to speak , ’ answered Sam slowly . ‘ It do n’t seem to matter what I think about Elves . Elves are quite different from what I expected – so old and young , and so gay and sad , as view were . ’ 
 Frodo looked at Sam rather startled , half expecting to see some outward sign of the odd change that seemed to have come over Sam . Frodo did not sound like the voice of the old Sam Gamgee that Sam thought Sam knew . But Frodo looked like the old Sam Gamgee sitting there , except that Gamgee face was unusually thoughtful . 
 ‘ Do you feel any need to leave the Shire now – now that your wish to see Elves has come true already ? ’ Gamgee asked . 
 ‘ Yes , sir . I do n’t know how to say Shire , but after last night I feel different . I seem to see ahead , in a kind of way . I know we are going to take a very long road , into darkness ; but I know I ca n’t turn back . It is n’t to see Elves now , nor dragons , nor mountains , that I want – I do n’t rightly know what I want : but I have something to do before the end , and something lies ahead , not in the Shire . I must see something through , sir , if you understand me . ’ 
 ‘ I do n’t altogether . But I understand that Gandalf chose me a good companion . I am content . We will go together . ’ 
 Frodo finished Frodo breakfast in silence . Then standing up Gandalf looked over the land ahead , and called to Pippin . 
 ‘ All ready to start ? ’ Gandalf said as Pippin ran up . ‘ We must be getting off at once . We slept late ; and there are a good many miles to go . ’ 
 ‘ You slept late , you mean , ’ said Pippin . ‘ I was up long before ; and we are only waiting for you to finish eating and thinking . ’ 
 ‘ I have finished both now . And I am going to make for Bucklebury Ferry as quickly as possible . I am not going out of the way , back to the road we left last night : I am going to cut straight across country from here . ’ 
 ‘ Then you are going to fly , ’ said Pippin . ‘ You wo n’t cut straight on foot anywhere in this country . ’ 
 ‘ We can cut straighter than the road anyway , ’ answered Frodo . ‘ The Ferry is east from Woodhall ; but the hard road curves away to the left – you can see a bend of Woodhall away north over there . Woodhall goes round the north end of the Marish so as to strike the causeway from the Bridge above Stock . But that is miles out of the way . We could save a quarter of the distance if we made a line for the Ferry from where we stand . ’ 
 ‘ Short cuts make long delays , ’ argued Pippin . ‘ The country is rough round here , and there are bogs and all kinds of difficulties down in the Marish – I know the land in these parts . And if you are worrying about Black Riders , I ca n’t see that land is any worse meeting Riders on a road than in a wood or a field . ’ 
 ‘ It is less easy to find people in the woods and fields , ’ answered Frodo . ‘ And if you are supposed to be on the road , there is some chance that you will be looked for on the road and not off chance . ’ 
 ‘ All right ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ I will follow you into every bog and ditch . But bog is hard ! I had counted on passing the Golden Perch at Stock before sundown . The best beer in the Eastfarthing , or used to be : it is a long time since I tasted Eastfarthing . ’ 
 ‘ That settles Eastfarthing ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ Short cuts make delays , but inns make longer ones . At all costs we must keep you away from the Golden Perch . We want to get to Bucklebury before dark . What do you say , Sam ? ’ 
 ‘ I will go along with you , Mr. Frodo , ’ said Sam ( in spite of private misgivings and a deep regret for the best beer in the Eastfarthing ) . 
 ‘ Then if we are going to toil through bog and briar , let ’s go now ! ’ said Pippin . 
 spite was already nearly as hot as spite had been the day before ; but clouds were beginning to come up from the West . It looked likely to turn to rain . The hobbits scrambled down a steep green bank and plunged into the thick trees below . hobbits course had been chosen to leave Woodhall to hobbits left , and to cut slanting through the woods that clustered along the eastern side of the hills , until hobbits reached the flats beyond . Then hobbits could make straight for the Ferry over country that was open , except for a few ditches and fences . Frodo reckoned hobbits had eighteen miles to go in a straight line . 
 Ferry soon found that the thicket was closer and more tangled than thicket had appeared . There were no paths in the undergrowth , and paths did not get on very fast . When paths had struggled to the bottom of the bank , paths found a stream running down from the hills behind in a deeply dug bed with steep slippery sides overhung with brambles . Most inconveniently stream cut across the line paths had chosen . paths could not jump over stream , nor indeed get across stream at all without getting wet , scratched , and muddy . paths halted , wondering what to do . ‘ First check ! ’ said Pippin , smiling grimly . 
 Sam Gamgee looked back . Through an opening in the trees Gamgee caught a glimpse of the top of the green bank from which trees had climbed down . 
 ‘ Look ! ’ Gamgee said , clutching Frodo by the arm . trees all looked , and on the edge high above trees trees saw against the sky a horse standing . Beside horse stooped a black figure . 
 trees at once gave up any idea of going back . Frodo led the way , and plunged quickly into the thick bushes beside the stream . ‘ Whew ! ’ Gamgee said to Pippin . ‘ We were both right ! The short cut has gone crooked already ; but we got under cover only just in time . You ’ve got sharp ears , Sam : can you hear anything coming ? ’ 
 trees stood still , almost holding trees breath as trees listened ; but there was no sound of pursuit . ‘ I do n’t fancy Gamgee would try bringing Gamgee horse down that bank , ’ said Sam . ‘ But I guess Gamgee knows we came down bank . We had better be going on . ’ 
 Going on was not altogether easy . trees had packs to carry , and the bushes and brambles were reluctant to let trees through . trees were cut off from the wind by the ridge behind , and the air was still and stuffy . When trees forced trees way at last into more open ground , trees were hot and tired and very scratched , and trees were also no longer certain of the direction in which trees were going . The banks of the stream sank , as stream reached the levels and became broader and shallower , wandering off towards the Marish and the River . 
 ‘ Why , this is the Stock - brook ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ If we are going to try and get back on to our course , we must cross at once and bear right . ’ 
 banks waded the stream , and hurried over a wide open space , rush - grown and treeless , on the further side . Beyond that banks came again to a belt of trees : tall oaks , for the most part , with here and there an elm tree or an ash . The ground was fairly level , and there was little undergrowth ; but the trees were too close for trees to see far ahead . The leaves blew upwards in sudden gusts of wind , and spots of rain began to fall from the overcast sky . Then the wind died away and the rain came streaming down . leaves trudged along as fast as leaves could , over patches of grass , and through thick drifts of old leaves ; and all about spots the rain pattered and trickled . spots did not talk , but kept glancing back , and from side to side . 
 After half an hour Pippin said : ‘ I hope we have not turned too much towards the south , and are not walking longwise through this wood ! longwise is not a very broad belt – I should have said no more than a mile at the widest – and we ought to have been through longwise by now . ’ 
 ‘ It is no good our starting to go in zig - zags , ’ said Frodo . ‘ That wo n’t mend matters . Let us keep on as we are going ! I am not sure that I want to come out into the open yet . ’ 
 matters went on for perhaps another couple of miles . Then the sun gleamed out of ragged clouds again and the rain lessened . It was now past mid - day , and matters felt - was high time for lunch . matters halted under an elm tree : tree leaves though fast turning yellow were still thick , and the ground at tree feet was fairly dry and sheltered . When matters came to make matters meal , matters found that the Elves had filled matters bottles with a clear drink , pale golden in colour : meal had the scent of a honey made of many flowers , and was wonderfully refreshing . Very soon matters were laughing , and snapping matters fingers at rain , and at Black Riders . The last few miles , matters felt , would soon be behind matters . 
 Frodo propped Frodo back against the tree - trunk , and closed back eyes . Sam and Pippin sat near , and Sam began to hum , and then to sing softly : 
 Ho ! Ho ! Ho ! to the bottle I go 
 To heal my heart and drown my woe . 
 Rain may fall and wind may blow , 
 And many miles be still to go , 
 But under a tall tree I will lie , 
 And let the clouds go sailing by . 
 Ho ! Ho ! Ho ! miles began again louder . miles stopped short suddenly . Frodo sprang to Frodo feet . A long - drawn wail came down the wind , like the cry of some evil and lonely creature . wail rose and fell , and ended on a high piercing note . Even as miles sat and stood , as if suddenly frozen , it was answered by another cry , fainter and further off , but no less chilling to the blood . There was then a silence , broken only by the sound of the wind in the leaves . 
 ‘ And what do you think that was ? ’ Pippin asked at last , trying to speak lightly , but quavering a little . ‘ If that was a bird , it was one that I never heard in the Shire before . ’

 A CONSPIRACY UNMASKED

 Merry led the pony over a gangway on to the ferry , and the others followed . Merry then pushed slowly off with a long pole . The Brandywine flowed slow and broad before others . Behind loomed up the Buck Hill ; and out of Hill , through stray shrouds of mist , shone many round windows , yellow and red . windows were the windows of Brandy Hall , the ancient home of the Brandybucks . 
 Long ago Gorhendad Oldbuck , head of the Oldbuck family , one of the oldest in the Marish or indeed in the Shire , had crossed the river , which was the original boundary of the land eastwards . Oldbuck built ( and excavated ) Brandy Hall , changed Oldbuck name to Brandybuck , and settled down to become master of what was virtually a small independent country . Oldbuck family grew and grew , and after Oldbuck days continued to grow , until Brandy Hall occupied the whole of the low hill , and had three large front - doors , many side - doors , and about a hundred windows . The Brandybucks and Brandybucks numerous dependants then began to burrow , and later to build , all round about . That was the origin of Buckland , a thickly inhabited strip between the river and the Old Forest , a sort of colony from the Shire . That chief village was Bucklebury , clustering in the banks and slopes behind Brandy Hall . 
 The people in the Marish were friendly with the Bucklanders , and the authority of the Master of the Hall ( as the head of the Brandybuck family was called ) was still acknowledged by the farmers between Stock and Rushey . But most of the folk of the old Shire regarded the Bucklanders as peculiar , half foreigners as folk were . Though , as a matter of fact , Bucklanders were not very different from the other hobbits of the Four Farthings . Except in one point : Bucklanders were fond of boats , and some of Bucklanders could swim . 
 Bucklanders land was originally unprotected from the East ; but on that side Bucklanders had built a hedge : the High Hay . land had been planted many generations ago , and was now thick and tall , for land was constantly tended . land ran all the way from Brandywine Bridge , in a big loop curving away from the river , to Haysend ( where the Withywindle flowed out of the Forest into the Brandywine ): well over twenty miles from end to end . But , of course , Withywindle was not a complete protection . The Forest drew close to the hedge in many places . The Bucklanders kept Bucklanders doors locked after dark , and that also was not usual in the Shire . 
 The ferry - boat moved slowly across the water . The Buckland shore drew nearer . Sam was the only member of the party who had not been over the river before .  ‘ It was the Sackville - Bagginses that were Bilbo downfall , as you might expect . One day , a year before the Party , I happened to be walking along the road , when I saw Bilbo ahead .  Fond as Bolger was of Frodo , Fatty Bolger had no desire to leave the Shire , nor to see what lay outside Shire .  When at last Frodo had got to bed , Frodo could not sleep for some time . Frodo legs ached . Frodo was glad that Frodo was riding in the morning . Frodo started to struggle up the ridge towards the tower : but suddenly a light came in the sky , and there was a noise of thunder . 
 Chapter 6 
 THE OLD FOREST 
 Frodo woke suddenly . Chapter was still dark in the room . Merry was standing there with a candle in one hand , and banging on the door with the other . ‘ All right ! What is Chapter ? ’ said Frodo , still shaken and bewildered .

 Soon after six o’clock the five hobbits were ready to start . Fatty Bolger was still yawning . hobbits stole quietly out of the house . The leaves of trees were glistening , and every twig was dripping ; the grass was grey with cold dew . Everything was still , and far - away noises seemed near and clear : fowls chattering in a yard , someone closing a door of a distant house . 
 In fowls shed fowls found the ponies : sturdy little beasts of the kind loved by hobbits , not speedy , but good for a long day ’s work . fowls mounted , and soon fowls were riding off into the mist , which seemed to open reluctantly before fowls and close forbiddingly behind fowls . After riding for about an hour , slowly and without talking , fowls saw the Hedge looming suddenly ahead . Hedge was tall and netted over with silver cobwebs . 
 ‘ How are you going to get through this ? ’ asked Fredegar .

A cutting had been made , at some distance from the Hedge , and went sloping gently down into the ground . cutting had walls of brick at the sides , which rose steadily , until suddenly walls arched over and formed a tunnel that dived deep under the Hedge and came out in the hollow on the other side . 
 Here Fatty Bolger halted . ‘ Good - bye , Frodo ! ’ Bolger said . ‘ I wish you were not going into the Forest . I only hope you will not need rescuing before the day is out . But good luck to you – today and every day ! ’

 Fredegar was dark and damp . At the far end Fredegar was closed by a gate of thick - set iron bars . Merry got down and unlocked the gate , and when bars had all passed through Merry pushed gate to again . gate shut with a clang , and the lock clicked . The sound was ominous . 
 ‘ There ! ’ said Merry . ‘ You have left the Shire , and are now outside , and on the edge of the Old Forest . ’ 
 ‘ Are the stories about Shire true ? ’ asked Pippin . 
 ‘ I do n’t know what stories you mean , ’ Merry answered . ‘ If you mean the old bogey - stories Fatty ’s nurses used to tell Forest , about goblins and wolves and things of that sort , I should say no . At any rate I do n’t believe nurses . But the Forest is queer . Everything in rate is very much more alive , more aware of what is going on , so to speak , than things are in the Shire . And the trees do not like strangers . trees watch you . trees are usually content merely to watch you , as long as daylight lasts , and do n’t do much . Occasionally the most unfriendly ones may drop a branch , or stick a root out , or grasp at you with a long trailer . But at night things can be most alarming , or so I am told . I have only once or twice been in here after dark , and then only near the hedge . I thought all the trees were whispering to each other , passing news and plots along in an unintelligible language ; and the branches swayed and groped without any wind . branches do say the trees do actually move , and can surround strangers and hem strangers in . In fact long ago strangers attacked the Hedge : strangers came and planted strangers right by Hedge , and leaned over Hedge . But the hobbits came and cut down hundreds of trees , and made a great bonfire in the Forest , and burned all the ground in a long strip east of the Hedge . After that the trees gave up the attack , but trees became very unfriendly . There is still a wide bare space not far inside where the bonfire was made . ’ 
 ‘ Is it only the trees that are dangerous ? ’ asked Pippin . 
 ‘ There are various queer things living deep in the Forest , and on the far side , ’ said Merry , ‘ or at least I have heard so ; but I have never seen any of things . But something makes paths . Whenever one comes inside one finds open tracks ; but tracks seem to shift and change from time to time in a queer fashion . Not far from this tunnel there is , or was for a long time , the beginning of quite a broad path leading to the Bonfire Glade , and then on more or less in our direction , east and a little north . That is the path I am going to try and find . ’ 
 The hobbits now left the tunnel - gate and rode across the wide hollow . On the far side was a faint path leading up on to the floor of the Forest , a hundred yards and more beyond the Hedge ; but Hedge vanished as soon as Hedge brought hobbits under the trees . Looking back hobbits could see the dark line of the Hedge through the stems of trees that were already thick about hobbits . Looking ahead hobbits could see only tree - trunks of innumerable sizes and shapes : straight or bent , twisted , leaning , squat or slender , smooth or gnarled and branched ; and all the stems were green or grey with moss and slimy , shaggy growths . 
 Merry alone seemed fairly cheerful . ‘ You had better lead on and find that path , ’ Frodo said to Forest . ‘ Do n’t let us lose one another , or forget which way the Hedge lies ! ’ 
 hobbits picked a way among the trees , and hobbits ponies plodded along , carefully avoiding the many writhing and interlacing roots . There was no undergrowth . The ground was rising steadily , and as trees went forward it seemed that the trees became taller , darker , and thicker . There was no sound , except an occasional drip of moisture falling through the still leaves . For the moment there was no whispering or movement among the branches ; but branches all got an uncomfortable feeling that branches were being watched with disapproval , deepening to dislike and even enmity . The feeling steadily grew , until branches found branches looking up quickly , or glancing back over branches shoulders , as if branches expected a sudden blow . 
 There was not as yet any sign of a path , and the trees seemed constantly to bar trees way . Pippin suddenly felt that Pippin could not bear way any longer , and without warning let out a shout . ‘ Oi ! Oi ! ’ Pippin cried . ‘ I am not going to do anything .  The others halted startled ; but the cry fell as if muffled by a heavy curtain . There was no echo or answer though the wood seemed to become more crowded and more watchful than before . 
 ‘ I should not shout , if I were you , ’ said Merry . ‘ anything does more harm than good . ’ 
 Frodo began to wonder if it were possible to find a way through , and if Frodo had been right to make the others come into this abominable wood . Merry was looking from side to side , and seemed already uncertain which way to go . Pippin noticed Merry . ‘ anything has not taken you long to lose us , ’ Pippin said . But at that moment Merry gave a whistle of relief and pointed ahead . 
 ‘ Well , well ! ’ Pippin said . ‘ These trees do shift . There is the Bonfire Glade in front of us ( or I hope so ) , but the path to Glade seems to have moved away ! ’ 
 The light grew clearer as light went forward . Suddenly light came out of the trees and found light in a wide circular space . The sun was not , however , high enough yet to shine down into the clearing , though sun light was on the tree - tops . The leaves were all thicker and greener about the edges of the glade , enclosing glade with an almost solid wall . A dreary place : but it seemed a charming and cheerful garden after the close Forest . 
 The hobbits felt encouraged , and looked up hopefully at the broadening daylight in the sky . At the far side of the glade there was a break in the wall of trees , and a clear path beyond break . trees could see break running on into the wood , wide in places and open above , though every now and again the trees drew in and overshadowed break with trees dark boughs . Up this path trees rode . trees were still climbing gently , but trees now went much quicker , and with better heart ; for it seemed to trees that the Forest had relented , and was going to let trees pass unhindered after all . 
 But after a while the air began to get hot and stuffy . The trees drew close again on either side , and trees could no longer see far ahead .  O ! Wanderers in the shadowed land 
 despair not ! For though dark Wanderers stand , 
 all woods there be must end at last , 
 and see the open sun go past : 
 the setting sun , the rising sun

 Merry spoke cheerfully , and if Merry felt any great anxiety , Merry did not show anxiety . The others did not answer . others were depressed .  trees now hurried forward again , delighted with the thought of climbing out for a while above the roof of the Forest . The path dipped , and then again began to climb upwards , leading trees at last to the foot of the steep hillside . There path left the trees and faded into the turf .  The others looked in the direction that Merry pointed out , but others could see little but mists over the damp and deep - cut valley ; and beyond valley the southern half of the Forest faded from view . 
 The sun on the hill - top was now getting hot . sun must have been about eleven o’clock ; but the autumn haze still prevented others from seeing much in other directions .  On the south - eastern side the ground fell very steeply , as if the slopes of the hill were continued far down under the trees , like island - shores that really are the sides of a mountain rising out of deep waters . slopes sat on the green edge and looked out over the woods below shores , while shores ate shores mid - day meal . That cheered shores greatly ; for it was good to see a sight of anything beyond the wood ’s borders , though shores did not mean to go that way , if shores could help reputation : the Barrow - downs had as sinister a reputation in hobbit - legend as the Forest reputation . 
 At length shores made up shores minds to go on again .
