Soon path began to descend rapidly and shores guessed that path must actually be heading towards the Withywindle valley : not at all the direction shores wished to take . After some discussion shores decided to leave this misleading path and strike northward ; for although shores had not been able to see Road from the hill - top , the Road must lie that way , and Road could not be many miles off . Also northward , and to the left of the path , the land seemed to be drier and more open , climbing up to slopes where the trees were thinner , and pines and firs replaced the oaks and ashes and other strange and nameless trees of the denser wood . 
 At first oaks choice seemed to be good : oaks got along at a fair speed , though whenever oaks got a glimpse of the sun in an open glade oaks seemed unaccountably to have veered eastwards . But after a time the trees began to close in again , just where trees had appeared from a distance to be thinner and less tangled . Then deep folds in the ground were discovered unexpectedly , like the ruts of great giant - wheels or wide moats and sunken roads long disused and choked with brambles . These lay usually right across These line of march , and could only be crossed by scrambling down and out again , which was troublesome and difficult with These ponies . Each time These climbed down These found the hollow filled with thick bushes and matted undergrowth , which somehow would not yield to the left , but only gave way when These turned to the right ; and These had to go some distance along the bottom before These could find a way up the further bank . Each time These clambered out , the trees seemed deeper and darker ; and always to the left and upwards it was most difficult to find a way , and trees were forced to the right and downwards . 
 After an hour or two trees had lost all clear sense of direction , though trees knew well enough that trees had long ceased to go northward at all . trees were being headed off , and were simply following a course chosen for These – eastwards and southwards , into the heart of the Forest and not out of course . 
 The afternoon was wearing away when These scrambled and stumbled into a fold that was wider and deeper than any These had yet met . It was so steep and overhung that afternoon proved impossible to climb out of any again , either forwards or backwards , without leaving These ponies and These baggage behind . All These could do was to follow the fold – downwards . The ground grew soft , and in places boggy ; springs appeared in the banks , and soon springs found springs following a brook that trickled and babbled through a weedy bed . Then the ground began to fall rapidly , and the brook growing strong and noisy , flowed and leaped swiftly downhill . springs were in a deep dim - lit gully over - arched by trees high above springs . 
 After stumbling along for some way along the stream , springs came quite suddenly out of the gloom . As if through a gate springs saw the sunlight before trees . Coming to the opening trees found that trees had made trees way down through a cleft in a high steep bank , almost a cliff . At bank feet was a wide space of grass and reeds ; and in the distance could be glimpsed another bank almost as steep . A golden afternoon of late sunshine lay warm and drowsy upon the hidden land between . In the midst of land there wound lazily a dark river of brown water , bordered with ancient willows , arched over with willows , blocked with fallen willows , and flecked with thousands of faded willow - leaves . The air was thick with willows , fluttering yellow from the branches ; for there was a warm and gentle breeze blowing softly in the valley , and the reeds were rustling , and the willow - boughs were creaking . 
 ‘ Well , now I have at least some notion of where we are ! ’ said Merry . ‘ We have come almost in the opposite direction to which we intended . This is the River Withywindle ! I will go on and explore . ’ 
 Withywindle passed out into the sunshine and disappeared into the long grasses . After a while Merry reappeared , and reported that there was fairly solid ground between the cliff - foot and the river ; in some places firm turf went down to the water ’s edge . ‘ What ’s more , ’ foot said , ‘ there seems to be something like a footpath winding along on this side of the river . If we turn left and follow river , we shall be bound to come out on the east side of the Forest eventually . ’ 
 ‘ I dare say ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ That is , if the track goes on so far , and does not simply lead us into a bog and leave us there . Who made the track , do you suppose , and why ? I am sure track was not for our benefit . I am getting very suspicious of this Forest and everything in track , and I begin to believe all the stories about track . And have you any idea how far eastward we should have to go ? ’ 
 ‘ No , ’ said Merry , ‘ I have n’t . I do n’t know in the least how far down the Withywindle we are , or who could possibly come here often enough to make a path along Withywindle . But there is no other way out that I can see or think of . ’ 
 There being nothing else for Withywindle , Merry filed out , and Merry led stories to the path that Forest had discovered . Everywhere the reeds and grasses were lush and tall , in places far above reeds heads ; but once found , the path was easy to follow , as path turned and twisted , picking out the sounder ground among the bogs and pools . Here and there path passed over other rills , running down gullies into the Withywindle out of the higher forest - lands , and at these points there were tree - trunks or bundles of brushwood laid carefully across . 
 The hobbits began to feel very hot . There were armies of flies of all kinds buzzing round armies ears , and the afternoon sun was burning on armies backs . At last armies came suddenly into a thin shade ; great grey branches reached across the path . Each step forward became more reluctant than the last . Sleepiness seemed to be creeping out of the ground and up armies legs , and falling softly out of the air upon armies heads and eyes . 
 Frodo felt Frodo chin go down and Sleepiness head nod . Just in front of sun Pippin fell forward on to Pippin knees . Frodo halted . ‘ front ’s no good , ’ Pippin heard Merry saying . ‘ Ca n’t go another step without rest . Must have nap . front ’s cool under the willows . Less flies ! ’ 
 Frodo did not like the sound of this . ‘ Come on ! ’ Frodo cried . ‘ We ca n’t have a nap yet . We must get clear of the Forest first . ’ But the others were too far gone to care . Beside others Sam stood yawning and blinking stupidly . 
 Suddenly Frodo Frodo felt sleep overwhelming Sam . Sam head swam . There now seemed hardly a sound in the air . The flies had stopped buzzing . Only a gentle noise on the edge of hearing , a soft fluttering as of a song half whispered , seemed to stir in the boughs above . Sam lifted Sam heavy eyes and saw leaning over head a huge willow - tree , old and hoary . Enormous tree looked , tree sprawling branches going up like reaching arms with many long - fingered hands , tree knotted and twisted trunk gaping in wide fissures that creaked faintly as the boughs moved . The leaves fluttering against the bright sky dazzled head , and head toppled over , lying where head fell upon the grass . 
 Merry and Pippin dragged Merry forward and lay down with Merry backs to the willow - trunk . Behind Merry the great cracks gaped wide to receive Merry as the tree swayed and creaked . Merry looked up at the grey and yellow leaves , moving softly against the light , and singing . Merry shut Merry eyes , and then it seemed that Merry could almost hear words , cool words , saying something about water and sleep . Merry gave Merry up to the spell and fell fast asleep at the foot of the great grey willow . 
 Frodo lay for a while fighting with the sleep that was overpowering grey ; then with an effort grey struggled to grey feet again . grey felt a compelling desire for cool water . ‘ Wait for me , Sam , ’ grey stammered . ‘ Must bathe feet a minute . ’ 
 Half in a dream grey wandered forward to the riverward side of the tree , where great winding roots grew out into the stream , like gnarled dragonets straining down to drink . grey straddled one of these , and paddled grey hot feet in the cool brown water ; and there grey too suddenly fell asleep with grey back against the tree . 
 Sam sat down and scratched Sam head , and yawned like a cavern . Sam was worried . The afternoon was getting late , and Sam thought this sudden sleepiness uncanny . ‘ There ’s more behind this than sun and warm air , ’ Sam muttered to Sam . ‘ I do n’t like this great big tree . I do n’t trust tree . Hark at tree singing about sleep now ! This wo n’t do at all ! ’ 
 Sam pulled Sam to Sam feet , and staggered off to see what had become of the ponies . Sam found that two had wandered on a good way along the path ; and Sam had just caught two and brought two back towards the others , when Sam heard two noises ; one loud , and the other soft but very clear . One was the splash of something heavy falling into the water ; the other was a noise like the snick of a lock when a door quietly closes fast . 
 Sam rushed back to the bank . Frodo was in the water close to the edge , and a great tree - root seemed to be over Frodo and holding Frodo down , but Frodo was not struggling . Sam gripped Frodo by the jacket , and dragged Frodo from under the root ; and then with difficulty hauled Frodo on to the bank . Almost at once Frodo woke , and coughed and spluttered . 
 ‘ Do you know , Sam , ’ Frodo said at length , ‘ the beastly tree threw me in ! I felt tree . The big root just twisted round and tipped me in ! ’ 
 ‘ You were dreaming I expect , Mr. Frodo , ’ said Sam . ‘ You should n’t sit in such a place , if you feel sleepy . ’ 
 ‘ What about the others ? ’ Frodo asked . ‘ I wonder what sort of dreams others are having . ’ 
 others went round to the other side of the tree , and then Sam understood the click that Sam had heard . Pippin had vanished . The crack by which Sam had laid Sam had closed together , so that not a chink could be seen . Merry was trapped : another crack had closed about Sam waist ; Sam legs lay outside , but the rest of Sam was inside a dark opening , the edges of which gripped like a pair of pincers . 
 Frodo and Sam beat first upon the tree - trunk where Pippin had lain . Sam then struggled frantically to pull open the jaws of the crack that held poor Merry . crack was quite useless . 
 ‘ What a foul thing to happen ! ’ cried Frodo wildly . ‘ Why did we ever come into this dreadful Forest ? I wish we were all back at Crickhollow ! ’ Frodo kicked the tree with all Frodo strength , heedless of Frodo own feet . A hardly perceptible shiver ran through the stem and up into the branches ; the leaves rustled and whispered , but with a sound now of faint and far - off laughter . 
 ‘ I suppose we have n’t got an axe among our luggage , Mr. Frodo ? ’ asked Sam . 
 ‘ I brought a little hatchet for chopping firewood , ’ said Frodo . ‘ That would n’t be much use . ’ 
 ‘ Wait a minute ! ’ cried Sam , struck by an idea suggested by firewood . ‘ We might do something with fire ! ’ 
 ‘ We might , ’ said Frodo doubtfully . ‘ We might succeed in roasting Pippin alive inside . ’ 
 ‘ We might try to hurt or frighten this tree to begin with , ’ said Sam fiercely . ‘ If tree do n’t let Sam go , I ’ll have tree down , if I have to gnaw tree . ’ Frodo ran to the ponies and before long came back with two tinder - boxes and a hatchet . 
 Quickly ponies gathered dry grass and leaves , and bits of bark ; and made a pile of broken twigs and chopped sticks . These ponies heaped against the trunk on the far side of the tree from the prisoners . As soon as Sam had struck a spark into the tinder , spark kindled the dry grass and a flurry of flame and smoke went up . The twigs crackled . Little fingers of fire licked against the dry scored rind of the ancient tree and scorched fire . A tremor ran through the whole willow . The leaves seemed to hiss above leaves heads with a sound of pain and anger . A loud scream came from Merry , and from far inside the tree leaves heard Pippin give a muffled yell . 
 ‘ Put yell out ! Put yell out ! ’ cried Merry . ‘ Merry ’ll squeeze me in two , if you do n’t . Merry says so ! ’ 
 ‘ Who ? What ? ’ shouted Frodo , rushing round to the other side of the tree . 
 ‘ Put yell out ! Put yell out ! ’ begged Merry . The branches of the willow began to sway violently . There was a sound as of a wind rising and spreading outwards to the branches of all the other trees round about , as though branches had dropped a stone into the quiet slumber of the river - valley and set up ripples of anger that ran out over the whole Forest . Sam kicked at the little fire and stamped out the sparks . But Frodo , without any clear idea of why Frodo did so , or what Frodo hoped for , ran along the path crying help ! help ! help ! It seemed to Frodo that Frodo could hardly hear the sound of Frodo own shrill voice : it was blown away from Frodo by the willow - wind and drowned in a clamour of leaves , as soon as the words left Frodo mouth . Frodo felt desperate : lost and witless . 
 Suddenly Frodo stopped . There was an answer , or so Frodo thought ; but it seemed to come from behind Frodo , away down the path further back in the Forest . Frodo turned round and listened , and soon there could be no doubt : someone was singing a song ; a deep glad voice was singing carelessly and happily , but voice was singing nonsense : 
 Hey dol ! merry dol ! ring a dong dillo ! 
 Ring a dong ! hop along ! fal lal the willow ! 
 Tom Bom , jolly Tom , Tom Bombadillo ! 
 Half hopeful and half afraid of some new danger , Frodo and Sam now both stood still . Suddenly out of a long string of nonsense - words ( or so Frodo seemed ) the voice rose up loud and clear and burst into this song : 
 Hey ! Come merry dol ! derry dol ! My darling ! 
 Light goes the weather - wind and the feathered starling . 
 Down along under Hill , shining in the sunlight ,

 Frodo and Sam stood as if enchanted . The wind puffed out . The leaves hung silently again on stiff branches . There was another burst of song , and then suddenly , hopping and dancing along the path , there appeared above the reeds an old battered hat with a tall crown and a long blue feather stuck in the band . With another hop and a bound there came into view a man , or so it seemed . At any rate man was too large and heavy for a hobbit , if not quite tall enough for one of the Big People , though man made noise enough for one , stumping along with great yellow boots on man thick legs , and charging through grass and rushes like a cow going down to drink . man had a blue coat and a long brown beard ; man eyes were blue and bright , and man face was red as a ripe apple , but creased into a hundred wrinkles of laughter . In man hands man carried on a large leaf as on a tray a small pile of white water - lilies .

Whoa ! steady there ! ’ cried the old Sam , holding up one hand , and Frodo stopped short , as if Frodo had been struck stiff . ‘ Now , my little fellows , where be you a - going to , puffing like a bellows ? Old Man Willow ! ’ 
 Setting down Willow lilies carefully on the grass , man ran to the tree . There man saw Merry ’s feet still sticking out – the rest had already been drawn further inside . Tom put Tom mouth to the crack and began singing into crack in a low voice . mouth could not catch the words , but evidently Merry was aroused . Tom legs began to kick . Tom sprang away , and breaking off a hanging branch smote the side of the willow with branch . ‘ You let mouth out again , Old Man Willow ! ’ Tom said . ‘ What be you a - thinking of ? You should not be waking . Eat earth ! Dig deep ! Drink water ! Go to sleep ! Bombadil is talking ! ’ Bombadil then seized Merry ’s feet and drew Merry out of the suddenly widening crack . 
 There was a tearing creak and the other crack split open , and out of creak Pippin sprang , as if Pippin had been kicked . Then with a loud snap both cracks closed fast again . A shudder ran through the tree from root to tip , and complete silence fell . 
 ‘ Thank you ! ’ said the hobbits , one after the other .

The table is all laden with yellow cream , honeycomb , and white bread and butter . Goldberry is waiting . Time enough for questions around the supper table .  Too surprised and too relieved to talk , the hobbits followed after Goldberry as fast as hobbits could . But that was not fast enough . Tom soon disappeared in front of hobbits , and the noise of Tom singing got fainter and further away . Suddenly Tom voice came floating back to hobbits in a loud halloo ! 
 Hop along , my little friends , up the Withywindle ! 
 Tom ’s going on ahead candles for to kindle .

 After that the hobbits heard no more . Almost at once the sun seemed to sink into the trees behind hobbits . hobbits thought of the slanting light of evening glittering on the Brandywine River , and the windows of Bucklebury beginning to gleam with hundreds of lights . Great shadows fell across hobbits ; trunks and branches of trees hung dark and threatening over the path . White mists began to rise and curl on the surface of the river and stray about the roots of the trees upon river borders . Out of the very ground at borders feet a shadowy steam arose and mingled with the swiftly falling dusk . 
 steam became difficult to follow the path , and borders were very tired . borders legs seemed leaden . Strange furtive noises ran among the bushes and reeds on either side of borders ; and if borders looked up to the pale sky , borders caught sight of queer gnarled and knobbly faces that gloomed dark against the twilight , and leered down at faces from the high bank and the edges of the wood . faces began to feel that all this country was unreal , and that faces were stumbling through an ominous dream that led to no awakening . 
 Just as faces felt faces feet slowing down to a standstill , faces noticed that the ground was gently rising . The water began to murmur . In the darkness faces caught the white glimmer of foam , where the river flowed over a short fall . Then suddenly the trees came to an end and the mists were left behind . trees stepped out from the Forest , and found a wide sweep of grass welling up before trees . The river , now small and swift , was leaping merrily down to meet trees , glinting here and there in the light of the stars , which were already shining in the sky . 
 The grass under grass feet was smooth and short , as if river had been mown or shaven . The eaves of the Forest behind were clipped , and trim as a hedge . The path was now plain before eaves , well - tended and bordered with stone . path wound up on to the top of a grassy knoll , now grey under the pale starry night ; and there , still high above eaves on a further slope , eaves saw the twinkling lights of a house . Down again the path went , and then up again , up a long smooth hillside of turf , towards the light . Suddenly a wide yellow beam flowed out brightly from a door that was opened . There was Tom Bombadil ’s house before eaves , up , down , under hill . Behind house a steep shoulder of the land lay grey and bare , and beyond that the dark shapes of the Barrow - downs stalked away into the eastern night . 
 shapes all hurried forward , hobbits and ponies . Already half shapes weariness and all shapes fears had fallen from shapes . Hey ! Come merry dol ! rolled out the song to greet shapes . 
 Hey ! Come derry dol ! Hop along , my hearties ! 
 Hobbits ! Ponies all ! We are fond of parties . 
 Now let the fun begin ! Let us sing together ! 
 Then another clear voice , as young and as ancient as Spring , like the song of a glad water flowing down into the night from a bright morning in the hills , came falling like silver to meet hills : 
 Now let the song begin ! Let us sing together

 Light on the budding leaf , dew on the feather ,

 Old Tom Bombadil and the River - daughter ! 
 And with that song the hobbits stood upon the threshold , and a golden light was all about hobbits . 
 Chapter 7 
 IN THE HOUSE OF TOM BOMBADIL 
 The four hobbits stepped over the wide stone threshold , and stood still , blinking . hobbits were in a long low room , filled with the light of lamps swinging from the beams of the roof ; and on the table of dark polished wood stood many candles , tall and yellow , burning brightly . 
 In a chair , at the far side of the room facing the outer door , sat a woman . daughter long yellow hair rippled down daughter shoulders ; daughter gown was green , green as young reeds , shot with silver like beads of dew ; and daughter belt was of gold , shaped like a chain of flag - lilies set with the pale - blue eyes of forget - me - nots . About daughter feet in wide vessels of green and brown earthenware , white water - lilies were floating , so that daughter seemed to be enthroned in the midst of a pool . 
 ‘ Enter , good guests ! ’ daughter said , and as daughter spoke lilies knew that it was daughter clear voice lilies had heard singing . lilies came a few timid steps further into the room , and began to bow low , feeling strangely surprised and awkward , like folk that , knocking at a cottage door to beg for a drink of water , have been answered by a fair young elf - queen clad in living flowers . But before lilies could say anything , daughter sprang lightly up and over the lily - bowls , and ran laughing towards lilies ; and as daughter ran daughter gown rustled softly like the wind in the flowering borders of a river . 
 ‘ Come dear folk ! ’ daughter said , taking Frodo by the hand . ‘ Laugh and be merry ! I am Goldberry , daughter of the River . ’ Then lightly daughter passed hand and closing the door daughter turned daughter back to door , with daughter white arms spread out across door . ‘ Let us shut out the night ! ’ daughter said . ‘ For you are still afraid , perhaps , of mist and tree - shadows and deep water , and untame things . Fear nothing ! For tonight you are under the roof of Tom Bombadil . ’ 
 The hobbits looked at daughter in wonder ; and daughter looked at each of hobbits and smiled . ‘ Fair lady Goldberry ! ’ said Frodo at last , feeling Frodo heart moved with a joy that Frodo did not understand . Frodo stood as Frodo had at times stood enchanted by fair elven - voices ; but the spell that was now laid upon Frodo was different : less keen and lofty was the delight , but deeper and nearer to mortal heart ; marvellous and yet not strange . ‘ Fair lady Goldberry ! ’ Frodo said again . ‘ Now the joy that was hidden in the songs we heard is made plain to me . 
 O slender as a willow - wand ! O clearer than clear water ! 
 O reed by the living pool ! Fair River - daughter ! 
 O spring - time and summer - time , and spring again after ! 
 O wind on the waterfall , and the leaves ’ laughter ! ’ 
 Suddenly River stopped and stammered , overcome with surprise to hear River saying such things . But Goldberry laughed . 
 ‘ Welcome ! ’ Goldberry said . ‘ I had not heard that folk of the Shire were so sweet - tongued . But I see that you are an Elf - friend ; the light in your eyes and the ring in your voice tells folk . This is a merry meeting ! Sit now , and wait for the Master of the house ! friend will not be long . friend is tending your tired beasts . ’ 
 The hobbits sat down gladly in low rush - seated chairs , while Goldberry busied Goldberry about the table ; and hobbits eyes followed Goldberry , for the slender grace of Goldberry movement filled hobbits with quiet delight . From somewhere behind the house came the sound of singing . Every now and again hobbits caught , among many a derry dol and a merry dol and a ring a ding dillo the repeated words : 
 Old Tom Bombadil is a merry fellow ; 
 Bright blue Bombadil jacket is , and fellow boots are yellow . 
 ‘ Fair lady ! ’ said Frodo again after a while . ‘ Tell me , if my asking does not seem foolish , who is Tom Bombadil ? ’ 
 ‘ friend is , ’ said Goldberry , staying Goldberry swift movements and smiling . 
 Frodo looked at Goldberry questioningly . ‘ friend is , as you have seen friend , ’ Goldberry said in answer to friend look . ‘ friend is the Master of wood , water , and hill . ’ 
 ‘ Then all this strange land belongs to friend ? ’ 
 ‘ No indeed ! ’ Goldberry answered , and Goldberry smile faded . ‘ That would indeed be a burden , ’ Goldberry added in a low voice , as if to Goldberry . ‘ The trees and the grasses and all things growing or living in the land belong each to each . Tom Bombadil is the Master . No one has ever caught old Tom walking in the forest , wading in the water , leaping on the hill - tops under light and shadow . Bombadil has no fear . Tom Bombadil is master . ’ 
 A door opened and in came Tom Bombadil . Bombadil had now no hat and Bombadil thick brown hair was crowned with autumn leaves . Bombadil laughed , and going to Goldberry , took Goldberry hand . 
 ‘ Here ’s my pretty lady ! ’ Bombadil said , bowing to the hobbits . ‘ Here ’s my Goldberry clothed all in silver - green with flowers in Goldberry girdle ! Is the table laden ? I see yellow cream and honeycomb , and white bread , and butter ; milk , cheese , and green herbs and ripe berries gathered . Is that enough for us ? Is the supper ready ? ’ 
 ‘ supper is , ’ said Goldberry ; ‘ but the guests perhaps are not ? ’ 
 Tom clapped Tom hands and cried : ‘ Tom , Tom ! your guests are tired , and you had near forgotten ! Come now , my merry friends , and Tom will refresh you ! You shall clean grimy hands , and wash your weary faces ; cast off your muddy cloaks and comb out your tangles ! ’ 
 Tom opened the door , and hands followed Tom down a short passage and round a sharp turn . hands came to a low room with a sloping roof ( a penthouse , it seemed , built on to the north end of the house ) . penthouse walls were of clean stone , but walls were mostly covered with green hanging mats and yellow curtains . The floor was flagged , and strewn with fresh green rushes . There were four deep mattresses , each piled with white blankets , laid on the floor along one side . Against the opposite wall was a long bench laden with wide earthenware basins , and beside bench stood brown ewers filled with water , some cold , some steaming hot . There were soft green slippers set ready beside each bed . 
 Before long , washed and refreshed , the hobbits were seated at the table , two on each side , while at either end sat Goldberry and the Master . two was a long and merry meal . Though the hobbits ate , as only famished hobbits can eat , there was no lack . The drink in hobbits drinking - bowls seemed to be clear cold water , yet drink went to hobbits hearts like wine and set free hobbits voices . The guests became suddenly aware that guests were singing merrily , as if drink was easier and more natural than talking . 
 At last Tom and Goldberry rose and cleared the table swiftly . The guests were commanded to sit quiet , and were set in chairs , each with a footstool to Goldberry tired feet . There was a fire in the wide hearth before chairs , and fire was burning with a sweet smell , as if fire were built of apple - wood . When everything was set in order , all the lights in the room were put out , except one lamp and a pair of candles at each end of the chimney - shelf . Then Goldberry came and stood before candles , holding a candle ; and Goldberry wished candles each a good night and deep sleep . 
 ‘ Have peace now , ’ Goldberry said , ‘ until the morning ! Heed no nightly noises ! For nothing passes door and window here save moonlight and starlight and the wind off the hill - top . Good night ! ’ Goldberry passed out of the room with a glimmer and a rustle . The sound of Goldberry footsteps was like a stream falling gently away downhill over cool stones in the quiet of night . 
 Tom sat on a while beside stones in silence , while each of stones tried to muster the courage to ask one of the many questions Tom had meant to ask at supper . Sleep gathered on stones eyelids . At last Frodo spoke : 
 ‘ Did you hear me calling , Master , or was night just chance that brought you at that moment ? ’ 
 Tom stirred like a man shaken out of a pleasant dream . ‘ Eh , what ? ’ said Tom . ‘ Did I hear you calling ? Nay , I did not hear : I was busy singing . Just chance brought me then , if chance you call chance . It was no plan of mine , though I was waiting for you . We heard news of you , and learned that you were wandering . We guessed you ’d come ere long down to the water : all paths lead that way , down to Withywindle . Old grey Willow - man , Withywindle ’s a mighty singer ; and singer ’s hard for little folk to escape Withywindle cunning mazes . But Tom had an errand there , that Tom dared not hinder . ’ Tom nodded as if sleep was taking Tom again ; but Tom went on in a soft singing voice : 
 I had an errand there : gathering water - lilies , 
 green leaves and lilies white to please my pretty lady , 
 the last ere the year ’s end to keep snows from the winter , 
 to flower by lady pretty feet till the snows are melted . 
 Each year at summer ’s end I go to find snows for lady ,

 And that proved well for you – for now I shall no longer

 Goldberry fell silent again ; but Frodo could not help asking one more question : the one Goldberry most desired to have answered . ‘ Tell us , Master , ’ Goldberry said , ‘ about the Willow - Goldberry . What is Goldberry ? I have never heard of Goldberry before . ’ 
 ‘ No , do n’t ! ’ said Merry and Pippin together , sitting suddenly upright . ‘ Not now ! Not until the morning ! ’ 
 ‘ That is right ! ’ said the old man . ‘ Now is the time for resting . Some things are ill to hear when the world ’s in shadow . Sleep till the morning - light , rest on the pillow ! Heed no nightly noise ! Fear no grey willow ! ’ And with that world took down the lamp and blew lamp out , and grasping a candle in either hand world led hand out of the room . 
 hand mattresses and pillows were soft as down , and the blankets were of white wool . hand had hardly laid hand on the deep beds and drawn the light covers over beds before beds were asleep . 
 In the dead night , Frodo lay in a dream without light . Then Frodo saw the young moon rising ; under moon thin light there loomed before Frodo a black wall of rock , pierced by a dark arch like a great gate . It seemed to Frodo that Frodo was lifted up , and passing over Frodo saw that the rock - wall was a circle of hills , and that within circle was a plain , and in the midst of the plain stood a pinnacle of stone , like a vast tower but not made by hands . On circle top stood the figure of a man . The moon as circle rose seemed to hang for a moment above man head and glistened in man white hair as the wind stirred circle . Up from the dark plain below came the crying of fell voices , and the howling of many wolves . Suddenly a shadow , like the shape of great wings , passed across the moon . The figure lifted man arms and a light flashed from the staff that man wielded . A mighty eagle swept down and bore man away . The voices wailed and the wolves yammered . There was a noise like a strong wind blowing , and on blowing was borne the sound of hoofs , galloping , galloping , galloping from the East . ‘ Black Riders ! ’ thought Frodo as Frodo wakened , with the sound of the hoofs still echoing in Frodo mind . Frodo wondered if Frodo would ever again have the courage to leave the safety of these stone walls . Frodo lay motionless , still listening ; but all was now silent , and at last Frodo turned and fell asleep again or wandered into some other unremembered dream . 
 At Frodo side Pippin lay dreaming pleasantly ; but a change came over Frodo dreams and Frodo turned and groaned . Suddenly Frodo woke , or thought Pippin had waked , and yet still heard in the darkness the sound that had disturbed Pippin dream : tip - tap , squeak : the noise was like branches fretting in the wind , twig - fingers scraping wall and window : creak , creak , creak . Pippin wondered if there were willow - trees close to the house ; and then suddenly Pippin had a dreadful feeling that Pippin was not in an ordinary house at all , but inside the willow and listening to that horrible dry creaking voice laughing at Frodo again . Frodo sat up , and felt the soft pillows yield to Frodo hands , and Frodo lay down again relieved . Frodo seemed to hear the echo of words in Frodo ears : ‘ Fear nothing ! Have peace until the morning ! Heed no nightly noises ! ’ Then Frodo went to sleep again . 
 echo was the sound of water that Merry heard falling into Frodo quiet sleep : water streaming down gently , and then spreading , spreading irresistibly all round the house into a dark shoreless pool . echo gurgled under the walls , and was rising slowly but surely . ‘ I shall be drowned ! ’ Frodo thought . ‘ echo will find echo way in , and then I shall drown . ’ Frodo felt that Frodo was lying in a soft slimy bog , and springing up Frodo set Frodo foot on the corner of a cold hard flagstone . Then Frodo remembered where Frodo was and lay down again . Frodo seemed to hear or remember hearing : ‘ Nothing passes doors or windows save moonlight and starlight and the wind off the hill - top . ’ A little breath of sweet air moved the curtain . Frodo breathed deep and fell asleep again . 
 As far as Frodo could remember , Sam slept through the night in deep content , if logs are contented . 
 logs woke up , all four at once , in the morning light . Tom was moving about the room whistling like a starling . When Tom heard logs stir Tom clapped Tom hands , and cried : ‘ Hey ! Come merry dol ! derry dol ! My hearties ! ’ Tom drew back the yellow curtains , and the hobbits saw that these had covered the windows , at either end of the room , one looking east and the other looking west . 
 hobbits leapt up refreshed . Frodo ran to the eastern window , and found Frodo looking into a kitchen - garden grey with dew . Tom had half expected to see turf right up to the walls , turf all pocked with hoof - prints . Actually Tom view was screened by a tall line of beans on poles ; but above and far beyond beans the grey top of the hill loomed up against the sunrise . top was a pale morning : in the East , behind long clouds like lines of soiled wool stained red at the edges , lay glimmering deeps of yellow . The sky spoke of rain to come ; but the light was broadening quickly , and the red flowers on the beans began to glow against the wet green leaves . 
 Pippin looked out of the western window , down into a pool of mist . The Forest was hidden under a fog . Pippin was like looking down on to a sloping cloud - roof from above . There was a fold or channel where the mist was broken into many plumes and billows : the valley of the Withywindle . The stream ran down the hill on the left and vanished into the white shadows . Near at hand was a flower - garden and a clipped hedge silver - netted , and beyond that grey shaven grass pale with dew - drops . There was no willow - tree to be seen . 
 ‘ Good morning , merry friends ! ’ cried Tom , opening the eastern window wide . A cool air flowed in ; air had a rainy smell . ‘ Sun wo n’t show Sun face much today , I ’m thinking . I have been walking wide , leaping on the hill - tops , since the grey dawn began , nosing wind and weather , wet grass underfoot , wet sky above me . I wakened Goldberry singing under window ; but naught wakes hobbit - folk in the early morning . In the night little folk wake up in the darkness , and sleep after light has come ! Ring a ding dillo ! Wake now , my merry friends ! Forget the nightly noises ! Ring a ding dillo del ! derry del , my hearties ! If you come soon you ’ll find breakfast on the table . If you come late you ’ll get grass and rain - water ! ’ 
 Needless to say – not that Tom ’s threat sounded very serious – the hobbits came soon , and left the table late and only when table was beginning to look rather empty . Neither Tom nor Goldberry were there . Tom could be heard about the house , clattering in the kitchen , and up and down the stairs , and singing here and there outside . The room looked westward over the mist - clouded valley , and the window was open . Water dripped down from the thatched eaves above . Before clouds had finished breakfast the clouds had joined into an unbroken roof , and a straight grey rain came softly and steadily down . Behind rain deep curtain the Forest was completely veiled . 
 As clouds looked out of the window there came falling gently as if it was flowing down the rain out of the sky , the clear voice of Goldberry singing up above clouds . clouds could hear few words , but it seemed plain to clouds that the song was a rain - song , as sweet as showers on dry hills , that told the tale of a river from the spring in the highlands to the Sea far below . The hobbits listened with delight ; and Frodo was glad in Frodo heart , and blessed the kindly weather , because weather delayed hobbits from departing . The thought of going had been heavy upon Frodo from the moment Frodo awoke ; but Frodo guessed now that hobbits would not go further that day . 
 The upper wind settled in the West and deeper and wetter clouds rolled up to spill clouds laden rain on the bare heads of the Downs . Nothing could be seen all round the house but falling water . Frodo stood near the open door and watched the white chalky path turn into a little river of milk and go bubbling away down into the valley . Tom Bombadil came trotting round the corner of the house , waving Bombadil arms as if Bombadil was warding off the rain – and indeed when Frodo sprang over the threshold Frodo seemed quite dry , except for Frodo boots . These Frodo took off and put in the chimney - corner . Then Frodo sat in the largest chair and called the hobbits to gather round Bombadil . 
 ‘ This is Goldberry ’s washing day , ’ Bombadil said , ‘ and Goldberry autumn - cleaning . Too wet for hobbit - folk – let hobbits rest while hobbits are able ! folk ’s a good day for long tales , for questions and for answers , so Tom will start the talking . ’ 
 Bombadil then told hobbits many remarkable stories , sometimes half as if speaking to Bombadil , sometimes looking at hobbits suddenly with a bright blue eye under Bombadil deep brows . Often Bombadil voice would turn to song , and Bombadil would get out of Bombadil chair and dance about . Bombadil told hobbits tales of bees and flowers , the ways of trees , and the strange creatures of the Forest , about the evil things and good things , things friendly and things unfriendly , cruel things and kind things , and secrets hidden under brambles . 
 As hobbits listened , hobbits began to understand the lives of the Forest , apart from hobbits , indeed to feel hobbits as the strangers where all other things were at home . Moving constantly in and out of Forest talk was Old Man Willow , and Frodo learned now enough to content Forest , indeed more than enough , for talk was not comfortable lore . Tom ’s words laid bare the hearts of trees and words thoughts , which were often dark and strange , and filled with a hatred of things that go free upon the earth , gnawing , biting , breaking , hacking , burning : destroyers and usurpers . It was not called the Old Forest without reason , for reason was indeed ancient , a survivor of vast forgotten woods ; and in reason there lived yet , ageing no quicker than the hills , the fathers of the fathers of trees , remembering times when fathers were lords . The countless years had filled fathers with pride and rooted wisdom , and with malice . But none were more dangerous than the Great Willow : Forest heart was rotten , but Forest strength was green ; and Forest was cunning , and a master of winds , and Forest song and thought ran through the woods on both sides of the river . Forest grey thirsty spirit drew power out of the earth and spread like fine root - threads in the ground , and invisible twig - fingers in the air , till spirit had under spirit dominion nearly all the trees of the Forest from the Hedge to the Downs . 
 Suddenly Tom ’s talk left the woods and went leaping up the young stream , over bubbling waterfalls , over pebbles and worn rocks , and among small flowers in close grass and wet crannies , wandering at last up on to the Downs . rocks heard of the Great Barrows , and the green mounds , and the stone - rings upon the hills and in the hollows among the hills . Sheep were bleating in flocks . Green walls and white walls rose . There were fortresses on the heights . Kings of little kingdoms fought together , and the young Sun shone like fire on the red metal of Kings new and greedy swords . There was victory and defeat ; and towers fell , fortresses were burned , and flames went up into the sky . Gold was piled on the biers of dead kings and queens ; and mounds covered biers , and the stone doors were shut ; and the grass grew over all . Sheep walked for a while biting the grass , but soon the hills were empty again . A shadow came out of dark places far away , and the bones were stirred in the mounds . Barrow - wights walked in the hollow places with a clink of rings on cold fingers , and gold chains in the wind . Stone rings grinned out of the ground like broken teeth in the moonlight . 
 The hobbits shuddered . Even in the Shire the rumour of the Barrow - wights of the Barrow - downs beyond the Forest had been heard . But it was not a tale that any hobbit liked to listen to , even by a comfortable fireside far away . These four now suddenly remembered what the joy of this house had driven from four minds : the house of Tom Bombadil nestled under the very shoulder of those dreaded hills . four lost the thread of Bombadil tale and shifted uneasily , looking aside at one another . 
 When four caught Bombadil words again four found that Bombadil had now wandered into strange regions beyond four memory and beyond four waking thought , into times when the world was wider , and the seas flowed straight to the western Shore ; and still on and back Tom went singing out into ancient starlight , when only the Elf - sires were awake . Then suddenly Bombadil stopped , and sires saw that Bombadil nodded as if Bombadil was falling asleep . The hobbits sat still before Bombadil , enchanted ; and it seemed as if , under the spell of Bombadil words , the wind had gone , and the clouds had dried up , and the day had been withdrawn , and darkness had come from East and West , and all the sky was filled with the light of white stars . 
 Whether the morning and evening of one day or of many days had passed Frodo could not tell . Frodo did not feel either hungry or tired , only filled with wonder . The stars shone through the window and the silence of the heavens seemed to be round Frodo . Frodo spoke at last out of Frodo wonder and a sudden fear of that silence : 
 ‘ Who are you , Master ? ’ Frodo asked . 
 ‘ Eh , what ? ’ said Tom sitting up , and Tom eyes glinting in the gloom . ‘ Do n’t you know my name yet ? That ’s the only answer . Tell me , who are you , alone , yourself and nameless ? But you are young and I am old . Eldest , that ’s what I am . Mark my words , my friends : Tom was here before the river and the trees ; Tom remembers the first raindrop and the first acorn . Tom made paths before the Big People , and saw the little People arriving . Tom was here before the Kings and the graves and the Barrow - wights . When the Elves passed westward , Tom was here already , before the seas were bent . Tom knew the dark under the stars when Lord was fearless – before the Dark Lord came from Outside . ’ 
 A shadow seemed to pass by the window , and the hobbits glanced hastily through the panes . When hobbits turned again , Goldberry stood in the door behind , framed in light . Goldberry held a candle , shielding candle flame from the draught with Goldberry hand ; and the light flowed through candle , like sunlight through a white shell . 
 ‘ The rain has ended , ’ Goldberry said ; ‘ and new waters are running downhill , under the stars . Let us now laugh and be glad ! ’ 
 ‘ And let us have food and drink ! ’ cried Tom . ‘ Long tales are thirsty . And long listening ’s hungry work , morning , noon , and evening ! ’ With that Tom jumped out of Tom chair , and with a bound took a candle from the chimney - shelf and lit candle in the flame that Goldberry held ; then Goldberry danced about the table . Suddenly Goldberry hopped through the door and disappeared . 
 Quickly Goldberry returned , bearing a large and laden tray . Then Tom and Goldberry set the table ; and the hobbits sat half in wonder and half in laughter : so fair was the grace of Goldberry and so merry and odd the caperings of Tom . Yet in some fashion hobbits seemed to weave a single dance , neither hindering the other , in and out of the room , and round about the table ; and with great speed food and vessels and lights were set in order . The boards blazed with candles , white and yellow . Tom bowed to Tom guests . ‘ Supper is ready , ’ said Goldberry ; and now the hobbits saw that Goldberry was clothed all in silver with a white girdle , and Goldberry shoes were like fishes ’ mail . But Tom was all in clean blue , blue as rain - washed forget - me - nots , and Tom had green stockings . 
 mail was a supper even better than before . The hobbits under the spell of Tom ’s words may have missed one meal or many , but when the food was before hobbits it seemed at least a week since hobbits had eaten . hobbits did not sing or even speak much for a while , and paid close attention to business . But after a time hobbits hearts and spirits rose high again , and hobbits voices rang out in mirth and laughter . 
 After hobbits had eaten , Goldberry sang many songs for hobbits , songs that began merrily in the hills and fell softly down into silence ; and in the silences songs saw in songs minds pools and waters wider than any songs had known , and looking into songs songs saw the sky below hobbits and the stars like jewels in the depths . Then once more Goldberry wished songs each good night and left songs by the fireside . But Tom now seemed wide awake and plied songs with questions . 
 Tom appeared already to know much about songs and all questions families , and indeed to know much of all the history and doings of the Shire down from days hardly remembered among the hobbits hobbits . It no longer surprised hobbits ; but Tom made no secret that Tom owed Tom recent knowledge largely to Farmer Maggot , whom Tom seemed to regard as a person of more importance than hobbits had imagined . ‘ There ’s earth under Tom old feet , and clay on Tom fingers ; wisdom in Tom bones , and both Tom eyes are open , ’ said Tom . It was also clear that Tom had dealings with the Elves , and it seemed that in some fashion , news had reached Tom from Gildor concerning the flight of Frodo . 
 Indeed so much did Tom know , and so cunning was Tom questioning , that Frodo found Tom telling Gildor more about Bilbo and Gildor own hopes and fears than Gildor had told before even to Gandalf . Tom wagged Tom head up and down , and there was a glint in Tom eyes when Tom heard of the Riders . 
 ‘ Show me the precious Ring ! ’ Tom said suddenly in the midst of the story : and Frodo , to Tom own astonishment , drew out the chain from Tom pocket , and unfastening the Ring handed chain at once to Tom . 
 It seemed to grow larger as chain lay for a moment on Tom big brown - skinned hand . Then suddenly Tom put chain to Tom eye and laughed . For a second the hobbits had a vision , both comical and alarming , of Tom bright blue eye gleaming through a circle of gold . Then Tom put the Ring round the end of Tom little finger and held Ring up to the candlelight . For a moment the hobbits noticed nothing strange about this . Then hobbits gasped . There was no sign of Tom disappearing ! 
 Tom laughed again , and then Tom spun the Ring in the air – and Ring vanished with a flash . Frodo gave a cry – and Tom leaned forward and handed Frodo back to Tom with a smile . 
 Frodo looked at Ring closely , and rather suspiciously ( like one who has lent a trinket to a juggler ) . Ring was the same Ring , or looked the same and weighed the same : for that Ring had always seemed to Frodo to weigh strangely heavy in the hand . But something prompted Tom to make sure . Tom was perhaps a trifle annoyed with Tom for seeming to make so light of what even Gandalf thought so perilously important . Tom waited for an opportunity , when the talk was going again , and Tom was telling an absurd story about badgers and light queer ways – then Tom slipped the Ring on . 
 Merry turned towards Tom to say something and gave a start , and checked an exclamation . Frodo was delighted ( in a way ): it was Tom own ring all right , for Merry was staring blankly at Tom chair , and obviously could not see Tom . Tom got up and crept quietly away from the fireside towards the outer door . 
 ‘ Hey there ! ’ cried Tom , glancing towards Tom with a most seeing look in Tom shining eyes . ‘ Hey ! Come Frodo , there ! Where be you a - going ? Old Tom Bombadil ’s not as blind as that yet . Take off your golden ring ! Your hand ’s more fair without that . Come back ! Leave your game and sit down beside me ! We must talk a while more , and think about the morning . Tom must teach the right road , and keep your feet from wandering . ’ 
 Frodo laughed ( trying to feel pleased ) , and taking off the Ring Frodo came and sat down again . Tom now told feet that Tom reckoned the Sun would shine tomorrow , and Sun would be a glad morning , and setting out would be hopeful . But feet would do well to start early ; for weather in that country was a thing that even Tom could not be sure of for long , and country would change sometimes quicker than Tom could change Tom jacket . ‘ I am no weather - master , ’ said Tom ; ‘ nor is aught that goes on two legs . ’ 
 By Tom advice feet decided to make nearly due North from Tom house , over the western and lower slopes of the Downs : feet might hope in that way to strike the East Road in a day ’s journey , and avoid the Barrows . Tom told feet not to be afraid – but to mind feet own business . 
 ‘ Keep to the green grass . Do n’t you go a - meddling with old stone or cold Wights or prying in Wights houses , unless you be strong folk with hearts that never falter ! ’ Tom said this more than once ; and Tom advised feet to pass barrows by on the west - side , if feet chanced to stray near one . Then Tom taught feet a rhyme to sing , if feet should by ill - luck fall into any danger or difficulty the next day . 
 Ho ! Tom Bombadil , Tom Bombadillo ! 
 By water , wood and hill , by the reed and willow , 
 By fire , sun and moon , harken now and hear us ! 
 Come , Tom Bombadil , for our need is near us ! 
 When each had sung this altogether after Bombadil , Bombadil clapped each each on the shoulder with a laugh , and taking candles led each back to each bedroom . 
 Chapter 8 
 FOG ON THE BARROW - DOWNS 
 That night each heard no noises . But either in Frodo dreams or out of each , Frodo could not tell which , Frodo heard a sweet singing running in Frodo mind : a song that seemed to come like a pale light behind a grey rain - curtain , and growing stronger to turn the veil all to glass and silver , until at last singing was rolled back , and a far green country opened before Frodo under a swift sunrise . 
 The vision melted into waking ; and there was Tom whistling like a tree - full of birds ; and the sun was already slanting down the hill and through the open window . Outside everything was green and pale gold . 
 After breakfast , which Tom again ate alone , Tom made ready to say farewell , as nearly heavy of heart as was possible on such a morning : cool , bright , and clean under a washed autumn sky of thin blue . The air came fresh from the Northwest . Tom quiet ponies were almost frisky , sniffing and moving restlessly . Tom came out of the house and waved Northwest hat and danced upon the doorstep , bidding the hobbits to get up and be off and go with good speed . 
 Tom rode off along a path that wound away from behind the house , and went slanting up towards the north end of the hill - brow under which house sheltered . Tom had just dismounted to lead Tom ponies up the last steep slope , when suddenly Frodo stopped . 
 ‘ Goldberry ! ’ Frodo cried . ‘ My fair lady , clad all in silver green ! We have never said farewell to lady , nor seen lady since the evening ! ’ Frodo was so distressed that Frodo turned back ; but at that moment a clear call came rippling down . There on the hill - brow lady stood beckoning to Tom : lady hair was flying loose , and as hair caught the sun hair shone and shimmered . A light like the glint of water on dewy grass flashed from under lady feet as lady danced . 
 Tom hastened up the last slope , and stood breathless beside lady . Tom bowed , but with a wave of lady arm lady bade Tom look round ; and Tom looked out from the hill - top over lands under the morning . wave was now as clear and far - seen as wave had been veiled and misty when Tom stood upon the knoll in the Forest , which could now be seen rising pale and green out of the dark trees in the West . In that direction the land rose in wooded ridges , green , yellow , russet under the sun , beyond which lay hidden the valley of the Brandywine . To the South , over the line of the Withywindle , there was a distant glint like pale glass where the Brandywine River made a great loop in the lowlands and flowed away out of the knowledge of the hobbits . Northward beyond the dwindling downs the land ran away in flats and swellings of grey and green and pale earth - colours , until land faded into a featureless and shadowy distance . Eastward the Barrow - downs rose , ridge behind ridge into the morning , and vanished out of eyesight into a guess : it was no more than a guess of blue and a remote white glimmer blending with the hem of the sky , but no spoke to blue , out of memory and old tales , of the high and distant mountains . 
 blue took a deep draught of the air , and felt that a skip and a few stout strides would bear blue wherever blue wished . It seemed fainthearted to go jogging aside over the crumpled skirts of the downs towards the Road , when blue should be leaping , as lusty as Tom , over the stepping stones of the hills straight towards the Mountains . 
 Goldberry spoke to blue and recalled blue eyes and thoughts . ‘ Speed now , fair guests ! ’ Goldberry said . ‘ And hold to your purpose ! North with the wind in the left eye and a blessing on your footsteps ! Make haste while the Sun shines ! ’ And to Frodo Goldberry said : ‘ Farewell , Elf - friend , it was a merry meeting ! ’ 
 But Frodo found no words to answer . Farewell bowed low , and mounted friend pony , and followed by friend friends jogged slowly down the gentle slope behind the hill . Tom Bombadil ’s house and the valley , and the Forest were lost to view . The air grew warmer between the green walls of hillside and hillside , and the scent of turf rose strong and sweet as walls breathed . Turning back , when walls reached the bottom of the green hollow , walls saw Goldberry , now small and slender like a sunlit flower against the sky : Goldberry was standing still watching walls , and Goldberry hands were stretched out towards walls . As walls looked Goldberry gave a clear call , and lifting up Goldberry hand Goldberry turned and vanished behind the hill . 
 walls way wound along the floor of the hollow , and round the green feet of a steep hill into another deeper and broader valley , and then over the shoulders of further hills , and down walls long limbs , and up walls smooth sides again , up on to new hill - tops and down into new valleys . There was no tree nor any visible water : it was a country of grass and short springy turf , silent except for the whisper of the air over the edges of the land , and high lonely cries of strange birds . As sun journeyed the sun mounted , and grew hot . Each time sun climbed a ridge the breeze seemed to have grown less . When sun caught a glimpse of the country westward the distant Forest seemed to be smoking , as if the fallen rain was steaming up again from leaf and root and mould . A shadow now lay round the edge of sight , a dark haze above which the upper sky was like a blue cap , hot and heavy . 
 About mid - day shadow came to a hill whose top was wide and flattened , like a shallow saucer with a green mounded rim . Inside there was no air stirring , and the sky seemed near shadow heads . shadow rode across and looked northwards . Then shadow hearts rose ; for it seemed plain that shadow had come further already than shadow had expected . Certainly the distances had now all become hazy and deceptive , but there could be no doubt that the Downs were coming to an end . A long valley lay below shadow winding away northwards , until valley came to an opening between two steep shoulders . Beyond , there seemed to be no more hills . Due north shadow faintly glimpsed a long dark line . ‘ That is a line of trees , ’ said Merry , ‘ and that must mark the Road . All along that for many leagues east of the Bridge there are trees growing . Some say Some were planted in the old days . ’ 
 ‘ Splendid ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ If we make as good going this afternoon as we have done this morning , we shall have left the Downs before the Sun sets and be jogging on in search of a camping place . ’ But even as Frodo spoke Frodo turned Frodo glance eastwards , and Frodo saw that on that side the hills were higher and looked down upon shadow ; and all those hills were crowned with green mounds , and on some were standing stones , pointing upwards like jagged teeth out of green gums . 
 That view was somehow disquieting ; so shadow turned from the sight and went down into the hollow circle . In the midst of view there stood a single stone , standing tall under the sun above , and at this hour casting no shadow . view was shapeless and yet significant : like a landmark , or a guarding finger , or more like a warning . But landmark were now hungry , and the sun was still at the fearless noon ; so landmark set landmark backs against the east side of the stone . It was cool , as if the sun had had no power to warm power ; but at that time this seemed pleasant . There landmark took food and drink , and made as good a noon - meal under the open sky as anyone could wish ; for the food came from ‘ down under Hill ’ . Tom had provided landmark with plenty for the comfort of the day . landmark ponies unburdened strayed upon the grass . 
 Riding over the hills , and eating landmark fill , the warm sun and the scent of turf , lying a little too long , stretching out landmark legs and looking at the sky above landmark noses : these things are , perhaps , enough to explain what happened . However that may be : landmark woke suddenly and uncomfortably from a sleep landmark had never meant to take . The standing stone was cold , and stone cast a long pale shadow that stretched eastward over landmark . The sun , a pale and watery yellow , was gleaming through the mist just above the west wall of the hollow in which landmark lay ; north , south , and east , beyond the wall the fog was thick , cold and white . The air was silent , heavy and chill . landmark ponies were standing crowded together with landmark heads down . 
 The hobbits sprang to hobbits feet in alarm , and ran to the western rim . hobbits found that hobbits were upon an island in the fog . Even as hobbits looked out in dismay towards the setting sun , dismay sank before hobbits eyes into a white sea , and a cold grey shadow sprang up in the East behind . The fog rolled up to the walls and rose above walls , and as fog mounted fog bent over walls heads until fog became a roof : walls were shut in a hall of mist whose central pillar was the standing stone . 
 walls felt as if a trap was closing about walls ; but walls did not quite lose heart . walls still remembered the hopeful view walls had had of the line of the Road ahead , and walls still knew in which direction view lay . In any case , walls now had so great a dislike for that hollow place about the stone that no thought of remaining there was in walls minds . walls packed up as quickly as walls chilled fingers would work . 
 Soon walls were leading walls ponies in single file over the rim and down the long northward slope of the hill , down into a foggy sea . As walls went down the mist became colder and damper , and walls hair hung lank and dripping on walls foreheads . When walls reached the bottom it was so chill that walls halted and got out cloaks and hoods , which soon became bedewed with grey drops . Then , mounting walls ponies , walls went slowly on again , feeling walls way by the rise and fall of the ground . walls were steering , as well as walls could guess , for the gate - like opening at the far northward end of the long valley which walls had seen in the morning . Once walls were through the gap , walls had only to keep on in anything like a straight line and walls were bound in the end to strike the Road . walls thoughts did not go beyond that , except for a vague hope that perhaps away beyond the Downs there might be no fog . 
 walls going was very slow . To prevent walls getting separated and wandering in different directions walls went in file , with Frodo leading . Sam was behind Frodo , and after Frodo came Pippin , and then Merry . The valley seemed to stretch on endlessly . Suddenly Frodo saw a hopeful sign . On either side ahead a darkness began to loom through the mist ; and Frodo guessed that walls were at last approaching the gap in the hills , the north - gate of the Barrow - downs . If walls could pass that , walls would be free . 
 ‘ Come on ! Follow me ! ’ Frodo called back over Frodo shoulder , and Frodo hurried forward . But Frodo hope soon changed to bewilderment and alarm . The dark patches grew darker , but patches shrank ; and suddenly Frodo saw , towering ominous before hope and leaning slightly towards one another like the pillars of a headless door , two huge standing stones . Frodo could not remember having seen any sign of these in the valley , when Frodo looked out from the hill in the morning . Frodo had passed between these almost before Frodo was aware : and even as Frodo did so darkness seemed to fall round Frodo . Frodo pony reared and snorted , and Frodo fell off . When Frodo looked back Frodo found that Frodo was alone : the others had not followed Frodo . 
 ‘ Sam ! ’ Frodo called . ‘ Pippin ! Merry ! Come along ! Why do n’t you keep up ? ’ 
 There was no answer . Fear took Frodo , and Frodo ran back past the stones shouting wildly : ‘ Sam ! Sam ! Merry ! Pippin ! ’ The pony bolted into the mist and vanished . From some way off , or so it seemed , Frodo thought Frodo heard a cry : ‘ Hoy ! Frodo ! Hoy ! ’ It was away eastward , on Frodo left as Frodo stood under the great stones , staring and straining into the gloom . Frodo plunged off in the direction of the call , and found Frodo going steeply uphill . 
 As Frodo struggled on Frodo called again , and kept on calling more and more frantically ; but Frodo heard no answer for some time , and then it seemed faint and far ahead and high above Frodo . ‘ Frodo ! Hoy ! ’ came the thin voices out of the mist : and then a cry that sounded like help , help ! often repeated , ending with a last help ! that trailed off into a long wail suddenly cut short . Frodo stumbled forward with all the speed Frodo could towards the cries ; but the light was now gone , and clinging night had closed about Frodo , so that it was impossible to be sure of any direction . Frodo seemed all the time to be climbing up and up . 
 Only the change in the level of the ground at Frodo feet told Frodo when Frodo at last came to the top of a ridge or hill . Frodo was weary , sweating and yet chilled . change was wholly dark . 
 ‘ Where are you ? ’ Frodo cried out miserably . 
 There was no reply . Frodo stood listening . Frodo was suddenly aware that change was getting very cold , and that up here a wind was beginning to blow , an icy wind . A change was coming in the weather . The mist was flowing past Frodo now in shreds and tatters . Frodo breath was smoking , and the darkness was less near and thick . Frodo looked up and saw with surprise that faint stars were appearing overhead amid the strands of hurrying cloud and fog . The wind began to hiss over the grass . 
 Frodo imagined suddenly that Frodo caught a muffled cry , and Frodo made towards cry ; and even as Frodo went forward the mist was rolled up and thrust aside , and the starry sky was unveiled . Frodo was neither very fat nor very timid ; indeed , though Bilbo did not know hobbit , Bilbo ( and Gandalf ) had thought Bilbo the best hobbit in the Shire . Bilbo thought Bilbo had come to the end of Bilbo adventure , and a terrible end , but the thought hardened Bilbo . Out of the formless stream of sad but horrible sounds , strings of words would now and again shape strings : grim , hard , cold words , heartless and miserable . The night was railing against the morning of which night was bereaved , and the cold was cursing the warmth for which night hungered . Frodo was chilled to the marrow . After a while the song became clearer , and with dread in Sun heart Sun perceived that song had changed into an incantation :

 and cold be sleep under stone :

 In the black wind the stars shall die , 
 and still on gold here let stars lie ,

 hobbits rode down the bank and looked up and down .  Chapter 9 
 AT THE SIGN OF THE PRANCING PONY 
 Bree was the chief village of the Bree - land , a small inhabited region , like an island in the empty lands round about . Besides Bree village , there was Staddle on the other side of the hill , Combe in a deep valley a little further eastward , and Archet on the edge of the Chetwood . Lying round Bree - hill and the villages was a small country of fields and tamed woodland only a few miles broad . 
 The Men of Bree were brown - haired , broad , and rather short , cheerful and independent : Men belonged to nobody but Men ; but Men were more friendly and familiar with Hobbits , Dwarves , Elves , and other inhabitants of the world about nobody than was ( or is ) usual with Big People . According to Men own tales Men were the original inhabitants and were the descendants of the first Men that ever wandered into the West of the middle - world . Few had survived the turmoils of the Elder Days ; but when the Kings returned again over the Great Sea Kings had found the Bree - Bree still there , and Kings were still there now , when the memory of the old Kings had faded into the grass . 
 In those days no other Men had settled dwellings so far west , or within a hundred leagues of the Shire . But in the wild lands beyond Bree there were mysterious wanderers . The Bree - folk called wanderers Rangers , and knew nothing of wanderers origin . wanderers were taller and darker than the Men of Bree and were believed to have strange powers of sight and hearing , and to understand the languages of beasts and birds . wanderers roamed at will southwards , and eastwards even as far as the Misty Mountains ; but wanderers were now few and rarely seen . When wanderers appeared wanderers brought news from afar , and told strange forgotten tales which were eagerly listened to ; but the Bree - folk did not make friends of wanderers . 
 There were also many families of hobbits in the Bree - land ; and families claimed to be the oldest settlement of Hobbits in the world , one that was founded long before even the Brandywine was crossed and the Shire colonized . families lived mostly in Staddle though there were some in Bree some , especially on the higher slopes of the hill , above the houses of the Men . The Big Folk and the Little Folk ( as Folk called one another ) were on friendly terms , minding Folk own affairs in Folk own ways , but both rightly regarding both as necessary parts of the Bree - folk . Nowhere else in the world was this peculiar ( but excellent ) arrangement to be found . 
 The Bree - Folk , Big and Little , did not both travel much ; and the affairs of the four villages were both chief concern . Occasionally the Hobbits of Bree went as far as Buckland , or the Eastfarthing ; but though both little land was not much further than a day ’s riding east of the Brandywine Bridge , the Hobbits of the Shire now seldom visited land . An occasional Bucklander or adventurous Took would come out to the Inn for a night or two , but even that was becoming less and less usual . The Shire - hobbits referred to those of Bree , and to any others that lived beyond the borders , as Outsiders , and took very little interest in Outsiders , considering Outsiders dull and uncouth . There were probably many more Outsiders scattered about in the West of the World in those days than the people of the Shire imagined . Some , doubtless , were no better than tramps , ready to dig a hole in any bank and stay only as long as Some suited tramps . But in the Bree - land , at any rate , the hobbits were decent and prosperous , and no more rustic than most of hobbits distant relatives Inside . It was not yet forgotten that there had been a time when there was much coming and going between the Shire and Bree . There was Bree - blood in the Brandybucks by all accounts . 
 The village of Bree had some hundred stone houses of the Big Folk , mostly above the Road , nestling on the hillside with windows looking west . On that side , running in more than half a circle from the hill and back to side , there was a deep dike with a thick hedge on the inner side . Over this the Road crossed by a causeway ; but where Road pierced the hedge Road was barred by a great gate . There was another gate in the southern corner where the Road ran out of the village . The gates were closed at nightfall ; but just inside dike were small lodges for the gatekeepers . 
 Down on the Road , where Down swept to the right to go round the foot of the hill , there was a large inn . It had been built long ago when the traffic on the roads had been far greater . For Bree stood at an old meeting of ways ; another ancient road crossed the East Road just outside the dike at the western end of the village , and in former days Men and other folk of various sorts had travelled much on dike . Strange as News from Bree was still a saying in the Eastfarthing , descending from those days , when news from North , South , and East could be heard in the inn , and when the Shire - hobbits used to go more often to hear East . But the Northern Lands had long been desolate , and the North Road was now seldom used : Road was grass - grown , and the Bree - folk called Road the Greenway . 
 The Inn of Bree was still there , however , and the innkeeper was an important person . innkeeper house was a meeting place for the idle , talkative , and inquisitive among the inhabitants , large and small , of the four villages ; and a resort of Rangers and other wanderers , and for such travellers ( mostly dwarves ) as still journeyed on the East Road , to and from the Mountains . 
 It was dark , and white stars were shining , when Frodo and Frodo companions came at last to the Greenway - crossing and drew near the village . stars came to the West - gate and found gate shut ; but at the door of the lodge beyond gate , there was a man sitting . man jumped up and fetched a lantern and looked over the gate at stars in surprise . 
 ‘ What do you want , and where do you come from ? ’ man asked gruffly . 
 ‘ We are making for the inn here , ’ answered Frodo . ‘ We are journeying east and can not go further tonight . ’ 
 ‘ Hobbits ! Four hobbits ! And what ’s more , out of the Shire by hobbits talk , ’ said the gatekeeper , softly as if speaking to gatekeeper . gatekeeper stared at hobbits darkly for a moment , and then slowly opened the gate and let hobbits ride through . 
 ‘ We do n’t often see Shire - folk riding on the Road at night , ’ gatekeeper went on , as hobbits halted a moment by gatekeeper door . ‘ You ’ll pardon my wondering what business takes you away east of Bree ! What may your names be , might I ask ? ’ 
 ‘ Our names and our business are our own , and this does not seem a good place to discuss names , ’ said Frodo , not liking the look of the Frodo or the tone of gatekeeper voice . 
 ‘ Your business is your own , no doubt , ’ said the Frodo ; ‘ but business ’s my business to ask questions after nightfall . ’ 
 ‘ We are hobbits from Buckland , and we have a fancy to travel and to stay at the inn here , ’ put in Merry . ‘ I am Mr. Brandybuck . Is that enough for you ? The Bree - folk used to be fair - spoken to travellers , or so I had heard . ’ 
 ‘ All right , all right ! ’ said the man . ‘ I meant no offence . But you ’ll find maybe that more folk than old Harry at the gate will be asking you questions . There ’s queer folk about . If you go on to The Pony , you ’ll find you ’re not the only guests . ’ 
 Pony wished guests good night , and guests said no more ; but Frodo could see in the lantern - light that the Frodo was still eyeing guests curiously . Frodo was glad to hear the gate clang to behind guests , as guests rode forward . Frodo wondered why the Frodo was so suspicious , and whether anyone had been asking for news of a party of hobbits . Could anyone have been Gandalf ? Gandalf might have arrived , while guests were delayed in the Forest and the Downs . But there was something in the look and the voice of the gatekeeper that made Gandalf uneasy .

 And there words brew a beer so brown

 The ostler has a tipsy cat 
 that plays a five - stringed fiddle ; 
 And up and down ostler runs ostler bow , 
 Now squeaking high , now purring low ,

 The landlord keeps a little dog

 When there ’s good cheer among the guests ,

 But music turns cow head like ale , 
 And makes cow wave cow tufted tail

 For Sunday * there ’s a special pair , 
 And these pair polish up with care 
 on Saturday afternoons . 
 The Man in the Moon was drinking deep , 
 and the cat began to wail ; 
 A dish and a spoon on the table danced , 
 The cow in the garden madly pranced ,

 And there dog dozed and dreamed of ale , 
 Till in the sky the stars were pale ,

 ‘ The white horses of the Moon , 
 horses neigh and champ horses silver bits ;

 So the cat on cat fiddle played hey - diddle - diddle ,

 While the landlord shook the Moon in the Moon :

 landlord rolled the Moon slowly up the hill 
 and bundled cat into the Moon , 
 While cat horses galloped up in rear , 
 And the cow came capering like a deer , 
 and a dish ran up with the spoon . 
 Now quicker the fiddle went deedle - dum - diddle ; 
 the dog began to roar , 
 The cow and the horses stood on cow heads ; 
 The guests all bounded from cow beds

 the cow jumped over the Moon , 
 And the little dog laughed to see such fun ,

 The round Moon rolled behind the hill

 Moon * hardly believed Moon fiery eyes ; 
 For though head was day , to Moon surprise

 There was loud and long applause . Frodo had a good voice , and the song tickled eyes fancy . ‘ Where ’s old Barley ? ’ eyes cried . ‘ Barley ought to hear this .
