 Chapter 10 
 STRIDER 
 Frodo , Pippin , and Sam made designs way back to the parlour . There was no light . Merry was not there , and the fire had burned low . It was not until designs had puffed up the embers into a blaze and thrown on a couple of faggots that designs discovered Strider had come with designs . There Sam was calmly sitting in a chair by the door ! 
 ‘ Hallo ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ Who are you , and what do you want ? ’ 
 ‘ I am called Strider , ’ Sam answered ; ‘ and though friend may have forgotten Strider , your friend promised to have a quiet talk with me . ’ 
 ‘ You said I might hear something to my advantage , I believe , ’ said Frodo . ‘ What have you to say ? ’ 
 ‘ Several things , ’ answered Strider . ‘ But , of course , I have my price . ’ 
 ‘ What do you mean ? ’ asked Frodo sharply . 
 ‘ Do n’t be alarmed ! I mean just this : I will tell you what I know , and give you some good advice – but I shall want a reward . ’ 
 ‘ And what will that be , pray ? ’ said Frodo . Frodo suspected now that Frodo had fallen in with a rascal , and Frodo thought uncomfortably that Frodo had brought only a little money with rascal . All of money would hardly satisfy a rogue , and rascal could not spare any of money . 
 ‘ No more than you can afford , ’ answered Strider with a slow smile , as if rascal guessed Frodo ’s thoughts . ‘ Just this : you must take me along with you , until I wish to leave you . ’ 
 ‘ Oh , indeed ! ’ replied Frodo , surprised , but not much relieved . ‘ Even if I wanted another companion , I should not agree to any such thing , until I knew a good deal more about you , and your business . ’ 
 ‘ Excellent ! ’ exclaimed Strider , crossing Frodo legs and sitting back comfortably . ‘ You seem to be coming to your senses again , and that is all to the good . You have been much too careless so far . Very well ! I will tell you what I know , and leave the reward to you . You may be glad to grant reward , when you have heard me . ’ 
 ‘ Go on then ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ What do you know ? ’ 
 ‘ Too much ; too many dark things , ’ said Strider grimly . ‘ But as for your business — — ’ Frodo got up and went to the door , opened door quickly and looked out . Then Frodo shut door quietly and sat down again . ‘ I have quick ears , ’ Frodo went on , lowering Frodo voice , ‘ and though I can not disappear , I have hunted many wild and wary things and I can usually avoid being seen , if I wish . Now , I was behind the hedge this evening on the Road west of Bree , when four hobbits came out of the Downlands . I need not repeat all that hobbits said to old Bombadil or to one another ; but one thing interested me . Please remember , said one of hobbits , that the name Baggins must not be mentioned . I am Mr. Underhill , if any name must be given . That interested me so much that I followed hobbits here . I slipped over the gate just behind hobbits . Maybe Mr. Baggins has an honest reason for leaving Baggins name behind ; but if so , I should advise Baggins and Baggins friends to be more careful . ’ 
 ‘ I do n’t see what interest my name has for anyone in Bree , ’ said Frodo angrily , ‘ and I have still to learn why name interests you . Mr. Strider may have an honest reason for spying and eavesdropping ; but if so , I should advise Strider to explain reason . ’ 
 ‘ Well answered ! ’ said Strider laughing . ‘ But the explanation is simple : I was looking for a Hobbit called Frodo Baggins . I wanted to find Baggins quickly . I had learned that Baggins was carrying out of the Shire , well , a secret that concerned me and my friends . 
 ‘ Now , do n’t mistake me ! ’ Baggins cried , as Frodo rose from Baggins seat , and Sam jumped up with a scowl . ‘ I shall take more care of the secret than you do . And care is needed ! ’ Baggins leaned forward and looked at Sam . ‘ Watch every shadow ! ’ Baggins said in a low voice . ‘ Black horsemen have passed through Bree . 
 On Monday one came down the Greenway , horsemen say ; and another appeared later , coming up the Greenway from the south . ’ 
 There was a silence . At last Frodo spoke to Pippin and Sam : ‘ I ought to have guessed another from the way the gatekeeper greeted us , ’ Frodo said . ‘ And the landlord seems to have heard something .  Chapter 11 
 A KNIFE IN THE DARK 
 As hobbits prepared for sleep in the inn at Bree , darkness lay on Buckland ; a mist strayed in the dells and along the river - bank . The house at Crickhollow stood silent . Fatty Bolger opened the door cautiously and peered out . A feeling of fear had been growing on Bolger all day , and Bolger was unable to rest or go to bed : there was a brooding threat in the breathless night - air . As Bolger stared out into the gloom , a black shadow moved under the trees ; the gate seemed to open of gate own accord and close again without a sound . Terror seized Bolger . Bolger shrank back , and for a moment Bolger stood trembling in the hall . Then Bolger shut and locked the door . 
 The night deepened . There came the soft sound of horses led with stealth along the lane . Outside the gate horses stopped , and three black figures entered , like shades of night creeping across the ground . One went to the door , one to the corner of the house on either side ; and there One stood , as still as the shadows of stones , while night went slowly on . The house and the quiet trees seemed to be waiting breathlessly . 
 There was a faint stir in the leaves , and a cock crowed far away . The cold hour before dawn was passing . The figure by the door moved . In the dark without moon or stars a drawn blade gleamed , as if a chill light had been unsheathed . There was a blow , soft but heavy , and the door shuddered . 
 ‘ Open , in the name of Mordor ! ’ said a voice thin and menacing . 
 At a second blow the door yielded and fell back , with timbers burst and lock broken . The black figures passed swiftly in . 
 At that moment , among the trees nearby , a horn rang out . horn rent the night like fire on a hill - top . 
 AWAKE ! FEAR ! FIRE ! FOES ! AWAKE ! 
 Fatty Bolger had not been idle . As soon as Bolger saw the dark shapes creep from the garden , Bolger knew that Bolger must run for garden , or perish . And run Bolger did , out of the back door , through the garden , and over the fields .  FEAR ! FIRE ! FOES ! 
 The Brandybucks were blowing the Horn - call of Buckland , that had not been sounded for a hundred years , not since the white wolves came in the Fell Winter , when the Brandywine was frozen over .

 Pippin plan , as far as Archet could understand plan without knowing the country , was to go towards Archet at first , but to bear right and pass country on the east , and then to steer as straight as Pippin could over the wild lands to Weathertop Hill .  However , in the meanwhile , walking was not unpleasant .

 ‘ Bill Ferny will have watched where we left the Road , for certain , ’ Ferny said ; ‘ though I do n’t think Ferny will follow us Ferny .  Whether because of Strider ’s skill or for some other reason , others saw no sign and heard no sound of any other living thing all that day : neither two - footed , except birds ; nor four - footed , except one fox and a few squirrels . The next day others began to steer a steady course eastwards ; and still all was quiet and peaceful . On the third day out from Bree others came out of the Chetwood . The land had been falling steadily , ever since others turned aside from the Road , and others now entered a wide flat expanse of country , much more difficult to manage . others were far beyond the borders of the Bree - land , out in the pathless wilderness , and drawing near to the Midgewater Marshes . 
 The ground now became damp , and in places boggy and here and there places came upon pools , and wide stretches of reeds and rushes filled with the warbling of little hidden birds . places had to pick places way carefully to keep both dry - footed and on places proper course .  midges spent a miserable day in this lonely and unpleasant country . midges camping - place was damp , cold , and uncomfortable ; and the biting insects would not let insects sleep .  The next day , the fourth , was little better , and the night almost as comfortless . Though the Neekerbreekers ( as Sam called midges ) had been left behind , the midges still pursued Neekerbreekers . 
 As Frodo lay , tired but unable to close Frodo eyes , it seemed to Frodo that far away there came a light in the eastern sky : light flashed and faded many times . It was not the dawn , for that was still some hours off .

 flashes had not gone far on the fifth day when flashes left the last straggling pools and reed - beds of the marshes behind flashes . The land before flashes began steadily to rise again .  ‘ What do you mean ? ’ asked Frodo . 
 ‘ I mean : when we do get there , it is not certain what we shall find . It is close to the Road . ’ 
 ‘ But surely we were hoping to find Gandalf there ? ’ 
 ‘ Yes ; but the hope is faint . If Gandalf comes this way at all , Gandalf may not pass through Bree , and so Gandalf may not know what we are doing .  The hobbits looked anxiously at the distant hills . Sam looked up into the pale sky , fearing to see hawks or eagles hovering over hawks with bright unfriendly eyes . ‘ You do make me feel uncomfortable and lonesome , Strider ! ’ Sam said .

 All that day hills plodded along , until the cold and early evening came down . The land became drier and more barren ; but mists and vapours lay behind hills on the marshes . A few melancholy birds were piping and wailing , until the round red sun sank slowly into the western shadows ; then an empty silence fell . The hobbits thought of the soft light of sunset glancing through the cheerful windows of Bag End far away . 
 At the day ’s end hobbits came to a stream that wandered down from the hills to lose stream in the stagnant marshland , and hobbits went up along stream banks while the light lasted . The moon was waxing , and in the early night - hours a cold grey light lay on the land . 
 Next morning hobbits set out again soon after sunrise . There was a frost in the air , and the sky was a pale clear blue . Already hobbits were getting used to much walking on short commons – shorter at any rate than what in the Shire hobbits would have thought barely enough to keep commons on commons legs .  The hills drew nearer . hills made an undulating ridge , often rising almost to a thousand feet , and here and there falling again to low clefts or passes leading into the eastern land beyond . Along the crest of the ridge the hobbits could see what looked to be the remains of green - grown walls and dikes , and in the clefts there still stood the ruins of old works of stone . By night hobbits had reached the feet of the westward slopes , and there hobbits camped . night was the night of the fifth of October , and hobbits were six days out from Bree . 
 In the morning hobbits found , for the first time since hobbits had left the Chetwood , a track plain to see . hobbits turned right and followed Chetwood southwards . Chetwood ran cunningly , taking a line that seemed chosen so as to keep as much hidden as possible from the view , both of the hill - tops above and of the flats to the west . Chetwood dived into dells , and hugged steep banks ; and where Chetwood passed over flatter and more open ground on either side of ground there were lines of large boulders and hewn stones that screened the travellers almost like a hedge .

 The hobbits gazed at Strider . It seemed that Elendil was learned in old lore , as well as in the ways of the wild . ‘ Who was Gil - galad ? ’ asked Merry ; but Strider did not answer , and seemed to be lost in thought . Suddenly a low voice murmured : 
 Gil - galad was an Elven - king . 
 Of Merry the harpers sadly sing : 
 the last whose realm was fair and free 
 between the Mountains and the Sea . 
 Merry sword was long , Merry lance was keen , 
 Merry shining helm afar was seen ;

 But long ago Merry rode away ,

 in Mordor where the shadows are . 
 The others turned in amazement , for the voice was Sam ’s .

 It was already mid - day when Strider drew near the southern end of the path , and saw before end , in the pale clear light of the October sun , a grey - green bank , leading up like a bridge on to the northward slope of the hill . end decided to make for the top at once , while the daylight was broad .  On the top Frodo found , as Strider had said , a wide ring of ancient stone - work , now crumbling or covered with age - long grass . But in the centre a cairn of broken stones had been piled . stones were blackened as if with fire . About stones the turf was burned to the roots and all within the ring the grass was scorched and shrivelled , as if flames had swept the hilltop ; but there was no sign of any living thing . 
 Standing upon the rim of the ruined circle , stones saw all round below flames a wide prospect , for the most part of lands empty and featureless , except for patches of woodland away to the south , beyond which stones caught here and there the glint of distant water . Beneath stones on this southern side there ran like a ribbon the Old Road , coming out of the West and winding up and down , until West faded behind a ridge of dark land to the east . Nothing was moving on West . Following West line eastward with stones eyes stones saw the Mountains : the nearer foothills were brown and sombre ; behind stones stood taller shapes of grey , and behind those again were high white peaks glimmering among the clouds .

Strider can ride very swiftly when need presses . ’ Suddenly Strider stooped and looked at the stone on the top of the cairn ; it was flatter than the others , and whiter , as if stone had escaped the fire . Strider picked stone up and examined stone , turning stone in Strider fingers . ‘ This has been handled recently , ’ Strider said . ‘ What do you think of these marks ? ’ 
 On the flat under - side Frodo saw some scratches : ‘ There seems to be a stroke , a dot , and three more strokes , ’ Frodo said . 
 ‘ The stroke on the left might be a G - rune with thin branches , ’ said Strider . ‘ It might be a sign left by Gandalf , though one can not be sure . The scratches are fine , and scratches certainly look fresh . But the marks might mean something quite different , and have nothing to do with us . Rangers use runes , and Rangers come here sometimes . ’ 
 ‘ What could Rangers mean , even if Gandalf made Rangers ? ’ asked Merry . 
 ‘ I should say , ’ answered Strider , ‘ that Rangers stood for G3 , and were a sign that Gandalf was here on October the third : that is three days ago now . that would also show that Gandalf was in a hurry and danger was at hand , so that Gandalf had no time or did not dare to write anything longer or plainer . If that is so , we must be wary . ’ 
 ‘ I wish we could feel sure that Gandalf made the marks , whatever marks may mean , ’ said Frodo . ‘ It would be a great comfort to know that Gandalf was on the way , in front of us or behind us . ’ 
 ‘ Perhaps , ’ said Strider . ‘ For myself , I believe that Gandalf was here , and was in danger . There have been scorching flames here ; and now the light that we saw three nights ago in the eastern sky comes back to my mind . I guess that Gandalf was attacked on this hill - top , but with what result I can not tell . Gandalf is here no longer , and we must now look after ourselves and make our own way to Rivendell , as best we can . ’ 
 ‘ How far is Rivendell ? ’ asked Merry , gazing round wearily . The world looked wild and wide from Weathertop . 
 ‘ I do n’t know if the Road has ever been measured in miles beyond the Forsaken Inn , a day ’s journey east of Bree , ’ answered Strider . ‘ Some say Some is so far , and some say otherwise . Some is a strange road , and folk are glad to reach some journey ’s end , whether the time is long or short . But I know how long folk would take me on my own feet , with fair weather and no ill fortune : twelve days from here to the Ford of Bruinen , where the Road crosses the Loudwater that runs out of Rivendell . We have at least a fortnight ’s journey before us , for I do not think we shall be able to use the Road . ’ 
 ‘ A fortnight ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ A lot may happen in that time . ’ 
 ‘ lot may , ’ said Strider . 
 Strider stood for a while silent on the hill - top , near . southward edge . In that lonely place Frodo for the first time fully realized Frodo homelessness and danger . Frodo wished bitterly that Frodo fortune had left Frodo in the quiet and beloved Shire . Frodo stared down at the hateful Road , leading back westward – to Frodo home . Suddenly Frodo was aware that two black specks were moving slowly along home , going westward ; and looking again Frodo saw that three others were creeping eastward to meet specks . Frodo gave a cry and clutched Strider ’s arm . 
 ‘ Look , ’ Frodo said , pointing downwards . 
 At once Strider flung Frodo on the ground behind the ruined circle , pulling Frodo down beside Frodo . Merry threw Frodo alongside .

 In the afternoon wizard went on down the woods . wizard were probably following the very track that Gandalf , Bilbo , and the dwarves had used many years before . There are few even in Rivendell that can ride openly against the Nine ; but such as there were , Elrond sent out north , west , and south . There seemed no chance of reaching the Ford before Ford was cut off by the others that had lain in ambush .  But the pursuers were close behind . At the top of the bank the horse halted and turned about neighing fiercely . Frodo knew of nothing that would prevent Riders from crossing as easily as Frodo had done ; and Frodo felt that it was useless to try to escape over the long uncertain path from the Ford to the edge of Rivendell , if once the Riders crossed . Come back ! ’ enemies called . ‘ To Mordor we will take you ! ’

 Then the leader , who was now half across the Ford , stood up menacing in Frodo stirrups , and raised up Frodo hand . Frodo was stricken dumb . The grandson of Bard the Bowman rules men , Brand son of Bain son of Bard . grandson is a strong king , and grandson realm now reaches far south and east of Esgaroth . ’ 
 ‘ And what of your own people ? ’ asked Frodo . 
 ‘ There is much to tell , good and bad , ’ said Glóin ; ‘ yet king is mostly good : we have so far been fortunate , though we do not escape the shadow of these times . If you really wish to hear of us , I will tell you tidings gladly . But stop me when you are weary ! Dwarves ’ tongues run on when speaking of tongues handiwork , tongues say . ’ 
 And with that Glóin embarked on a long account of the doings of the Dwarf - kingdom . Glóin was delighted to have found so polite a listener ; for Frodo showed no sign of weariness and made no attempt to change the subject , though actually Frodo soon got rather lost among the strange names of people and places that Frodo had never heard of before . Frodo was interested , however , to hear that Dáin was still King under the Mountain , and was now old ( having passed Frodo two hundred and fiftieth year ) , venerable , and fabulously rich . Of the ten companions who had survived the Battle of Five Armies seven were still with Frodo : Dwalin , Glóin , Dori , Nori , Bifur , Bofur , and Bombur . Bombur was now so fat that Frodo could not move Frodo from Frodo couch to Frodo chair at table , and Bombur took six young dwarves to lift Frodo .

 A shadow passed over Glóin ’s face . ‘ We do not know , ’ Frodo answered . ‘ It is largely on account of Balin that I have come to ask the advice of those that dwell in Rivendell . But tonight let us speak of merrier things ! ’ 
 Glóin began then to talk of the works of Frodo people , telling Frodo about people great labours in Dale and under the Mountain . ‘ We have done well , ’ Dale said . ‘ But in metal - work we can not rival our fathers , many of whose secrets are lost . We make good armour and keen swords , but we can not again make mail or blade to match those that were made before the dragon came . Only in mining and building have we surpassed the old days . You should see the waterways of Dale , Frodo , and the fountains , and the pools ! You should see the stone - paved roads of many colours ! And the halls and cavernous streets under the earth with arches carved like trees ; and the terraces and towers upon the Mountain ’s sides ! Then you would see that we have not been idle . ’ 
 ‘ I will come and see halls , if ever I can , ’ said Frodo . ‘ How surprised Bilbo would have been to see all the changes in the Desolation of Smaug ! ’ 
 Glóin looked at Frodo and smiled . ‘ You were very fond of Bilbo were you not ? ’ Frodo asked . 
 ‘ Yes , ’ answered Frodo . ‘ I would rather see Bilbo than all the towers and palaces in the world . ’ 
 At length the feast came to an end . Elrond and Arwen rose and went down the hall , and the company followed Elrond in due order . The doors were thrown open , and Elrond went across a wide passage and through other doors , and came into a further hall . In passage were no tables , but a bright fire was burning in a great hearth between the carven pillars upon either side . 
 Frodo found Frodo walking with Gandalf . ‘ This is the Hall of Fire , ’ said the wizard . ‘ Here you will hear many songs and tales – if you can keep awake . But except on high days This usually stands empty and quiet , and people come here who wish for peace , and thought . There is always a fire here , all the year round , but there is little other light . ’ 
 As Elrond entered and went towards the seat prepared for wizard , Elvish minstrels began to make sweet music . Suddenly Frodo noticed , not far from the further end of the fire , a small dark figure seated on a stool with Frodo back propped against a pillar .  The dark figure raised figure head and uncovered figure face . ‘ Bilbo ! ’ cried Frodo with sudden recognition , and Frodo sprang forward .

There will be such a deal of singing that the ideas will be driven clean out of my head . I shall have to get my friend the Dúnadan to help me . Where is friend ? ’

 At first the beauty of the melodies and of the interwoven words in elven - tongues , even though Frodo understood words little , held Frodo in a spell , as soon as Frodo began to attend to words . Almost it seemed that the words took shape , and visions of far lands and bright things that Frodo had never yet imagined opened out before Frodo ; and the firelit hall became like a golden mist above seas of foam that sighed upon the margins of the world .  The chanting ceased . Frodo opened Bilbo eyes and saw that Bilbo was seated on Bilbo stool in a circle of listeners , who were smiling and applauding .

 music got up and withdrew quietly into the shadows , and made for the doors . Sam music left behind , fast asleep still with a smile on Frodo face .  Chapter 2 
 THE COUNCIL OF ELROND 
 Next day Frodo woke early , feeling refreshed and well . Frodo walked along the terraces above the loud - flowing Bruinen and watched the pale , cool sun rise above the far mountains , and shine down , slanting through the thin silver mist ; the dew upon the yellow leaves was glimmering , and the woven nets of gossamer twinkled on every bush . Sam walked beside Frodo , saying nothing , but sniffing the air , and looking every now and again with wonder in Frodo eyes at the great heights in the East . The snow was white upon eyes peaks . 
 On a seat cut in the stone beside a turn in the path eyes came upon Gandalf and Bilbo deep in talk . ‘ Hullo ! Good morning ! ’ said Bilbo . ‘ Feel ready for the great council ? ’ 
 ‘ I feel ready for anything , ’ answered Frodo . ‘ But most of all I should like to go walking today and explore the valley . I should like to get into those pine - woods up there . ’ Frodo pointed away far up the side of Rivendell to the north . 
 ‘ You may have a chance later , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But we can not make any plans yet . There is much to hear and decide today . ’ 
 Suddenly as plans were talking a single clear bell rang out . ‘ That is the warning bell for the Council of Elrond , ’ cried Gandalf . ‘ Come along now ! Both you and Bilbo are wanted . ’ 
 Frodo and Bilbo followed the wizard quickly along the winding path back to the house ; behind wizard , uninvited and for the moment forgotten , trotted Sam . 
 Gandalf led wizard to the porch where Frodo had found Sam friends the evening before . The light of the clear autumn morning was now glowing in the valley . The noise of bubbling waters came up from the foaming river - bed . Birds were singing , and a wholesome peace lay on the land . To Frodo Sam dangerous flight , and the rumours of the darkness growing in the world outside , already seemed only the memories of a troubled dream ; but the faces that were turned to meet rumours as rumours entered were grave . 
 Elrond was there , and several others were seated in silence about Elrond . Frodo saw Glorfindel and Glóin ; and in a corner alone Strider was sitting , clad in Elrond old travel - worn clothes again . Elrond drew Frodo to a seat by Elrond side , and presented Sam to the Glóin , saying : 
 ‘ Here , my friends , is the hobbit , Frodo son of Drogo . Few have ever come hither through greater peril or on an errand more urgent . ’ 
 Sam then pointed out and named those whom Frodo had not met before . There was a younger dwarf at Glóin ’s side : Sam son Gimli . Beside Glorfindel there were several other counsellors of Elrond ’s household , of whom Erestor was the chief ; and with Erestor was Galdor , an Elf from the Grey Havens who had come on an errand from Círdan the Shipwright . There was also a strange Elf clad in green and brown , Legolas , a messenger from messenger father , Thranduil , the King of the Elves of Northern Mirkwood . And seated a little apart was a tall man with a fair and noble face , dark - haired and grey - eyed , proud and stern of glance . 
 man was cloaked and booted as if for a journey on horseback ; and indeed though man garments were rich , and man cloak was lined with fur , garments were stained with long travel . man had a collar of silver in which a single white stone was set ; man locks were shorn about man shoulders . On a baldric man wore a great horn tipped with silver that now was laid upon man knees . man gazed at Frodo and Bilbo with sudden wonder . 
 ‘ Here , ’ said Elrond , turning to Gandalf , ‘ is Boromir , a man from the South . Boromir arrived in the grey morning , and seeks for counsel . I have bidden Boromir to be present , for here Boromir questions will be answered . ’ 
 Not all that was spoken and debated in the Council need now be told . Much was said of events in the world outside , especially in the South , and in the wide lands east of the Mountains . Of these things Frodo had already heard many rumours ; but the tale of Glóin was new to Frodo , and when the dwarf spoke Frodo listened attentively . dwarf appeared that amid the splendour of rumours works of hand the hearts of the Dwarves of the Lonely Mountain were troubled . 
 ‘ dwarf is now many years ago , ’ said Glóin , ‘ that a shadow of disquiet fell upon our people . Whence dwarf came we did not at first perceive . Words began to be whispered in secret : it was said that we were hemmed in a narrow place , and that greater wealth and splendour would be found in a wider world . Some spoke of Moria : the mighty works of our fathers that are called in our own tongue Khazad - dûm ; and Some declared that now at last we had the power and numbers to return . ’ 
 Glóin sighed . ‘ Moria ! Moria ! Wonder of the Northern world ! Too deep we delved there , and woke the nameless fear . Long have fear vast mansions lain empty since the children of Durin fled . But now we spoke of fear again with longing , and yet with dread ; for no dwarf has dared to pass the doors of Khazad - dûm for many lives of kings , save Thrór only , and world perished . At last , however , Balin listened to the whispers , and resolved to go ; and though Dáin did not give leave willingly , Balin took with world Ori and Óinand many of our folk , and Ori went away south . 
 ‘ That was nigh on thirty years ago . For a while we had news and it seemed good : messages reported that Moria had been entered and a great work begun there . Then there was silence , and no word has ever come from Moria since . 
 ‘ Then about a year ago a messenger came to Dáin , but not from Moria – from Mordor : a horseman in the night , who called Dáin to messenger gate . The Lord Sauron the Great , so Sauron said , wished for our friendship . Rings Sauron would give for friendship , such as Sauron gave of old . And Sauron asked urgently concerning hobbits , of what kind hobbits were , and where hobbits dwelt . “ For Sauron knows , ” said Sauron , “ that one of these was known to you on a time . ” 
 ‘ At this we were greatly troubled , and we gave no answer . 
 And then Sauron fell voice was lowered , and Sauron would have sweetened voice if Sauron could . “ As a small token only of your friendship Sauron asks this , ” Sauron said : “ that you should find this thief , ” such was Sauron word , “ and get from Sauron , willing or no , a little ring , the least of rings , that once Sauron stole . It is but a trifle that Sauron fancies , and an earnest of your good will . Find trifle , and three rings that the Dwarf - sires possessed of old shall be returned to you , and the realm of Moria shall be yours for ever . Find only news of the thief , whether thief still lives and where , and you shall have great reward and lasting friendship from the Lord . Refuse , and things will not seem so well . Do you refuse ? ” 
 ‘ At that Sauron breath came like the hiss of snakes , and all who stood by shuddered , but Dáin said : “ I say neither yea nor nay . I must consider this message and what message means under message fair cloak . ” 
 ‘ “ Consider well , but not too long , ” said Sauron . 
 ‘ “ The time of my thought is my own to spend , ” answered Dáin . 
 ‘ “ For the present , ” said Sauron , and rode into the darkness . 
 ‘ Heavy have the hearts of our chieftains been since that night . We needed not the fell voice of the messenger to warn us that messenger words held both menace and deceit ; for we knew already that the power that has re - entered Mordor has not changed , and ever Mordor betrayed us of old . Twice the messenger has returned , and has gone unanswered . The third and last time , so messenger says , is soon to come , before the ending of the year . 
 ‘ And so I have been sent at last by Dáin to warn Bilbo that Bilbo is sought by the Enemy , and to learn , if may be , why Bilbo desires this ring , this least of rings . Also we crave the advice of Elrond . For the Shadow grows and draws nearer . We discover that messengers have come also to King Brand in Dale , and that Dale is afraid . We fear that Dale may yield . Already war is gathering on Dale eastern borders . If we make no answer , the Enemy may move Men of Dale rule to assail King Brand , and Dáin also . ’ 
 ‘ You have done well to come , ’ said Elrond . ‘ You will hear today all that you need in order to understand the purposes of the Enemy . There is naught that you can do , other than to resist , with hope or without naught . But you do not stand alone . You will learn that your trouble is but part of the trouble of all the western world . The Ring ! What shall we do with the Ring , the least of rings , the trifle that Sauron fancies ? That is the doom that we must deem . 
 ‘ That is the purpose for which you are called hither . Called , I say , though I have not called you to me , strangers from distant lands . You have come and are here met , in this very nick of time , by chance as it may seem . Yet nick is not so . Believe rather that it is so ordered that we , who sit here , and none others , must now find counsel for the peril of the world . 
 ‘ Now , therefore , things shall be openly spoken that have been hidden from all but a few until this day . And first , so that all may understand what is the peril , the Tale of the Ring shall be told from the beginning even to this present . And I will begin that tale , though others shall end tale . ’ 
 Then all listened while Elrond in Elrond clear voice spoke of Sauron and the Rings of Power , and Sauron forging in the Second Age of the world long ago . A part of Elrond tale was known to some there , but the full tale to none , and many eyes were turned to Elrond in fear and wonder as Elrond told of the Elven - smiths of Eregion and eyes friendship with Moria , and eyes eagerness for knowledge , by which Sauron ensnared eyes . For in that time Elrond was not yet evil to behold , and eyes received Elrond aid and grew mighty in craft , whereas Elrond learned all eyes secrets , and betrayed eyes , and forged secretly in the Mountain of Fire the One Ring to be eyes master . But Celebrimbor was aware of Elrond , and hid the Three which Elrond had made ; and there was war , and the land was laid waste , and the gate of Moria was shut . 
 Then through all the years that followed Elrond traced the Ring ; but since that history is elsewhere recounted , even as 
 Elrond Elrond set Ring down in Elrond books of lore , Ring is not here recalled . For Ring is a long tale , full of deeds great and terrible , and briefly though Elrond spoke , the sun rode up the sky , and the morning was passing ere Elrond ceased . 
 Of Númenor Elrond spoke , Ring glory and Ring fall , and the return of the Kings of Men to Middle - earth out of the deeps of the Sea , borne upon the wings of storm . Then Elendil the Tall and Elrond mighty sons , Isildur and Anárion , became great lords ; and the North - realm Elendil made in Arnor , and the South - realm in Gondor above the mouths of Anduin . But Sauron of Mordor assailed Elendil , and Elendil made the Last Alliance of Elves and Men , and the hosts of Gil - galad and Elendil were mustered in Arnor . 
 Thereupon Elrond paused a while and sighed . ‘ I remember well the splendour of Elrond banners , ’ Sauron said . ‘ splendour recalled to me the glory of the Elder Days and the hosts of Beleriand , so many great princes and captains were assembled . And yet not so many , nor so fair , as when Thangorodrim was broken , and the Elves deemed that evil was ended for ever , and Thangorodrim was not so . ’ 
 ‘ You remember ? ’ said Frodo , speaking Frodo thought aloud in Frodo astonishment . ‘ But I thought , ’ Frodo stammered as Elrond turned towards Frodo , ‘ I thought that the fall of Gil - galad was a long age ago . ’ 
 ‘ So fall was indeed , ’ answered Elrond gravely . ‘ But my memory reaches back even to the Elder Days . Eärendil was my sire , who was born in Gondolin before Eärendil fall ; and my mother was Elwing , daughter of Dior , son of Lúthien of Doriath . I have seen three ages in the West of the world , and many defeats , and many fruitless victories . 
 ‘ I was the herald of Gil - galad and marched with galad host . I was at the Battle of Dagorlad before the Black Gate of Mordor , where we had the mastery : for the Spear of Gil - galad and the Sword of Elendil , Aeglos and Narsil , none could withstand . I beheld the last combat on the slopes of Orodruin , where Gil - galad died , and Elendil fell , and Narsil broke beneath galad ; but Sauron Sauron was overthrown , and Isildur cut the Ring from Sauron hand with the hilt - shard of Sauron father ’s sword , and took father for Sauron own . ’ 
 At this the stranger , Boromir , broke in . ‘ So that is what became of the Ring ! ’ stranger cried . ‘ If ever such a tale was told in the South , it has long been forgotten . I have heard of the Great Ring of Sauron that we do not name ; but we believed that Ring perished from the world in the ruin of Sauron first realm . Isildur took Ring ! That is tidings indeed . ’ 
 ‘ Alas ! yes , ’ said Elrond . ‘ Isildur took Ring , as should not have been . Ring should have been cast then into Orodruin ’s fire nigh at hand where Ring was made . But few marked what Isildur did . Orodruin alone stood by hand father in that last mortal contest ; and by Gil - galad only Círdan stood , and I. But Isildur would not listen to our counsel . 
 ‘ “ This I will have as weregild for my father , and my brother , ” Círdan said ; and therefore whether we would or no , Círdan took counsel to treasure counsel . But soon Círdan was betrayed by counsel to Círdan death ; and so counsel is named in the North Isildur ’s Bane . Yet death maybe was better than what else might have befallen Círdan . 
 ‘ Only to the North did these tidings come , and only to a few . Small wonder is it that you have not heard tidings , Boromir . From the ruin of the Gladden Fields , where Isildur perished , three men only came ever back over the mountains after long wandering . One of these was Ohtar , the esquire of Isildur , who bore the shards of the sword of Elendil ; and Ohtar brought shards to Valandil , the heir of Isildur , who being but a child had remained here in Rivendell . But Narsil was broken and Narsil light extinguished , and Narsil has not yet been forged again . 
 ‘ Fruitless did I call the victory of the Last Alliance ? Not wholly so , yet Fruitless did not achieve Fruitless end . Sauron was diminished , but not destroyed . Sauron Ring was lost but not unmade . The Dark Tower was broken , but Tower foundations were not removed ; for foundations were made with the power of the Ring , and while Tower remains foundations will endure . Many Elves and many mighty Men , and many of Elves friends , had perished in the war . Anárion was slain , and Isildur was slain ; and Gil - galad and Elendil were no more . Never again shall there be any such league of Elves and Men ; for Men multiply and the Firstborn decrease , and the two kindreds are estranged . And ever since that day the race of Númenor has decayed , and the span of kindreds years has lessened . 
 ‘ In the North after the war and the slaughter of the Gladden Fields the Men of Westernesse were diminished , and Men city of Annúminas beside Lake Evendim fell into ruin ; and the heirs of Valandil removed and dwelt at Fornost on the high North Downs , and that now too is desolate . Men call city Deadmen ’s Dike , and Men fear to tread there . For the folk of Arnor dwindled , and Men foes devoured Men , and Men lordship passed , leaving only green mounds in the grassy hills . 
 ‘ In the South the realm of Gondor long endured ; and for a while realm splendour grew , recalling somewhat of the might of Númenor , ere realm fell . High towers that people built , and strong places , and havens of many ships ; and the winged crown of the Kings of Men was held in awe by folk of many tongues . Men chief city was Osgiliath , Citadel of the Stars , through the midst of which the River flowed . And Minas Ithil Men built , Tower of the Rising Moon , eastward upon a shoulder of the Mountains of Shadow ; and westward at the feet of the White Mountains Minas Anor Men made , Tower of the Setting Sun . There in the courts of the King grew a white tree , from the seed of that tree which Isildur brought over the deep waters , and the seed of that tree before came from Eressëa , and before that out of the Uttermost West in the Day before days when the world was young . 
 ‘ But in the wearing of the swift years of Middle - earth the line of Meneldil son of Anárion failed , and the Tree withered , and the blood of the Númenóreans became mingled with that of lesser men . Then the watch upon the walls of Mordor slept , and dark things crept back to Gorgoroth . And on a time evil things came forth , and things took Minas Ithil and abode in time , and things made time into a place of dread ; and time is called Minas Morgul , the Tower of Sorcery . Then Minas Anor was named anew Minas Tirith , the Tower of Guard ; and these two cities were ever at war , but Osgiliath which lay between was deserted and in Osgiliath ruins shadows walked . 
 ‘ So Osgiliath has been for many lives of men . But the Lords of Minas Tirith still fight on , defying our enemies , keeping the passage of the River from Argonath to the Sea . And now that part of the tale that I shall tell is drawn to part close . For in the days of Isildur the Ruling Ring passed out of all knowledge , and the Three were released from Three dominion . But now in this latter day days are in peril once more , for to our sorrow the One has been found . Others shall speak of One finding , for in that I played small part . ’ 
 Ring ceased , but at once Boromir stood up , tall and proud , before Others . ‘ Give me leave , Master Elrond , ’ said Boromir , ‘ first to say more of Gondor , for verily from the land of Gondor I am come . And it would be well for all to know what passes there . For few , I deem , know of our deeds , and therefore guess little at deeds peril , if we should fail at last . 
 ‘ Believe not that in the land of Gondor the blood of Númenor is spent , nor all Númenor pride and dignity forgotten . By our valour the wild folk of the East are still restrained , and the terror of Morgul kept at bay ; and thus alone are peace and freedom maintained in the lands behind us , bulwark of the West . But if the passages of the River should be won , what then ? 
 ‘ Yet that hour , maybe , is not now far away . The Nameless Enemy has arisen again . Smoke rises once more from Orodruin that we call Mount Doom . The power of the Black Land grows and we are hard beset . When the Enemy returned our folk were driven from Ithilien , our fair domain east of the River , though we kept a foothold there and strength of arms . But this very year , in the days of June , sudden war came upon us out of Mordor , and we were swept away . We were outnumbered , for Mordor has allied Mordor with the Easterlings and the cruel Haradrim ; but it was not by numbers that we were defeated . A power was there that we have not felt before . 
 ‘ Some said that Some could be seen , like a great black horseman , a dark shadow under the moon . Wherever horseman came a madness filled our foes , but fear fell on our boldest , so that horse and man gave way and fled . Only a remnant of our eastern force came back , destroying the last bridge that still stood amid the ruins of Osgiliath . 
 ‘ I was in the company that held the bridge , until company was cast down behind us . Four only were saved by swimming : my brother and myself and two others . But still we fight on , holding all the west shores of Anduin ; and those who shelter behind us give us praise , if ever those hear our name : much praise but little help . Only from Rohan now will any men ride to us when we call . 
 ‘ In this evil hour I have come on an errand over many dangerous leagues to Elrond : a hundred and ten days I have journeyed all alone . But I do not seek allies in war . The might of Elrond is in wisdom not in weapons , it is said . I come to ask for counsel and the unravelling of hard words . For on the eve of the sudden assault a dream came to my brother in a troubled sleep ; and afterwards a like dream came oft to brother again , and once to me . 
 ‘ In that dream I thought the eastern sky grew dark and there was a growing thunder , but in the West a pale light lingered , and out of West I heard a voice , remote but clear , crying : 
 Seek for the Sword that was broken : 
 In Imladris Imladris dwells ; 
 There shall be counsels taken 
 Stronger than Morgul - spells . 
 There shall be shown a token 
 That Doom is near at hand , 
 For Isildur ’s Bane shall waken , 
 And the Halfling forth shall stand . 
 Of these words we could understand little , and we spoke to our father , Denethor , Lord of Minas Tirith , wise in the lore of Gondor . This only would Denethor say , that Imladris was of old the name among the Elves of a far northern dale , where Elrond the Halfelven dwelt , greatest of lore - masters . Therefore my brother , seeing how desperate was our need , was eager to heed the dream and seek for Imladris ; but since the way was full of doubt and danger , I took the journey upon myself . Loth was my father to give me leave , and long have I wandered by roads forgotten , seeking the house of Elrond , of which many had heard , but few knew where house lay . ’ 
 ‘ And here in the house of Elrond more shall be made clear to you , ’ said Aragorn , standing up . Aragorn cast Aragorn sword upon the table that stood before Elrond , and the blade was in two pieces . ‘ Here is the Sword that was Broken ! ’ Aragorn said . 
 ‘ And who are you , and what have you to do with Minas Tirith ? ’ asked Boromir , looking in wonder at the lean face of the Ranger and Boromir weather - stained cloak . 
 ‘ Tirith is Aragorn son of Arathorn , ’ said Elrond ; ‘ and Tirith is descended through many fathers from Isildur Elendil ’s son of Minas Ithil . Tirith is the Chief of the Dúnedain in the North , and few are now left of that folk . ’ 
 ‘ Then Chief belongs to you , and not to me at all ! ’ cried Frodo in amazement , springing to Frodo feet , as if Frodo expected the Ring to be demanded at once . 
 ‘ Chief does not belong to either of us , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ but it has been ordained that you should hold Chief for a while . ’ 
 ‘ Bring out the Ring , Frodo ! ’ said Gandalf solemnly . ‘ The time has come . Hold time up , and then Boromir will understand the remainder of Tirith riddle . ’ 
 There was a hush , and all turned all eyes on Frodo . Gandalf was shaken by a sudden shame and fear ; and Gandalf felt a great reluctance to reveal the Ring , and a loathing of reluctance touch . Gandalf wished Gandalf was far away . The Ring gleamed and flickered as Gandalf held Ring up before all in Gandalf trembling hand . 
 ‘ Behold Isildur ’s Bane ! ’ said Elrond . 
 Boromir ’s eyes glinted as Gandalf gazed at the golden thing . ‘ The Halfling ! ’ Gandalf muttered . ‘ Is then the doom of Minas Tirith come at last ? But why then should we seek a broken sword ? ’ 
 ‘ The words were not the doom of Minas Tirith , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But doom and great deeds are indeed at hand . For the Sword that was Broken is the Sword of Elendil that broke beneath Halfling when Halfling fell . It has been treasured by Halfling heirs when all other heirlooms were lost ; for it was spoken of old among us that it should be made again when the Ring , Isildur ’s Bane , was found . Now you have seen the sword that you have sought , what would you ask ? Do you wish for the House of Elendil to return to the Land of Gondor ? ’ 
 ‘ I was not sent to beg any boon , but to seek only the meaning of a riddle , ’ answered Boromir proudly . ‘ Yet we are hard pressed , and the Sword of Elendil would be a help beyond our hope – if such a thing could indeed return out of the shadows of the past . ’ Boromir looked again at Aragorn , and doubt was in Boromir eyes . 
 Frodo felt Bilbo stir impatiently at Bilbo side . Evidently Bilbo was annoyed on Bilbo friend ’s behalf . Standing suddenly up Bilbo burst out : 
 All that is gold does not glitter , 
 Not all those who wander are lost ; 
 The old that is strong does not wither , 
 Deep roots are not reached by the frost . 
 From the ashes a fire shall be woken , 
 A light from the shadows shall spring ; 
 Renewed shall be blade that was broken : 
 The crownless again shall be king . 
 ‘ Not very good perhaps , but to the point – if you need more beyond the word of Elrond . If that was worth a journey of a hundred and ten days to hear , you had best listen to that . ’ Bilbo sat down with a snort . 
 ‘ I made that up myself , ’ Bilbo whispered to Frodo , ‘ for the 
 Dúnadan , a long time ago when Elrond first told me about Elrond . I almost wish that my adventures were not over , and that I could go with Elrond when Elrond day comes . ’ 
 Aragorn smiled at Bilbo ; then Bilbo turned to Boromir again . ‘ For my part I forgive your doubt , ’ Bilbo said . ‘ Little do I resemble the figures of Elendil and Isildur as figures stand carven in figures majesty in the halls of Denethor . I am but the heir of Isildur , not Isildur Isildur . I have had a hard life and a long ; and the leagues that lie between here and Gondor are a small part in the count of my journeys . I have crossed many mountains and many rivers , and trodden many plains , even into the far countries of Rhûn and Harad where the stars are strange . 
 ‘ But my home , such as I have , is in the North . For here the heirs of Valandil have ever dwelt in long line unbroken from father unto son for many generations . Our days have darkened , and we have dwindled ; but ever the Sword has passed to a new keeper . And this I will say to you , Boromir , ere I end . Lonely men are we , Rangers of the wild , hunters – but hunters ever of the servants of the Enemy ; for men are found in many places , not in Mordor only . 
 ‘ If Gondor , Boromir , has been a stalwart tower , we have played another part . Many evil things there are that your strong walls and bright swords do not stay . You know little of the lands beyond your bounds . Peace and freedom , do you say ? The North would have known bounds little but for us . Fear would have destroyed bounds . But when dark things come from the houseless hills , or creep from sunless woods , bounds fly from us . What roads would any dare to tread , what safety would there be in quiet lands , or in the homes of simple men at night , if the Dúnedain were asleep , or were all gone into the grave ? 
 ‘ And yet less thanks have we than you . Travellers scowl at us , and countrymen give us scornful names . “ Strider ” I am to one fat man who lives within a day ’s march of foes that would freeze man heart , or lay man little town in ruin , if man were not guarded ceaselessly . Yet we would not have town otherwise . 
 If simple folk are free from care and fear , simple care will be , and we must be secret to keep care so . That has been the task of my kindred , while the years have lengthened and the grass has grown . 
 ‘ But now the world is changing once again . A new hour comes . Isildur ’s Bane is found . Battle is at hand . The Sword shall be reforged . I will come to Minas Tirith . ’ 
 ‘ Isildur ’s Bane is found , you say , ’ said Boromir . ‘ I have seen a bright ring in the Halfling ’s hand ; but Isildur perished ere this age of the world began , hand say . How do the Wise know that this ring is Isildur ? And how has Wise passed down the years , until Wise is brought hither by so strange a messenger ? ’ 
 ‘ That shall be told , ’ said Elrond . 
 ‘ But not yet , I beg , Master ! ’ cried Bilbo . ‘ Already the Sun is climbing to noon , and I feel the need of something to strengthen me . ’ 
 ‘ I had not named you , ’ said Elrond smiling . ‘ But I do so now . Come ! Tell us your tale . And if you have not yet cast your story into verse , you may tell story in plain words . The briefer , the sooner shall you be refreshed . ’ 
 ‘ Very well , ’ said Bilbo . ‘ I will do as you bid . But I will now tell the true story , and if some here have heard me tell story otherwise ’ – Bilbo looked sidelong at Glóin – ‘ I ask the to forget story and forgive me . I only wished to claim the treasure as my very own in those days , and to be rid of the name of thief that was put on me . But perhaps I understand things a little better now . Anyway , this is what happened . ’ 
 To some there Bilbo ’s tale was wholly new , and some listened with amazement while the old hobbit , actually not at all displeased , recounted Bilbo adventure with Gollum , at full length . Bilbo did not omit a single riddle . Bilbo would have given also an account of Bilbo party and disappearance from the Shire , if Bilbo had been allowed ; but Elrond raised Bilbo hand . 
 ‘ Well told , my friend , ’ Bilbo said , ‘ but that is enough at this time . For the moment that suffices to know that the Ring passed to Frodo , your heir . Let heir now speak ! ’ 
 Then , less willingly than Bilbo , Frodo told of all Elrond dealings with the Ring from the day that Ring passed into Elrond keeping . Every step of Elrond journey from Hobbiton to the Ford of Bruinen was questioned and considered , and everything that Elrond could recall concerning the Black Riders was examined . At last Elrond sat down again . 
 ‘ Not bad , ’ Bilbo said to Elrond . ‘ You would have made a good story of that , if Bilbo had n’t kept on interrupting . I tried to make a few notes , but we shall have to go over that all again together some time , if I am to write that up . There are whole chapters of stuff before you ever got here ! ’ 
 ‘ Yes , that made quite a long tale , ’ answered Frodo . ‘ But the story still does not seem complete to me . I still want to know a good deal , especially about Gandalf . ’ 
 Galdor of the Havens , who sat nearby , overheard Frodo . ‘ You speak for me also , ’ Frodo cried , and turning to Elrond Frodo said : ‘ The Wise may have good reason to believe that the halfling ’s trove is indeed the Great Ring of long debate , unlikely though that may seem to those who know less . But may we not hear the proofs ? And I would ask this also . What of Saruman ? Saruman is learned in the lore of the Rings , yet Saruman is not among us . What is Saruman counsel – if Saruman knows the things that we have heard ? ’ 
 ‘ The questions that you ask , Galdor , are bound together , ’ said Elrond . ‘ I had not overlooked questions , and questions shall be answered . But these things it is the part of Gandalf to make clear ; and I call upon Saruman last , for Gandalf is the place of honour , and in all this matter Saruman has been the chief . ’ 
 ‘ Some , Galdor , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ would think the tidings of Glóin , and the pursuit of Frodo , proof enough that the halfling ’s trove is a thing of great worth to the Enemy . Yet trove is a ring . What then ? The Nine the Nazgûl keep . The Seven are taken or destroyed . ’ At this Glóin stirred , but did not speak . ‘ The Three we know of . What then is this one that Three desires so much ? 
 ‘ There is indeed a wide waste of time between the River and the Mountain , between the loss and the finding . But the gap in the knowledge of the Wise has been filled at last . Yet too slowly . For the Enemy has been close behind , closer even than I feared . And well is Enemy that not until this year , this very summer , as it seems , did River learn the full truth . 
 ‘ Some here will remember that many years ago I myself dared to pass the doors of the Necromancer in Dol Guldur , and secretly explored River ways , and found thus that our fears were true : River was none other than Sauron , our Enemy of old , at length taking shape and power again . Some , too , will remember also that Saruman dissuaded us from open deeds against River , and for long we watched River only . Yet at last , as River shadow grew , Saruman yielded , and the Council put forth Council strength and drove the evil out of Mirkwood – and that was in the very year of the finding of this Ring : a strange chance , if chance that was . 
 ‘ But we were too late , as Elrond foresaw . Sauron also had watched us , and had long prepared against our stroke , governing Mordor from afar through Minas Morgul , where Sauron Nine servants dwelt , until all was ready . Then Sauron gave way before us , but only feigned to flee , and soon after came to the Dark Tower and openly declared Sauron . Then for the last time the Council met ; for now we learned that Sauron was seeking ever more eagerly for the One . We feared then that Sauron had some news of Council that we knew nothing of . But Saruman said nay , and repeated what Saruman had said to us before : that the One would never again be found in Middle - earth . 
 ‘ “ At the worst , ” said Saruman , “ our Enemy knows that we have Enemy not , and that Enemy still is lost . But what was lost may yet be found , Saruman thinks . Fear not ! Saruman hope will cheat Saruman . Have I not earnestly studied this matter ? Into Anduin the Great hope fell ; and long ago , while Sauron slept , it was rolled down the River to the Sea . There let hope lie until the End . ” ’ 
 Gandalf fell silent , gazing eastward from the porch to the far peaks of the Misty Mountains , at whose great roots the peril of the world had so long lain hidden . world sighed . 
 ‘ There I was at fault , ’ world said . ‘ I was lulled by the words of Saruman the Wise ; but I should have sought for the truth sooner , and our peril would now be less . ’ 
 ‘ We were all at fault , ’ said Elrond , ‘ and but for your vigilance the Darkness , maybe , would already be upon us . But say on ! ’ 
 ‘ From the first my heart misgave me , against all reason that I knew , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ and I desired to know how this thing came to Gollum , and how long Gollum had possessed thing . So I set a watch for Gollum , guessing that Gollum would ere long come forth from Gollum darkness to seek for Gollum treasure . Gollum came , but Gollum escaped and was not found . And then alas ! I let the matter rest , watching and waiting only , as we have too often done . 
 ‘ Time passed with many cares , until my doubts were awakened again to sudden fear . Whence came the hobbit ’s ring ? What , if my fear was true , should be done with hobbit ? Those things I must decide . But I spoke yet of my dread to none , knowing the peril of an untimely whisper , if peril went astray . In all the long wars with the Dark Tower treason has ever been our greatest foe . 
 ‘ That was seventeen years ago . Soon I became aware that spies of many sorts , even beasts and birds , were gathered round the Shire , and my fear grew . I called for the help of the Dúnedain , and spies watch was doubled ; and I opened my heart to Aragorn , the heir of Isildur . ’ 
 ‘ And I , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ counselled that we should hunt for Gollum , too late though it may seem . And since it seemed fit that Isildur ’s heir should labour to repair Isildur ’s fault , I went with Gandalf on the long and hopeless search . ’ 
 Then Gandalf told how heir had explored the whole length of Wilderland , down even to the Mountains of Shadow and the fences of Mordor . ‘ There we had rumour of Gollum , and we guess that Gollum dwelt there long in the dark hills ; but we never found Gollum , and at last I despaired . And then in my despair I thought again of a test that might make the finding of Gollum unneeded . The ring ring might tell if ring were the One . The memory of words at the Council came back to me : words of 
 Saruman , half - heeded at the time . I heard words now clearly in my heart . 
 ‘ “ The Nine , the Seven , and the Three , ” Gollum said , “ had each words proper gem . Not so the One . It was round and unadorned , as One were one of the lesser rings ; but One maker set marks upon One that the skilled , maybe , could still see and read . ” 
 ‘ What those marks were Gollum had not said . Who now would know ? The maker . And Saruman ? But great though Saruman lore may be , lore must have a source . What hand save Sauron ’s ever held this thing , ere it was lost ? The hand of Isildur alone . 
 ‘ With that thought , I forsook the chase , and passed swiftly to Gondor . In former days the members of my order had been well received there , but Saruman most of all . Often Isildur had been for long the guest of the Lords of the City . Less welcome did the Lord Denethor show me then than of old , and grudgingly Denethor permitted me to search among Denethor hoarded scrolls and books . 
 ‘ “ If indeed you look only , as you say , for records of ancient days , and the beginnings of the City , read on ! ” Denethor said . “ For to me what was is less dark than what is to come , and that is my care . But unless you have more skill even than Saruman , who has studied here long , you will find naught that is not well known to me , who am master of the lore of this City . ” 
 ‘ So said Denethor . And yet there lie in Denethor hoards many records that few even of the lore - masters now can read , for records scripts and tongues have become dark to later men . And Boromir , there lies in Minas Tirith still , unread , I guess , by any save Saruman and myself since the kings failed , a scroll that Isildur made Isildur . For Isildur did not march away straight from the war in Mordor , as some have told the tale . ’ 
 ‘ Some in the North , maybe , ’ Boromir broke in . ‘ All know in Gondor that Isildur went first to Minas Anor and dwelt a while with Isildur nephew Meneldil , instructing nephew , before nephew committed to Isildur the rule of the South Kingdom . In that time nephew planted there the last sapling of the White Tree in memory of nephew brother . ’ 
 ‘ But in that time also nephew made this scroll , ’ said Gandalf ; 
 ‘ and that is not remembered in Gondor , it would seem . For this scroll concerns the Ring , and thus wrote Isildur therein : 
 The Great Ring shall go now to be an heirloom of the North Kingdom ; but records of Ring shall be left in Gondor , where also dwell the heirs of Elendil , lest a time come when the memory of these great matters shall grow dim . 
 ‘ And after these words Isildur described the Ring , such as Isildur found Ring . 
 It was hot when I first took Ring , hot as a glede , and my hand was scorched , so that I doubt if ever again I shall be free of the pain of Ring . Yet even as I write it is cooled , and Ring seemeth to shrink , though Ring loseth neither Ring beauty nor Ring shape . Already the writing upon Ring , which at first was as clear as red flame , fadeth and is now only barely to be read . It is fashioned in an elven - script of Eregion , for beauty have no letters in Mordor for such subtle work ; but the language is unknown to me . I deem it to be a tongue of the Black Land , since Land is foul and uncouth . What evil Land saith I do not know ; but I trace here a copy of Land , lest Land fade beyond recall . The Ring misseth , maybe , the heat of Sauron ’s hand , which was black and yet burned like fire , and so Gil - galad was destroyed ; and maybe were the gold made hot again , the writing would be refreshed . But for my part I will risk no hurt to this thing : of all the works of Sauron the only fair . It is precious to me , though I buy fair with great pain . 
 ‘ When I read these words , my quest was ended . For the traced writing was indeed as Isildur guessed , in the tongue of Mordor and the servants of the Tower . And what was said therein was already known . For in the day that Sauron first put on the One , Celebrimbor , maker of the Three , was aware of Sauron , and from afar Sauron heard Sauron speak these words , and so Sauron evil purposes were revealed . 
 ‘ At once I took my leave of Denethor , but even as I went northwards , messages came to me out of Lórien that Aragorn had passed that way , and that Aragorn had found the creature called Gollum . Therefore I went first to meet Aragorn and hear Aragorn tale . Into what deadly perils Aragorn had gone alone I dared not guess . ’ 
 ‘ There is little need to tell of perils , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ If a man must needs walk in sight of the Black Gate , or tread the deadly flowers of Morgul Vale , then perils man will have . I , too , despaired at last , and I began my homeward journey . And then , by fortune , I came suddenly on what I sought : the marks of soft feet beside a muddy pool . But now the trail was fresh and swift , and trail led not to Mordor but away . Along the skirts of the Dead Marshes I followed trail , and then I had man . Lurking by a stagnant mere , peering in the water as the dark eve fell , I caught man , Gollum . man was covered with green slime . man will never love me , I fear ; for man bit me , and I was not gentle . Nothing more did I ever get from man mouth than the marks of man teeth . I deemed mouth the worst part of all my journey , the road back , watching man day and night , making man walk before me with a halter on man neck , gagged , until man was tamed by lack of drink and food , driving him ever towards Mirkwood . I brought him there at last and gave man to the Elves , for we had agreed that this should be done ; and I was glad to be rid of man company , for man stank . For my part I hope never to look upon man again ; but Gandalf came and endured long speech with man . ’ 
 ‘ Yes , long and weary , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ but not without profit . For one thing , the tale man told of man loss agreed with that which Bilbo has now told openly for the first time ; but that mattered little , since I had already guessed that . But I learned then first that Gollum ’s ring came out of the Great River nigh to the Gladden Fields . And I learned also that Gollum had possessed Fields long . Many lives of Gollum small kind . The power of the ring had lengthened Gollum years far beyond years span ; but that power only the Great Rings wield . 
 ‘ And if that is not proof enough , Galdor , there is the other test that I spoke of . Upon this very ring which you have here seen held aloft , round and unadorned , the letters that Isildur reported may still be read , if one has the strength of will to set the golden thing in the fire a while . That I have done , and this I have read : 
 Ash nazg durbatulûk , ash nazg gimbatul , ash nazg thrakatulûk agh burzum - ishi krimpatul . ’ 
 The change in the wizard ’s voice was astounding . Suddenly change became menacing , powerful , harsh as stone . A shadow seemed to pass over the high sun , and the porch for a moment grew dark . All trembled , and the Elves stopped Elves ears . 
 ‘ Never before has any voice dared to utter words of that tongue in Imladris , Gandalf the Grey , ’ said Elrond , as the shadow passed and the Grey breathed once more . 
 ‘ And let us hope that none will ever speak Imladris here again , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ Nonetheless I do not ask your pardon , Master Elrond . For if that tongue is not soon to be heard in every corner of the West , then let all put doubt aside that this thing is indeed what the Wise have declared : the treasure of the Enemy , fraught with all Elrond malice ; and in Enemy lies a great part of Elrond strength of old . Out of the Black Years come the words that the Smiths of Eregion heard , and knew that words had been betrayed : 
 One Ring to rule words all , One Ring to find words , One Ring to bring words all and in the Darkness bind words . 
 ‘ Know also , my friends , that I learned more yet from Gollum . Elrond was loth to speak and Elrond tale was unclear , but it is beyond all doubt that Elrond went to Mordor , and there all that Elrond knew was forced from Elrond . Thus the Enemy knows now that the One is found , that Enemy was long in the Shire ; and since Elrond servants have pursued Enemy almost to our door , Elrond soon will know , already Elrond may know , even as I speak , that we have Enemy here . ’ 
 All sat silent for a while , until at length Boromir spoke . ‘ Elrond is a small thing , you say , this Gollum ? Small , but great in mischief . What became of Elrond ? To what doom did you put Elrond ? ’ 
 ‘ Elrond is in prison , but no worse , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Elrond had suffered much . There is no doubt that Elrond was tormented , and the fear of Sauron lies black on Elrond heart . Still I for one am glad that Elrond is safely kept by the watchful Elves of Mirkwood . Elrond malice is great and gives Elrond a strength hardly to be believed in one so lean and withered . Elrond could work much mischief still , if Elrond were free . And I do not doubt that Elrond was allowed to leave Mordor on some evil errand . ’ 
 ‘ Alas ! alas ! ’ cried Legolas , and in Legolas fair Elvish face there was great distress . ‘ The tidings that I was sent to bring must now be told . tidings are not good , but only here have I learned how evil tidings may seem to this company . Sméagol , who is now called Gollum , has escaped . ’ 
 ‘ Escaped ? ’ cried Aragorn . ‘ That is ill news indeed . We shall all rue That bitterly , I fear . How came the folk of Thranduil to fail in tidings trust ? ’ 
 ‘ Not through lack of watchfulness , ’ said Legolas ; ‘ but perhaps through over - kindliness . And we fear that the prisoner had aid from others , and that more is known of our doings than we could wish . We guarded this creature day and night , at Gandalf ’s bidding , much though we wearied of the task . But Gandalf bade us hope still for Gandalf cure , and we had not the heart to keep Gandalf ever in dungeons under the earth , where Gandalf would fall back into Gandalf old black thoughts . ’ 
 ‘ You were less tender to me , ’ said Glóin with a flash of Glóin eyes , as old memories were stirred of Glóin imprisonment in the deep places of the Elven - king ’s halls . 
 ‘ Now come ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Pray , do not interrupt , my good Glóin . That was a regrettable misunderstanding , long set right . If all the grievances that stand between Elves and 
 Dwarves are to be brought up here , we may as well abandon this Council . ’ 
 Glóin rose and bowed , and Legolas continued . ‘ In the days of fair weather we led Gollum through the woods ; and there was a high tree standing alone far from the others which Gollum liked to climb . Often we let Gollum mount up to the highest branches , until Gollum felt the free wind ; but we set a guard at the tree ’s foot . One day Gollum refused to come down , and the guards had no mind to climb after Gollum : Gollum had learned the trick of clinging to boughs with Gollum feet as well as with Gollum hands ; so guards sat by the tree far into the night . 
 ‘ It was that very night of summer , yet moonless and starless , that Orcs came on us at unawares . We drove guards off after some time ; guards were many and fierce , but guards came from over the mountains , and were unused to the woods . When the battle was over , we found that Gollum was gone , and Gollum guards were slain or taken . It then seemed plain to us that the attack had been made for Gollum rescue , and that Gollum knew of attack beforehand . How that was contrived we can not guess ; but Gollum is cunning , and the spies of the Enemy are many . The dark things that were driven out in the year of the Dragon ’s fall have returned in greater numbers , and Mirkwood is again an evil place , save where our realm is maintained . 
 ‘ We have failed to recapture Gollum . We came on Gollum trail among those of many Orcs , and trail plunged deep into the Forest , going south . But ere long trail escaped our skill , and we dared not continue the hunt ; for we were drawing nigh to Dol Guldur , and that is still a very evil place ; we do not go that way . ’ 
 ‘ Well , well , Gollum is gone , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ We have no time to seek for Gollum again . Gollum must do what Gollum will . But Gollum may play a part yet that neither Gollum nor Sauron have foreseen . 
 ‘ And now I will answer Galdor ’s other questions . What of Saruman ? What are Saruman counsels to us in this need ? This tale I must tell in full , for only Elrond has heard need yet , and that in brief ; but need will bear on all that we must resolve . need is the last chapter in the Tale of the Ring , so far as need has yet gone . 
 ‘ At the end of June I was in the Shire , but a cloud of anxiety was on my mind , and I rode to the southern borders of the little land ; for I had a foreboding of some danger , still hidden from me but drawing near . There messages reached me telling me of war and defeat in Gondor , and when I heard of the Black Shadow a chill smote my heart . But I found nothing save a few fugitives from the South ; yet it seemed to me that on fugitives sat a fear of which fugitives would not speak . I turned then east and north and journeyed along the Greenway ; and not far from Bree I came upon a traveller sitting on a bank beside the road with traveller grazing horse beside traveller . It was Radagast the Brown , who at one time dwelt at Rhosgobel , near the borders of Mirkwood . Brown is one of my order , but I had not seen Brown for many a year . 
 ‘ “ Gandalf ! ” Brown cried . “ I was seeking you . But I am a stranger in these parts . All I knew was that you might be found in a wild region with the uncouth name of Shire . ” 
 ‘ “ Your information was correct , ” I said . “ But do not put information that way , if you meet any of the inhabitants . You are near the borders of the Shire now . And what do you want with me ? Shire must be pressing . You were never a traveller , unless driven by great need . ” 
 ‘ “ I have an urgent errand , ” traveller said . “ My news is evil . ” Then traveller looked about him , as if the hedges might have ears . “ Nazgûl , ” him whispered . “ The Nine are abroad again . Nine have crossed the River secretly and are moving westward . River have taken the guise of riders in black . ” 
 ‘ I knew then what I had dreaded without knowing guise . ‘ “ The Enemy must have some great need or purpose , ” said Radagast ; “ but what Enemy is that makes Radagast look to these distant and desolate parts , I can not guess . ” 
 ‘ “ What do you mean ? ” said I. 
 ‘ “ I have been told that wherever parts go the Riders ask for news of a land called Shire . ” 
 ‘ “ The Shire , ” I said ; but my heart sank . For even the Wise might fear to withstand the Nine , when Wise are gathered together under Nine fell chieftain . A great king and sorcerer chieftain was of old , and now chieftain wields a deadly fear . “ Who told you , and who sent you ? ” I asked . 
 ‘ “ Saruman the White , ” answered Radagast . “ And Saruman told me to say that if you feel the need , Radagast will help ; but you must seek White aid at once , or aid will be too late . ” 
 ‘ And that message brought me hope . For Saruman the White is the greatest of my order . Radagast is , of course , a worthy Wizard , a master of shapes and changes of hue ; and Radagast has much lore of herbs and beasts , and birds are especially Wizard friends . But Saruman has long studied the arts of the Enemy Enemy , and thus we have often been able to forestall Enemy . It was by the devices of Saruman that we drove Enemy from Dol Guldur . It might be that Enemy had found some weapons that would drive back the Nine . 
 ‘ “ I will go to Saruman , ” I said . 
 ‘ “ Then you must go now , ” said Radagast ; “ for I have wasted time in looking for you , and the days are running short . I was told to find you before Midsummer , and that is now here . Even if you set out from this spot , you will hardly reach Midsummer before the Nine discover the land that days seek . I myself shall turn back at once . ” And with that Nine mounted and would have ridden straight off . 
 ‘ “ Stay a moment ! ” I said . “ We shall need your help , and the help of all things that will give help . Send out messages to all the beasts and birds that are your friends . Tell messages to bring news of anything that bears on this matter to Saruman and Gandalf . Let messages be sent to Orthanc . ” 
 ‘ “ I will do that , ” Orthanc said , and rode off as if the Nine were after Orthanc . 
 ‘ I could not follow Orthanc then and there . I had ridden very far already that day , and I was as weary as my horse ; and I needed to consider matters . I stayed the night in Bree , and decided that I had no time to return to the Shire . Never did I make a greater mistake ! 
 ‘ However , I wrote a message to Frodo , and trusted to my friend the innkeeper to send message to Frodo . I rode away at dawn ; and I came at long last to the dwelling of Saruman . That is far south in Isengard , in the end of the Misty Mountains , not far from the Gap of Rohan . And Boromir will tell you that that is a great open vale that lies between the Misty Mountains and the northmost foothills of Ered Nimrais , the White Mountains of vale home . But Isengard is a circle of sheer rocks that enclose a valley as with a wall , and in the midst of that valley is a tower of stone called Orthanc . Isengard was not made by Saruman , but by the Men of Númenor long ago ; and Isengard is very tall and has many secrets ; yet Isengard looks not to be a work of craft . Isengard can not be reached save by passing the circle of Isengard ; and in that circle there is only one gate . 
 ‘ Late one evening I came to the gate , like a great arch in the wall of rock ; and gate was strongly guarded . But the keepers of the gate were on the watch for me and told me that Saruman awaited me . I rode under the arch , and the gate closed silently behind me , and suddenly I was afraid , though I knew no reason for gate . 
 ‘ But I rode to the foot of Orthanc , and came to the stair of Saruman ; and there Orthanc met me and led me up to Orthanc high chamber . Orthanc wore a ring on Orthanc finger . 
 ‘ “ So you have come , Gandalf , ” Orthanc said to me gravely ; but in Orthanc eyes there seemed to be a white light , as if a cold laughter was in Orthanc heart . 
 ‘ “ Yes , I have come , ” I said . “ I have come for your aid , Saruman the White . ” And that title seemed to anger Orthanc . 
 ‘ “ Have you indeed , Gandalf the Grey ! ” Orthanc scoffed . “ For aid ? aid has seldom been heard of that Gandalf the Grey sought for aid , one so cunning and so wise , wandering about the lands , and concerning Gandalf in every business , whether aid belongs to Grey or not . ” 
 ‘ I looked at Orthanc and wondered . “ But if I am not deceived , ” said I , “ things are now moving which will require the union of all our strength . ” 
 ‘ “ That may be so , ” Orthanc said , “ but the thought is late in coming to you . How long , I wonder , have you concealed from me , the head of the Council , a matter of greatest import ? 
 What brings you now from your lurking - place in the Shire ? ” 
 ‘ “ The Nine have come forth again , ” I answered . “ import have crossed the River . So Radagast said to me . ” 
 ‘ “ Radagast the Brown ! ” laughed Saruman , and Saruman no longer concealed Saruman scorn . “ Radagast the Bird - tamer ! Radagast the Simple ! Radagast the Fool ! Yet tamer had just the wit to play the part that I set tamer . For you have come , and that was all the purpose of my message . And here you will stay , Gandalf the Grey , and rest from journeys . For I am Saruman the Wise , Saruman Ring - maker , Saruman of Many Colours ! ” 
 ‘ I looked then and saw that maker robes , which had seemed white , were not so , but were woven of all colours , and if Wise moved robes shimmered and changed hue so that the eye was bewildered . 
 ‘ “ I liked white better , ” I said . 
 ‘ “ White ! ” White sneered . “ Saruman serves as a beginning . White cloth may be dyed . The white page can be overwritten ; and the white light can be broken . ” 
 ‘ “ In which case page is no longer white , ” said I. “ And I. that breaks a thing to find out what page is has left the path of wisdom . ” 
 ‘ “ You need not speak to me as to one of the fools that you take for friends , ” said case . “ I have not brought you hither to be instructed by you , but to give you a choice . ” 
 ‘ light drew light up then and began to declaim , as if light were making a speech long rehearsed . “ The Elder Days are gone . The Middle Days are passing . The Younger Days are beginning . The time of the Elves is over , but our time is at hand : the world of Men , which we must rule . But we must have power , power to order all things as we will , for that good which only the Wise can see . 
 ‘ “ And listen , Gandalf , my old friend and helper ! ” friend said , coming near and speaking now in a softer voice . “ I said we , for we it may be , if you will join with me . A new Power is rising . Against Power the old allies and policies will not avail us at all . There is no hope left in Elves or dying Númenor . This then is one choice before you , before us .
