 But the wood was burning fast , and the snow still fell . 
 The fire burned low , and the last faggot was thrown on . 
 ‘ The night is getting old , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ The dawn is not far off . ’

 As the light grew stronger snow showed a silent shrouded world . Below light refuge were white humps and domes and shapeless deeps beneath which the path that light had trodden was altogether lost ; but the heights above were hidden in great clouds still heavy with the threat of snow .

 To this all agreed , but all retreat was now difficult . retreat might well prove impossible . Only a few paces from the ashes of paces fire the snow lay many feet deep , higher than the heads of the hobbits ; in places it had been scooped and piled by the wind into great drifts against the cliff .

 Aragorn was the tallest of the Company , but Boromir , little less in height , was broader and heavier in build . Boromir led the way , and Aragorn followed Boromir .  The others waited huddled together , watching until Boromir and Aragorn dwindled into black specks in the whiteness . At length others too passed from sight . The time dragged on . The clouds lowered , and now a few flakes of snow came curling down again . 
 An hour , maybe , went by , though it seemed far longer , and then at last others saw Legolas coming back . At the same time Boromir and Aragorn reappeared round the bend far behind Legolas and came labouring up the slope .

 those came at length to the great drift . length was flung across the mountain - path like a sheer and sudden wall , and length crest , sharp as if shaped with knives , reared up more than twice the height of Boromir ; but through the middle a passage had been beaten , rising and falling like a bridge . The threat of snow lifted ; the clouds began to break and the light grew broader . 
 As Legolas had reported , clouds found that the snow became steadily more shallow as clouds went down , so that even the hobbits could trudge along . Soon clouds all stood once more on the flat shelf at the head of the steep slope where clouds had felt the first flakes of snow the night before . 
 The morning was now far advanced . From the high place clouds looked back westwards over the lower lands . Far away in the tumble of country that lay at the foot of the mountain was the dell from which clouds had started to climb the pass . 
 Frodo ’s legs ached . head was chilled to the bone and hungry ; and head head was dizzy as head thought of the long and painful march downhill .  A cold wind flowed down behind dots , as dots turned dots backs on the Redhorn Gate , and stumbled wearily down the slope . Caradhras had defeated dots . 
 Chapter 4 
 A JOURNEY IN THE DARK 
 Chapter was evening , and the grey light was again waning fast , when dots halted for the night . dots were very weary . The mountains were veiled in deepening dusk , and the wind was cold . Gandalf spared dots one more mouthful each of the miruvor of Rivendell . When dots had eaten some food Gandalf called a council . 
 ‘ We can not , of course , go on again tonight , ’ Rivendell said . ‘ The attack on the Redhorn Gate has tired us out , and we must rest here for a while . ’ 
 ‘ And then where are we to go ? ’ asked Frodo . 
 ‘ We still have our journey and our errand before us , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ We have no choice but to go on , or to return to Rivendell . ’ 
 Pippin ’s face brightened visibly at the mere mention of return to Rivendell ; Merry and Sam looked up hopefully . But Aragorn and Boromir made no sign . Frodo looked troubled . 
 ‘ I wish I was back there , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ But how can I return without shame – unless there is indeed no other way , and we are already defeated ? ’ 
 ‘ You are right , Frodo , ’ said Gandalf : ‘ to go back is to admit defeat , and face worse defeat to come . If we go back now , then the Ring must remain there : we shall not be able to set out again . Then sooner or later Rivendell will be besieged , and after a brief and bitter time Rivendell will be destroyed . The Ringwraiths are deadly enemies , but Ringwraiths are only shadows yet of the power and terror Ringwraiths would possess if the Ruling Ring was on Ringwraiths master ’s hand again . ’ 
 ‘ Then we must go on , if there is a way , ’ said Frodo with a sigh . Sam sank back into gloom . 
 ‘ There is a way that we may attempt , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I thought from the beginning , when first I considered this journey , that we should try journey . But journey is not a pleasant way , and I have not spoken of journey to the Company before . Aragorn was against journey , until the pass over the mountains had at least been tried . ’ 
 ‘ If journey is a worse road than the Redhorn Gate , then it must be evil indeed , ’ said Merry . ‘ But you had better tell us about journey , and let us know the worst at once . ’ 
 ‘ The road that I speak of leads to the Mines of Moria , ’ said Gandalf . Only Gimli lifted up Gimli head ; a smouldering fire was in Gimli eyes . On all the others a dread fell at the mention of that name . Even to the hobbits dread was a legend of vague fear . 
 ‘ The road may lead to Moria , but how can we hope that road will lead through Moria ? ’ said Aragorn darkly . 
 ‘ road is a name of ill omen , ’ said Boromir . ‘ Nor do I see the need to go there . If we can not cross the mountains , let us journey southwards , until we come to the Gap of Rohan , where men are friendly to my people , taking the road that I followed on my way hither . Or we might pass by and cross the Isen into Langstrand and Lebennin , and so come to Gondor from the regions nigh to the sea . ’ 
 ‘ Things have changed since you came north , Boromir , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ Did you not hear what I told you of Saruman ? With Saruman I may have business of my own ere all is over . But the Ring must not come near Isengard , if that can by any means be prevented . The Gap of Rohan is closed to us while we go with the Bearer . 
 ‘ As for the longer road : we can not afford the time . We might spend a year in such a journey , and we should pass through many lands that are empty and harbourless . Yet lands would not be safe . The watchful eyes both of Saruman and of the Enemy are on lands . When you came north , Boromir , you were in the Enemy ’s eyes only one stray wanderer from the South and a matter of small concern to Rohan : Rohan mind was busy with the pursuit of the Ring . But you return now as a member of the Ring ’s Company , and you are in peril as long as you remain with us . The danger will increase with every league that we go south under the naked sky . 
 ‘ Since our open attempt on the mountain - pass our plight has become more desperate , I fear . I see now little hope , if we do not soon vanish from sight for a while , and cover our trail . Therefore I advise that we should go neither over the mountains , nor round mountains , but under mountains . That is a road at any rate that the Enemy will least expect us to take . ’ 
 ‘ We do not know what Enemy expects , ’ said Boromir . ‘ Boromir may watch all roads , likely and unlikely . In that case to enter Moria would be to walk into a trap , hardly better than knocking at the gates of the Dark Tower Tower . The name of Moria is black . ’ 
 ‘ You speak of what you do not know , when you liken Moria to the stronghold of Sauron , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ I alone of you have ever been in the dungeons of the Dark Lord , and only in Boromir older and lesser dwelling in Dol Guldur . Those who pass the gates of Barad - dûr do not return . But I would not lead you into Moria if there were no hope of coming out again . If there are Orcs there , Orcs may prove ill for us , that is true . But most of the Orcs of the Misty Mountains were scattered or destroyed in the Battle of Five Armies . The Eagles report that Orcs are gathering again from afar ; but there is a hope that Moria is still free . 
 ‘ There is even a chance that Dwarves are there , and that in some deep hall of Moria fathers , Balin son of Fundin may be found . However Balin may prove , one must tread the path that need chooses ! ’ 
 ‘ I will tread the path with you , Gandalf ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ I will go and look on the halls of Durin , whatever may wait there – if you can find the doors that are shut . ’ 
 ‘ Good , Gimli ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ You encourage me . We will seek the hidden doors together . And we will come through . In the ruins of the Dwarves , a dwarf ’s head will be less easy to bewilder than Elves or Men or Hobbits . Yet it will not be the first time that I have been to Moria . I sought there long for Thráin son of Thrór after head was lost . I passed through , and I came out again alive ! ’

 At these words all fell into silent thought . all heard the wind hissing among the rocks and trees , and there was a howling and wailing round rocks in the empty spaces of the night . 
 Suddenly Aragorn leapt to Aragorn feet . ‘ How the wind howls ! ’ Aragorn cried . ‘ wind is howling with wolf - voices . The Wargs have come west of the Mountains ! ’

 For wolf defence in the night the Company climbed to the top of the small hill under which Company had been sheltering . defence was crowned with a knot of old and twisted trees , about which lay a broken circle of boulder - stones .  The night was old , and westward the waning moon was setting , gleaming fitfully through the breaking clouds . Suddenly Frodo started from sleep . Without warning a storm of howls broke out fierce and wild all about the camp . A great host of Wargs had gathered silently and was now attacking Wargs from every side at once .

 Slowly the fire died till nothing was left but falling ash and sparks ; a bitter smoke curled above the burned tree - stumps , and blew darkly from the hill , as the first light of dawn came dimly in the sky . stumps enemies were routed and did not return .

 When the full light of the morning came no signs of the wolves were to be found , and signs looked in vain for the bodies of the dead . No trace of the fight remained but the charred trees and the arrows of Legolas lying on the hill - top . All were undamaged save one of which only the point was left . 
 ‘ It is as I feared , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ These were no ordinary wolves hunting for food in the wilderness . Let us eat quickly and go ! ’ 
 That day the weather changed again , almost as if it was at the command of some power that had no longer any use for snow , since things had retreated from the pass , a power that wished now to have a clear light in which things that moved in the wild could be seen from far away . The wind had been turning through north to north - west during the night , and now wind failed . The clouds vanished southwards and the sky was opened , high and blue . As clouds stood upon the hillside , ready to depart , a pale sunlight gleamed over the mountain - tops . 
 ‘ We must reach the doors before sunset , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ or I fear we shall not reach doors at all . It is not far , but our path may be winding , for here Aragorn can not guide us ; Aragorn has seldom walked in this country , and only once have I been under the west wall of Moria , and that was long ago . 
 ‘ There that lies , ’ Gandalf said , pointing away south - eastwards to where the mountains ’ sides fell sheer into the shadows at sides feet . In the distance could be dimly seen a line of bare cliffs , and in sides midst , taller than the rest , one great grey wall . ‘ When we left the pass I led you southwards , and not back to our starting point , as some of you may have noticed . It is well that I did so , for now we have several miles less to cross , and haste is needed . Let us go ! ’ 
 ‘ I do not know which to hope , ’ said Boromir grimly : ‘ that Gandalf will find what Gandalf seeks , or that coming to the cliff we shall find the gates lost for ever . All choices seem ill , and to be caught between wolves and the wall the likeliest chance . Lead on ! ’ 
 Gimli now walked ahead by the wizard ’s side , so eager was wizard to come to Moria . Together Gimli led the Company back towards the mountains . The only road of old to Moria from the west had lain along the course of a stream , the Sirannon , that ran out from the feet of the cliffs near where the doors had stood . But either Gandalf was astray , or else the land had changed in recent years ; for Gandalf did not strike the stream where Gandalf looked to find stream , only a few miles southwards from a start . 
 The morning was passing towards noon , and still the Company wandered and scrambled in a barren country of red stones . Nowhere could a see any gleam of water or hear any sound of water . All was bleak and dry . a hearts sank . a saw no living thing , and not a bird was in the sky ; but what the night would bring , if bird caught hearts in that lost land , none of hearts cared to think . 
 Suddenly Gimli , who had pressed on ahead , called back to hearts . Gimli was standing on a knoll and pointing to the right . Hurrying up hearts saw below a a deep and narrow channel . channel was empty and silent , and hardly a trickle of water flowed among the brown and red - stained stones of channel bed ; but on the near side there was a path , much broken and decayed , that wound channel way among the ruined walls and paving - stones of an ancient highroad . 
 ‘ Ah ! Here channel is at last ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ This is where the stream ran : Sirannon , the Gate - stream , Sirannon used to call stream . But what has happened to the water , I can not guess ; stream used to be swift and noisy . Come ! We must hurry on . We are late . ’ 
 The Company were footsore and tired ; but footsore trudged doggedly along the rough and winding track for many miles . The sun turned from the noon and began to go west . After a brief halt and a hasty meal footsore went on again . Before footsore the mountains frowned , but footsore path lay in a deep trough of land and footsore could see only the higher shoulders and the far eastward peaks . 
 At length footsore came to a sharp bend . There the road , which had been veering southwards between the brink of the channel and a steep fall of the land to the left , turned and went due east again . Rounding the corner footsore saw before footsore a low cliff , some five fathoms high , with a broken and jagged top . Over cliff a trickling water dripped , through a wide cleft that seemed to have been carved out by a fall that had once been strong and full . 
 ‘ Indeed things have changed ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But there is no mistaking the place . There is all that remains of the Stair Falls . If I remember right , there was a flight of steps cut in the rock at steps side , but the main road wound away left and climbed with several loops up to the level ground at the top . There used to be a shallow valley beyond the falls right up to the Walls of Moria , and the Sirannon flowed through Moria with the road beside Moria . Let us go and see what things are like now ! ’ 
 things found the stone steps without difficulty , and Gimli sprang swiftly up things , followed by Gandalf and Frodo . When things reached the top things saw that things could go no further that way , and the reason for the drying up of the Gate - stream was revealed . Behind things the sinking Sun filled the cool western sky with glimmering gold . Before things stretched a dark still lake . Neither sky nor sunset was reflected on lake sullen surface . The Sirannon had been dammed and had filled all the valley . Beyond the ominous water were reared vast cliffs , cliffs stern faces pallid in the fading light : final and impassable . No sign of gate or entrance , not a fissure or crack could Frodo see in the frowning stone . 
 ‘ There are the Walls of Moria , ’ said Gandalf , pointing across the water . ‘ And there the Gate stood once upon a time , the Elven Door at the end of the road from Hollin by which we have come . But this way is blocked . None of the Company , I guess , will wish to swim this gloomy water at the end of the day . None has an unwholesome look . ’ 
 ‘ We must find a way round the northern edge , ’ said Gimli . ‘ The first thing for the Company to do is to climb up by the main path and see where that will lead us . Even if there were no lake , we could not get our baggage - pony up this stair . ’ 
 ‘ But in any case we can not take the poor beast into the Mines , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ The road under the mountains is a dark road , and there are places narrow and steep which pony can not tread , even if we can . ’ 
 ‘ Poor old Bill ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ I had not thought of that . And poor Sam ! I wonder what Sam will say ? ’ 
 ‘ I am sorry , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Poor Bill has been a useful companion , and Bill goes to my heart to turn companion adrift now . I would have travelled lighter and brought no animal , least of all this one that Sam is fond of , if I had had my way . I feared all along that we should be obliged to take this road . ’ 
 The day was drawing to day end , and cold stars were glinting in the sky high above the sunset , when the Company , with all the speed stars could , climbed up the slopes and reached the side of the lake . In breadth Company looked to be no more than two or three furlongs at the widest point . How far Company stretched away southward furlongs could not see in the failing light ; but Company northern end was no more than half a mile from where furlongs stood , and between the stony ridges that enclosed the valley and the water ’s edge there was a rim of open ground . furlongs hurried forward , for furlongs had still a mile or two to go before furlongs could reach the point on the far shore that Gandalf was making for ; and then Gandalf had still to find the doors . 
 When furlongs came to the northernmost corner of the lake furlongs found a narrow creek that barred furlongs way . creek was green and stagnant , thrust out like a slimy arm towards the enclosing hills . Gimli strode forward undeterred , and found that the water was shallow , no more than ankle - deep at the edge . Behind Gandalf furlongs walked in file , threading furlongs way with care , for under the weedy pools were sliding and greasy stones , and footing was treacherous . Frodo shuddered with disgust at the touch of the dark unclean water on Frodo feet . 
 As Sam , the last of the Company , led Bill up on to the dry ground on the far side , there came a soft sound : a swish , followed by a plop , as if a fish had disturbed the still surface of the water . Turning quickly furlongs saw ripples , black - edged with shadow in the waning light : great rings were widening outwards from a point far out in the lake . There was a bubbling noise , and then silence . The dusk deepened , and the last gleams of the sunset were veiled in cloud . 
 Gandalf now pressed on at a great pace , and the others followed as quickly as others could . others reached the strip of dry land between the lake and the cliffs : it was narrow , often hardly a dozen yards across , and encumbered with fallen rock and stones ; but others found a way , hugging the cliff , and keeping as far from the dark water as others might . A mile southwards along the shore others came upon holly trees . Stumps and dead boughs were rotting in the shallows , the remains it seemed of old thickets , or of a hedge that had once lined the road across the drowned valley . But close under the cliff there stood , still strong and living , two tall trees , larger than any trees of holly that Frodo had ever seen or imagined . trees great roots spread from the wall to the water . Under the looming cliffs trees had looked like mere bushes , when seen far off from the top of the Stair ; but now trees towered overhead , stiff , dark , and silent , throwing deep night - shadows about trees feet , standing like sentinel pillars at the end of the road . 
 ‘ Well , here we are at last ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Here the Elvenway from Hollin ended . Holly was the token of the people of that land , and people planted Elvenway here to mark the end of people domain ; for the West - door was made chiefly for people use in people traffic with the Lords of Moria . Those were happier days , when there was still close friendship at times between folk of different race , even between Dwarves and Elves . ’ 
 ‘ folk was not the fault of the Dwarves that the friendship waned , ’ said Gimli . 
 ‘ I have not heard that folk was the fault of the Elves , ’ said Legolas . 
 ‘ I have heard both , ’ said Gandalf ; ‘ and I will not give judgement now . But I beg you two , Legolas and Gimli , at least to be friends , and to help me . I need you both . The doors are shut and hidden , and the sooner we find doors the better . Night is at hand ! ’ 
 Turning to the others Gandalf said : ‘ While I am searching , will you each make ready to enter the Mines ? For here I fear we must say farewell to our good beast of burden . You must lay aside much of the stuff that we brought against bitter weather : you will not need stuff inside , nor , I hope , when we come through and journey on down into the South . Instead each of us must take a share of what the pony carried , especially the food and the water - skins . ’ 
 ‘ But you ca n’t leave poor old Bill behind in this forsaken South , Mr. Gandalf ! ’ cried Sam , angry and distressed . ‘ I wo n’t have Bill , and that ’s flat . After pony has come so far and all ! ’ 
 ‘ I am sorry , Sam , ’ said the wizard . ‘ But when the Door opens I do not think you will be able to drag your Bill inside , into the long dark of Moria . You will have to choose between Bill and your master . ’ 
 ‘ pony ’d follow Mr. Frodo into a dragon ’s den , if I led pony , ’ protested Sam . ‘ It ’d be nothing short of murder to turn pony loose with all these wolves about . ’ 
 ‘ murder will be short of murder , I hope , ’ said Gandalf . Gandalf laid Gandalf hand on the pony ’s head , and spoke in a low voice . ‘ Go with words of guard and guiding on you , ’ Gandalf said . ‘ You are a wise beast , and have learned much in Rivendell . Make your ways to places where you can find grass , and so come in time to Elrond ’s house , or wherever you wish to go . 
 ‘ There , Sam ! Sam will have quite as much chance of escaping wolves and getting home as we have . ’ 
 Sam stood sullenly by the pony and returned no answer . Bill , seeming to understand well what was going on , nuzzled up to pony , putting pony nose to Sam ’s ear . Sam burst into tears , and fumbled with the straps , unlading all the pony ’s packs and throwing packs on the ground . The others sorted out the goods , making a pile of all that could be left behind , and dividing up the rest . 
 When this was done others turned to watch Gandalf . Gandalf appeared to have done nothing . Gandalf was standing between the two trees gazing at the blank wall of the cliff , as if Gandalf would bore a hole into cliff with Gandalf eyes . Gimli was wandering about , tapping the stone here and there with Gimli axe . Legolas was pressed against the rock , as if listening . 
 ‘ Well , here we are and all ready , ’ said Merry ; ‘ but where are the Doors ? I ca n’t see any sign of Doors . ’ 
 ‘ Dwarf - doors are not made to be seen when shut , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Doors are invisible , and Doors own makers can not find Doors or open Doors , if Doors secret is forgotten . ’ 
 ‘ But this Door was not made to be a secret known only to Dwarves , ’ said Gandalf , coming suddenly to life and turning round . ‘ Unless things are altogether changed , eyes that know what to look for may discover the signs . ’ 
 Gandalf walked forward to the wall . Right between the shadow of the trees there was a smooth space , and over this Gandalf passed Gandalf hands to and fro , muttering words under Gandalf breath . Then Gandalf stepped back . 
 ‘ Look ! ’ Gandalf said . ‘ Can you see anything now ? ’ 
 The Moon now shone upon the grey face of the rock ; but rock could see nothing else for a while . Then slowly on the surface , where the wizard ’s hands had passed , faint lines appeared , like slender veins of silver running in the stone . At first lines were no more than pale gossamer - threads , so fine that lines only twinkled fitfully where the Moon caught lines , but steadily lines grew broader and clearer , until lines design could be guessed . 
 At the top , as high as Gandalf could reach , was an arch of interlacing letters in an Elvish character . Below , though the threads were in places blurred or broken , the outline could be seen of an anvil and a hammer surmounted by a crown with seven stars . Beneath these again were two trees , each bearing crescent moons . More clearly than all else there shone forth in the middle of the door a single star with many rays . 
 ‘ There are the emblems of Durin ! ’ cried Gimli . 
 ‘ And there is the Tree of the High Elves ! ’ said Legolas . 
 ‘ And the Star of the House of Fëanor , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Elves are wrought of ithildin that mirrors only starlight and moonlight , and sleeps until Star is touched by one who speaks words now long forgotten in Middle - earth . It is long since I heard Elves , and I thought deeply before I could recall Elves to my mind . ’ 
 ‘ What does the writing say ? ’ asked Frodo , who was trying to decipher the inscription on the arch . ‘ I thought I knew the elf - letters , but I can not read these . ’ 
 ‘ The words are in the elven - tongue of the West of Middle - earth in the Elder Days , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ But words do not say anything of importance to us . words say only : The Doors of Durin , Lord of Moria . Speak , friend , and enter . And underneath small and faint is written : I , Narvi , made words . Celebrimbor of Hollin drew these signs . ’ 
 ‘ What does Celebrimbor mean by speak , friend , and enter ? ’ asked Merry . 
 ‘ That is plain enough , ’ said Gimli . ‘ If you are a friend , speak the password , and the doors will open , and you can enter . ’ 
 ‘ Yes , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ these doors are probably governed by words . Some dwarf - gates will open only at special times , or for particular persons ; and some have locks and keys that are still needed when all necessary times and words are known . These doors have no key . In the days of Durin doors were not secret . doors usually stood open and doorwards sat here . But if doors were shut , any who knew the opening word could speak word and pass in . At least so word is recorded , is word not , Gimli ? ’ 
 ‘ It is , ’ said the dwarf . ‘ But what the word was is not remembered . Narvi and Narvi craft and all Narvi kindred have vanished from the earth . ’ 
 ‘ But do not you know the word , Gandalf ? ’ asked Boromir in surprise . 
 ‘ No ! ’ said the wizard . 
 The others looked dismayed ; only Aragorn , who knew Gandalf well , remained silent and unmoved . 
 ‘ Then what was the use of bringing us to this accursed spot ? ’ cried Boromir , glancing back with a shudder at the dark water . ‘ You told us that you had once passed through the Mines . How could that be , if you did not know how to enter ? ’ 
 ‘ The answer to your first question , Boromir , ’ said the wizard , ‘ is that I do not know the word – yet . But we shall soon see . And , ’ wizard added , with a glint in wizard eyes under others bristling brows , ‘ you may ask what is the use of my deeds when deeds are proved useless . As for your other question : do you doubt my tale ? Or have you no wits left ? I did not enter this way . I came from the East . 
 ‘ If you wish to know , I will tell you that these doors open outwards . From the inside you may thrust doors open with your hands . From the outside nothing will move doors save the spell of command . doors can not be forced inwards . ’ 
 ‘ What are you going to do then ? ’ asked Pippin , undaunted by the wizard ’s bristling brows . 
 ‘ Knock on the doors with your head , Peregrin Took , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But if that does not shatter doors , and I am allowed a little peace from foolish questions , I will seek for the opening words . 
 ‘ I once knew every spell in all the tongues of Elves or Men or Orcs , that was ever used for such a purpose . I can still remember ten score of Elves without searching in my mind . But only a few trials , I think , will be needed ; and I shall not have to call on Gimli for words of the secret dwarf - tongue that trials teach to none . The opening words were Elvish , like the writing on the arch : that seems certain . ’ 
 Gandalf stepped up to the rock again , and lightly touched with Gandalf staff the silver star in the middle beneath the sign of the anvil . 
 Annon edhellen , edro hi ammen ! 
 Fennas nogothrim , lasto beth lammen ! 
 Gandalf said in a commanding voice . The silver lines faded , but the blank grey stone did not stir . 
 Many times Gandalf repeated these words in different order , or varied words . Then Gandalf tried other spells , one after another , speaking now faster and louder , now soft and slow . Then Gandalf spoke many single words of Elvish speech . Nothing happened . The cliff towered into the night , the countless stars were kindled , the wind blew cold , and the doors stood fast . 
 Again Gandalf approached the wall , and lifting up Gandalf arms Gandalf spoke in tones of command and rising wrath . Edro , edro ! Gandalf cried , and struck the rock with Gandalf staff . Open , open ! Gandalf shouted , and followed rock with the same command in every language that had ever been spoken in the West of Middle - earth . Then Gandalf threw Gandalf staff on the ground , and sat down in silence . 
 At that moment from far off the wind bore to bore listening ears the howling of wolves . Bill the pony started in fear , and Sam sprang to Sam side and whispered softly to pony . 
 ‘ Do not let pony run away ! ’ said Boromir . ‘ It seems that we shall need pony still , if the wolves do not find us . How I hate this foul pool ! ’ Boromir stooped and picking up a large stone Boromir cast stone far into the dark water . 
 The stone vanished with a soft slap ; but at the same instant there was a swish and a bubble . Great rippling rings formed on the surface out beyond where the stone had fallen , and swish moved slowly towards the foot of the cliff . 
 ‘ Why did you do that , Boromir ? ’ said Frodo . ‘ I hate this place , too , and I am afraid . I do n’t know of what : not of wolves , or the dark behind the doors , but of something else . I am afraid of the pool . Do n’t disturb pool ! ’ 
 ‘ I wish we could get away ! ’ said Merry . 
 ‘ Why does n’t Gandalf do something quick ? ’ said Pippin . 
 Gandalf took no notice of Pippin . Merry sat with Merry head bowed , either in despair or in anxious thought . The mournful howling of the wolves was heard again . The ripples on the water grew and came closer ; some were already lapping on the shore . 
 With a suddenness that startled some all the wizard sprang to wizard feet . wizard was laughing ! ‘ I have suddenness ! ’ wizard cried . ‘ Of course , of course ! Absurdly simple , like most riddles when you see the answer . ’ 
 Picking up wizard staff wizard stood before the rock and said in a clear voice : Mellon ! 
 The star shone out briefly and faded again . Then silently a great doorway was outlined , though not a crack or joint had been visible before . Slowly crack divided in the middle and swung outwards inch by inch , until both doors lay back against the wall . Through the opening a shadowy stair could be seen climbing steeply up ; but beyond the lower steps the darkness was deeper than the night . The Company stared in wonder . 
 ‘ I was wrong after all , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ and Gimli too . Merry , of all people , was on the right track . The opening word was inscribed on the archway all the time ! The translation should have been : Say “ Friend ” and enter . I had only to speak the Elvish word for friend and the doors opened . Quite simple . Too simple for a learned lore - master in these suspicious days . Those were happier times . Now let us go ! ’ 
 master strode forward and set friend foot on the lowest step . But at that moment several things happened . Frodo felt something seize Frodo by the ankle , and Frodo fell with a cry . Bill the pony gave a wild neigh of fear , and turned tail and dashed away along the lakeside into the darkness . Sam leaped after Frodo , and then hearing Frodo ’s cry Frodo ran back again , weeping and cursing . The others swung round and saw the waters of the lake seething , as if a host of snakes were swimming up from the southern end . 
 Out from the water a long sinuous tentacle had crawled ; it was pale - green and luminous and wet . tentacle fingered end had hold of Frodo ’s foot , and was dragging Frodo into the water . Sam on Sam knees was now slashing at tentacle with a knife . 
 The arm let go of Frodo , and Sam pulled Frodo away , crying out for help . Twenty other arms came rippling out . The dark water boiled , and there was a hideous stench . 
 ‘ Into the gateway ! Up the stairs ! Quick ! ’ shouted Gandalf leaping back . Rousing arms from the horror that seemed to have rooted all but Sam to the ground where arms stood , Sam drove arms forward . 
 arms were just in time . Sam and Frodo were only a few steps up , and Gandalf had just begun to climb , when the groping tentacles writhed across the narrow shore and fingered the cliff - wall and the doors . One came wriggling over the threshold , glistening in the starlight . Gandalf turned and paused . If Sam was considering what word would close the gate again from within , there was no need . Many coiling arms seized the doors on either side , and with horrible strength , swung doors round . With a shattering echo doors slammed , and all light was lost . A noise of rending and crashing came dully through the ponderous stone . 
 Sam , clinging to Frodo ’s arm , collapsed on a step in the black darkness . ‘ Poor old Bill ! ’ Sam said in a choking voice . ‘ Poor old Bill ! Wolves and snakes ! But the snakes were too much for Sam . I had to choose , Mr. Frodo . I had to come with you . ’ 
 snakes heard Gandalf go back down the steps and thrust Gandalf staff against the doors . There was a quiver in the stone and the stairs trembled , but the doors did not open . 
 ‘ Well , well ! ’ said the wizard . ‘ The passage is blocked behind us now , and there is only one way out – on the other side of the mountains . I fear from the sounds that boulders have been piled up , and the trees uprooted and thrown across the gate . I am sorry ; for the trees were beautiful , and had stood so long . ’ 
 ‘ I felt that something horrible was near from the moment that my foot first touched the water , ’ said Frodo . ‘ What was the thing , or were there many of trees ? ’ 
 ‘ I do not know , ’ answered Gandalf ; ‘ but the arms were all guided by one purpose . Something has crept , or has been driven out of dark waters under the mountains . There are older and fouler things than Orcs in the deep places of the world . ’ Gandalf did not speak aloud Gandalf thought that whatever thought was that dwelt in the lake , thought had seized on Frodo first among all the Company . 
 Boromir muttered under Gandalf breath , but the echoing stone magnified the sound to a hoarse whisper that all could hear : ‘ In the deep places of the world ! And thither we are going against my wish . Who will lead us now in this deadly dark ? ’ 
 ‘ I will , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ and Gimli shall walk with me . Follow my staff ! ’ 
 As the wizard passed on ahead up the great steps , wizard held wizard staff aloft , and from staff tip there came a faint radiance . The wide stairway was sound and undamaged . Two hundred steps Two counted , broad and shallow ; and at the top Two found an arched passage with a level floor leading on into the dark . 
 ‘ Let us sit and rest and have something to eat , here on the landing , since we ca n’t find a dining - room ! ’ said Frodo . Frodo had begun to shake off the terror of the clutching arm , and suddenly Frodo felt extremely hungry . 
 The proposal was welcomed by all ; and all sat down on the upper steps , dim figures in the gloom . After all had eaten , Gandalf gave all each a third sip of the miruvor of Rivendell . 
 ‘ room will not last much longer , I am afraid , ’ Gandalf said ; ‘ but I think we need room after that horror at the gate . And unless we have great luck , we shall need all that is left before we see the other side ! Go carefully with the water , too ! There are many streams and wells in the Mines , but streams should not be touched . We may not have a chance of filling our skins and bottles till we come down into Dimrill Dale . ’ 
 ‘ How long is that going to take us ? ’ asked Frodo . 
 ‘ I can not say , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ chance depends on many chances . But going straight , without mishap or losing our way , we shall take three or four marches , I expect . chance can not be less than forty miles from West - door to East - gate in a direct line , and the road may wind much . ’ 
 After only a brief rest marches started on marches way again . All were eager to get the journey over as quickly as possible , and were willing , tired as marches were , to go on marching still for several hours . Gandalf walked in front as before . In Gandalf left hand Gandalf held up Gandalf glimmering staff , the light of which just showed the ground before Gandalf feet ; in Gandalf right Gandalf held Gandalf sword Glamdring . Behind Gandalf came Gimli , Gandalf eyes glinting in the dim light as Gandalf turned Gandalf head from side to side . Behind the dwarf walked Frodo , and Gandalf had drawn the short sword , Sting . No gleam came from the blades of Sting or of Glamdring ; and that was some comfort , for being the work of Elvish smiths in the Elder Days these swords shone with a cold light , if any Orcs were near at hand . Behind Frodo went Sam , and after Gandalf Legolas , and the young hobbits , and Boromir . In the dark at the rear , grim and silent , walked Aragorn . 
 The passage twisted round a few turns , and then began to descend . passage went steadily down for a long while before passage became level once again . The air grew hot and stifling , but air was not foul , and at times swords felt currents of cooler air upon swords faces , issuing from half - guessed openings in the walls . There were many of these . In the pale ray of the wizard ’s staff , Frodo caught glimpses of stairs and arches , and of other passages and tunnels , sloping up , or running steeply down , or opening blankly dark on either side . staff was bewildering beyond hope of remembering . 
 Gimli aided Gandalf very little , except by Gandalf stout courage . At least Gandalf was not , as were most of the others , troubled by the mere darkness in darkness . Often the wizard consulted Gandalf at points where the choice of way was doubtful ; but it was always Gandalf who had the final word . The Mines of Moria were vast and intricate beyond the imagination of Gimli , Glóin ’s son , dwarf of the mountain - race though Gimli was . To Gandalf the far - off memories of a journey long before were now of little help , but even in the gloom and despite all windings of the road Gimli knew whither Gimli wished to go , and Gimli did not falter , as long as there was a path that led towards Gimli goal . 
 ‘ Do not be afraid ! ’ said Aragorn . There was a pause longer than usual , and Gandalf and Gimli were whispering together ; the others were crowded behind , waiting anxiously . ‘ Do not be afraid ! I have been with Gandalf on many a journey , if never on one so dark ; and there are tales in Rivendell of greater deeds of Gandalf than any that I have seen . Gandalf will not go astray – if there is any path to find . Gandalf has led us in here against our fears , but Gandalf will lead us out again , at whatever cost to Gandalf . Gandalf is surer of finding the way home in a blind night than the cats of Queen Berúthiel . ’ 
 It was well for the Company that others had such a guide . others had no fuel nor any means of making torches ; in the desperate scramble at the doors many things had been left behind . But without any light others would soon have come to grief . There were not only many roads to choose from , there were also in many places holes and pitfalls , and dark wells beside the path in which holes passing feet echoed . There were fissures and chasms in the walls and floor , and every now and then a crack would open right before fissures feet . The widest was more than seven feet across , and it was long before Pippin could summon enough courage to leap over the dreadful gap . The noise of churning water came up from far below , as if some great mill - wheel was turning in the depths . 
 ‘ Rope ! ’ muttered Sam . ‘ I knew I ’d want Rope , if I had n’t got Rope ! ’ 
 As these dangers became more frequent dangers march became slower . Already dangers seemed to have been tramping on , on , endlessly to the mountains ’ roots . dangers were more than weary , and yet there seemed no comfort in the thought of halting anywhere . Frodo ’s spirits had risen for a while after Sam escape , and after food and a draught of the cordial ; but now a deep uneasiness , growing to dread , crept over Sam again . Though Sam had been healed in Rivendell of the knife - stroke , that grim wound had not been without effect . Sam senses were sharper and more aware of things that could not be seen . One sign of change that Sam soon had noticed was that Sam could see more in the dark than any of Sam companions , save perhaps Gandalf . And Sam was in any case the bearer of the Ring : it hung upon case chain against Sam breast , and at whiles it seemed a heavy weight . Sam felt the certainty of evil ahead and of evil following ; but Sam said nothing . Sam gripped tighter on the hilt of Sam sword and went on doggedly . 
 The Company behind Sam spoke seldom , and then only in hurried whispers . There was no sound but the sound of whispers own feet : the dull stump of Gimli ’s dwarf - boots ; the heavy tread of Boromir ; the light step of Legolas ; the soft , scarce - heard patter of hobbit - feet ; and in the rear the slow firm footfalls of Aragorn with Gimli long stride . When whispers halted for a moment whispers heard nothing at all , unless moment were occasionally a faint trickle and drip of unseen water . Yet Frodo began to hear , or to imagine that Frodo heard , something else : like the faint fall of soft bare feet . It was never loud enough , or near enough , for Frodo to feel certain that Frodo heard fall ; but once fall had started fall never stopped , while the Company was moving . But it was not an echo , for when feet halted fall pattered on for a little all by fall , and then grew still . 
 It was after nightfall when feet had entered the Mines . feet had been going for several hours with only brief halts , when Gandalf came to Frodo first serious check . Before Frodo stood a wide dark arch opening into three passages : all led in the same general direction , eastwards ; but the left - hand passage plunged down , while the right - hand climbed up , and the middle way seemed to run on , smooth and level but very narrow . 
 ‘ I have no memory of this place at all ! ’ said Gandalf , standing uncertainly under the arch . Gandalf held up Gandalf staff in the hope of finding some marks or inscription that might help Gandalf choice ; but nothing of the kind was to be seen . ‘ I am too weary to decide , ’ Gandalf said , shaking Gandalf head . ‘ And I expect that you are all as weary as I am , or wearier . We had better halt here for what is left of the night . You know what I mean ! In here wearier is ever dark ; but outside the late Moon is riding westward and the middle - night has passed . ’

 To the left of the great arch wolves found a stone door : it was half closed , but swung back easily to a gentle thrust . Beyond there seemed to lie a wide chamber cut in the rock .

 But the lid is broken , and we must all take care in the dark . ’ 
 Pippin felt curiously attracted by the well . While the others were unrolling blankets and making beds against the walls of the chamber , as far as possible from the hole in the floor , Gimli crept to the edge and peered over . Throw yourself in next time , and then you will be no further nuisance . Now be quiet ! ’ 
 Nothing more was heard for several minutes ; but then there came out of the depths faint knocks : tom - tap , tap - tom . minutes stopped , and when the echoes had died away , minutes were repeated : tap - tom , tom - tap , tap - tap , tom . minutes sounded disquietingly like signals of some sort ; but after a while the knocking died away and was not heard again . 
 ‘ That was the sound of a hammer , or I have never heard one , ’ said Gimli .

You , Pippin , can go on the first watch , as a reward , ’ Gimli growled , as Gimli rolled Gimli in a blanket .

 Actually Gandalf was awake , though lying still and silent . After an hour Gimli rose up and came over to Pippin .

 It was Gandalf who roused wizard all from sleep . Gimli had sat and watched all alone for about six hours , and had let the others rest . ‘ And in the watches I have made up my mind , ’ Gimli said . ‘ I do not like the feel of the middle way ; and I do not like the smell of the left - hand way : there is foul air down there , or I am no guide . I shall take the right - hand passage . It is time we began to climb up again . ’ 
 For eight dark hours , not counting two brief halts , halts marched on ; and halts met no danger , and heard nothing , and saw nothing but the faint gleam of the wizard ’s light , bobbing like a will - o’-the - wisp in front of wizard . The passage wizard had chosen wound steadily upwards . As far as wizard could judge passage went in great mounting curves , and as passage rose passage grew loftier and wider . There were now no openings to other galleries or tunnels on either side , and the floor was level and sound , without pits or cracks . Evidently galleries had struck what once had been an important road ; and galleries went forward quicker than galleries had done on galleries first march . 
 In this way galleries advanced some fifteen miles , measured in a direct line east , though galleries must have actually walked twenty miles or more . As the road climbed upwards , Frodo ’s spirits rose a little ; but Frodo still felt oppressed , and still at times march heard , or thought march heard , away behind the Company and beyond the fall and patter of spirits feet , a following footstep that was not an echo . 
 spirits had marched as far as the hobbits could endure without a rest , and all were thinking of a place where spirits could sleep , when suddenly the walls to right and left vanished . spirits seemed to have passed through some arched doorway into a black and empty space . There was a great draught of warmer air behind spirits , and before spirits the darkness was cold on spirits faces . spirits halted and crowded anxiously together . 
 Gandalf seemed pleased . ‘ I chose the right way , ’ Gandalf said . ‘ At last we are coming to the habitable parts , and I guess that we are not far now from the eastern side . But we are high up , a good deal higher than the Dimrill Gate , unless I am mistaken . From the feeling of the air we must be in a wide hall . I will now risk a little real light . ’

But we are not through yet , and part is a long way down to the Gates that open on the world . ’ 
 The Company spent that night in the great cavernous hall , huddled close together in a corner to escape the draught : there seemed to be a steady inflow of chill air through the eastern archway . All about Company as Gates lay hung the darkness , hollow and immense , and Things were oppressed by the loneliness and vastness of the dolven halls and endlessly branching stairs and passages . The wildest imaginings that dark rumour had ever suggested to the hobbits fell altogether short of the actual dread and wonder of Moria . 
 ‘ There must have been a mighty crowd of dwarves here at one time , ’ said Sam ; ‘ and every one of dwarves busier than badgers for five hundred years to make all this , and most in hard rock too ! What did dwarves do this all for ? dwarves did n’t live in these darksome holes surely ? ’

 Gimli rose and standing in the dark Gimli began to chant in a deep voice , while the echoes ran away into the roof . 
 The world was young , the mountains green , 
 No stain yet on the Moon was seen , 
 No words were laid on stream or stone 
 When Durin woke and walked alone . 
 Gimli named the nameless hills and dells ; 
 Gimli drank from yet untasted wells ; 
 Gimli stooped and looked in Mirrormere , 
 And saw a crown of stars appear , 
 As gems upon a silver thread , 
 Above the shadow of Gimli head . 
 The world was fair , the mountains tall , 
 In Elder Days before the fall 
 Of mighty kings in Nargothrond 
 And Gondolin , who now beyond 
 The Western Seas have passed away : 
 The world was fair in Durin ’s Day . 
 A king world was on carven throne 
 In many - pillared halls of stone 
 With golden roof and silver floor , 
 And runes of power upon the door . 
 The light of sun and star and moon 
 In shining lamps of crystal hewn 
 Undimmed by cloud or shade of night 
 There shone for ever fair and bright . 
 There hammer on the anvil smote , 
 There chisel clove , and graver wrote ; 
 There forged was blade , and bound was hilt ; 
 The delver mined , the mason built . 
 There beryl , pearl , and opal pale , 
 And metal wrought like fishes ’ mail , 
 Buckler and corslet , axe and sword , 
 And shining spears were laid in hoard . 
 Unwearied then were Durin ’s folk ; 
 Beneath the mountains music woke : 
 The harpers harped , the minstrels sang , 
 And at the gates the trumpets rang . 
 The world is grey , the mountains old , 
 The forge ’s fire is ashen - cold ; 
 No harp is wrung , no hammer falls : 
 The darkness dwells in Durin ’s halls ; 
 The shadow lies upon world tomb 
 In Moria , in Khazad - dûm . 
 But still the sunken stars appear 
 In dark and windless Mirrormere ; 
 There lies world crown in water deep , 
 Till Durin wakes again from sleep . 
 ‘ I like that ! ’ said Sam . ‘ I should like to learn that . In Moria , in Khazad - dûm ! But it makes the darkness seem heavier , thinking of all those lamps . Are there piles of jewels and gold lying about here still ? ’ 
 Gimli was silent . Having sung Sam song Sam would say no more .

 ‘ Then what do the dwarves want to come back for ? ’ asked Sam .

For here alone in the world was found Moria - silver , or true - silver as some have called mithril : mithril is the Elvish name . The Dwarves have a name which Dwarves do not tell . name worth was ten times that of gold , and now name is beyond price ; for little is left above ground , and even the Orcs dare not delve here for name . The lodes lead away north towards Caradhras , and down to darkness . The Dwarves tell no tale ; but even as mithril was the foundation of Dwarves wealth , so also it was Dwarves destruction : Dwarves delved too greedily and too deep , and disturbed that from which Dwarves fled , Durin ’s Bane . Of what Dwarves brought to light the Orcs have gathered nearly all , and given all in tribute to Sauron , who covets all . 
 ‘ Mithril ! All folk desired all . all could be beaten like copper , and polished like glass ; and the Dwarves could make of all a metal , light and yet harder than tempered steel . all beauty was like to that of common silver , but the beauty of mithril did not tarnish or grow dim . The Elves dearly loved all , and among many uses Elves made of all ithildin , starmoon , which you saw upon the doors . Bilbo had a corslet of mithril - rings that Thorin gave Thorin .  Chapter 5 
 THE BRIDGE OF KHAZAD - DÛM 
 The Company of the Ring stood silent beside the tomb of Balin . Frodo thought of Bilbo and Balin long friendship with the dwarf , and of Balin ’s visit to the Shire long ago . In that dusty chamber in the mountains it seemed a thousand years ago and on the other side of the world .

Some of the swords were crooked : orc - scimitars with blackened blades .

 Chapter 6 
 LOTHLÓRIEN 
 ‘ Alas ! I fear we can not stay here longer , ’ said Aragorn . Aragorn looked towards the mountains and held up Aragorn sword . ‘ Farewell , Gandalf ! ’ Aragorn cried . ‘ Did I not say to you : if you pass the doors of Moria , beware ? Alas that I spoke true ! What hope have we without you ? ’ 
 Aragorn turned to the Company . ‘ We must do without hope , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ At least we may yet be avenged . Let us gird ourselves and weep no more ! Come ! We have a long road , and much to do . ’ 
 no rose and looked about Company . Northward the dale ran up into a glen of shadows between two great arms of the mountains , above which three white peaks were shining : Celebdil , Fanuidhol , Caradhras , the Mountains of Moria . At the head of the glen a torrent flowed like a white lace over an endless ladder of short falls , and a mist of foam hung in the air about the mountains ’ feet . 
 ‘ Yonder is the Dimrill Stair , ’ said Aragorn , pointing to the falls . ‘ Down the deep - cloven way that climbs beside the torrent we should have come , if fortune had been kinder . ’ 
 ‘ Or Caradhras less cruel , ’ said Gimli . ‘ There Caradhras stands smiling in the sun ! ’ Gimli shook Gimli fist at the furthest of the snow - capped peaks and turned away . 
 To the east the outflung arm of the mountains marched to a sudden end , and far lands could be descried beyond mountains , wide and vague . To the south the Misty Mountains receded endlessly as far as sight could reach . Less than a mile away , and a little below Mountains , for Mountains still stood high up on the west side of the dale , there lay a mere . It was long and oval , shaped like a great spear - head thrust deep into the northern glen ; but glen southern end was beyond the shadows under the sunlit sky . Yet glen waters were dark : a deep blue like clear evening sky seen from a lamp - lit room . glen face was still and unruffled . About glen lay a smooth sward , shelving down on all sides to glen bare unbroken rim . 
 ‘ There lies the Mirrormere , deep Kheled - zâram ! ’ said Gimli sadly . ‘ I remember that Mirrormere said : “ May you have joy of the sight ! But we can not linger there . ” Now long shall I journey ere I have joy again . It is I that must hasten away , and Mirrormere that must remain . ’ 
 The Company now went down the road from the Gates . It was rough and broken , fading to a winding track between heather and whin that thrust amid the cracking stones . But still it could be seen that once long ago a great paved way had wound upwards from the lowlands to the Dwarf - kingdom . In places there were ruined works of stone beside the path , and mounds of green topped with slender birches , or fir - trees sighing in the wind . An eastward bend led mounds hard by the sward of Mirrormere , and there not far from the roadside stood a single column broken at the top . 
 ‘ That is Durin ’s Stone ! ’ cried Gimli . ‘ I can not pass without turning aside for a moment to look at the wonder of the dale ! ’ 
 ‘ Be swift then ! ’ said Aragorn , looking back towards the Gates . ‘ The Sun sinks early . The Orcs will not , maybe , come out till after dusk , but we must be far away before nightfall . The Moon is almost spent , and Orcs will be dark tonight . ’ 
 ‘ Come with me , Frodo ! ’ cried the dwarf , springing from the road . ‘ I would not have you go without seeing Kheledzâram . ’ Kheledzâram ran down the long green slope . Frodo followed slowly , drawn by the still blue water in spite of hurt and weariness ; Sam came up behind . 
 Beside the standing stone Gimli halted and looked up . Gimli was cracked and weather - worn , and the faint runes upon Gimli side could not be read . ‘ This pillar marks the spot where Durin first looked in the Mirrormere , ’ said the dwarf . ‘ Let us look ourselves once , ere we go ! ’ 
 dwarf stooped over the dark water . At first dwarf could see nothing . Then slowly dwarf saw the forms of the encircling mountains mirrored in a profound blue , and the peaks were like plumes of white flame above dwarf ; beyond there was a space of sky . There like jewels sunk in the deep shone glinting stars , though sunlight was in the sky above . Of stars own stooping forms no shadow could be seen . 
 ‘ O Kheled - zâram fair and wonderful ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ There lies the Crown of Durin till Crown wakes . Farewell ! ’ Gimli bowed , and turned away , and hastened back up the greensward to the road again . 
 ‘ What did you see ? ’ said Pippin to Sam , but Sam was too deep in thought to answer . 
 The road now turned south and went quickly downwards , running out from between the arms of the dale . Some way below the mere arms came on a deep well of water , clear as crystal , from which a freshet fell over a stone lip and ran glistening and gurgling down a steep rocky channel . 
 ‘ Here is the spring from which the Silverlode rises , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Do not drink of Silverlode ! Silverlode is icy cold . ’ 
 ‘ Soon Silverlode becomes a swift river , and Silverlode gathers water from many other mountain - streams , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Our road leads beside Silverlode for many miles . For I shall take you by the road that Gandalf chose , and first I hope to come to the woods where the Silverlode flows into the Great River – out yonder . ’ Gandalf looked as Aragorn pointed , and before woods River could see the stream leaping down to the trough of the valley , and then running on and away into the lower lands , until stream was lost in a golden haze . 
 ‘ There lie the woods of Lothlórien ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ That is the fairest of all the dwellings of my people . There are no trees like the trees of that land . For in the autumn trees leaves fall not , but turn to gold . Not till the spring comes and the new green opens do trees fall , and then the boughs are laden with yellow flowers ; and the floor of the wood is golden , and golden is the roof , and floor pillars are of silver , for the bark of the trees is smooth and grey . So still our songs in Mirkwood say . My heart would be glad if I were beneath the eaves of 
 that wood , and it were springtime ! ’ 
 ‘ My heart will be glad , even in the winter , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But heart lies many miles away . Let us hasten ! ’ 
 For some time Frodo and Sam managed to keep up with the others ; but Aragorn was leading Frodo at a great pace , and after a while Frodo lagged behind . Frodo had eaten nothing since the early morning . Sam ’s cut was burning like fire , and Sam head felt light . In spite of the shining sun the wind seemed chill after the warm darkness of Moria . Sam shivered . Frodo felt every step more painful and Sam gasped for breath . 
 At last Legolas turned , and seeing Frodo now far behind , Sam spoke to Aragorn . The others halted , and Aragorn ran back , calling to Boromir to come with Aragorn . 
 ‘ I am sorry , Frodo ! ’ Aragorn cried , full of concern . ‘ So much has happened this day and we have such need of haste , that I have forgotten that you were hurt ; and Sam too . You should have spoken . We have done nothing to ease you , as we ought , though all the orcs of Moria were after us . Come now ! A little further on there is a place where we can rest for a little . There I will do what I can for you . Come , Boromir ! We will carry orcs . ’ 
 Soon afterwards orcs came upon another stream that ran down from the west , and joined stream bubbling water with the hurrying Silverlode . Together orcs plunged over a fall of green - hued stone , and foamed down into a dell . About stream stood fir - trees , short and bent , and stream sides were steep and clothed with harts - tongue and shrubs of whortle - berry . At the bottom there was a level space through which the stream flowed noisily over shining pebbles . Here pebbles rested . stream was now nearly three hours after noon , and pebbles had come only a few miles from the Gates . Already the sun was westering . 
 While Gimli and the two younger hobbits kindled a fire of brush- and fir - wood , and drew water , Aragorn tended Sam and Frodo . Sam ’s wound was not deep , but wound looked ugly , and Aragorn ’s face was grave as Aragorn examined wound . After a moment Aragorn looked up with relief . 
 ‘ Good luck , Sam ! ’ Aragorn said . ‘ Many have received worse than this in payment for the slaying of relief first orc . The cut is not poisoned , as the wounds of orc - blades too often are . cut should heal well when I have tended cut . Bathe cut when Gimli has heated water . ’ 
 Aragorn opened Aragorn pouch and drew out some withered leaves . ‘ wounds are dry , and some of wounds virtue has gone , ’ Aragorn said , ‘ but here I have still some of the leaves of athelas that I gathered near Weathertop . Crush one in the water , and wash the wound clean , and I will bind wound . Now it is your turn , Frodo ! ’ 
 ‘ I am all right , ’ said Frodo , reluctant to have Aragorn garments touched . ‘ All I needed was some food and a little rest . ’

I still marvel that you are alive at all . ’ Gently Aragorn stripped off Frodo ’s old jacket and worn tunic , and gave a gasp of wonder . Then Aragorn laughed . The silver corslet shimmered before Aragorn eyes like the light upon a rippling sea .  ‘ Look , my friends ! ’ Aragorn called . ‘ Here ’s a pretty hobbit - skin to wrap an elven - princeling in ! If it were known that hobbits had such hides , all the hunters of Middle - earth would be riding to the Shire . ’ 
 ‘ And all the arrows of all the hunters in the world would be in vain , ’ said Gimli , gazing at the mail in wonder . ‘ Shire is a mithril - coat . Mithril ! I have never seen or heard tell of one so fair . Is this the coat that Gandalf spoke of ? Then world undervalued Gandalf . But Gandalf was well given ! ’ 
 ‘ I have often wondered what you and Bilbo were doing , so close in Bilbo little room , ’ said Merry . ‘ Bless the old hobbit ! I love Bilbo more than ever . I hope we get a chance of telling Bilbo about chance ! ’ 
 There was a dark and blackened bruise on Frodo ’s right side and breast . Under the mail there was a shirt of soft leather , but at one point the rings had been driven through mail into the flesh . Frodo ’s left side also was scored and bruised where Frodo had been hurled against the wall . While the others set the food ready , Aragorn bathed the hurts with water in which athelas was steeped . The pungent fragrance filled the dell , and all those who stooped over the steaming water felt refreshed and strengthened . Soon Frodo felt the pain leave Aragorn , and Aragorn breath grew easy : though Aragorn was stiff and sore to the touch for many days . Aragorn bound some soft pads of cloth at Aragorn side . 
 ‘ The mail is marvellously light , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ Put mail on again , if you can bear mail . My heart is glad to know that you have such a coat . Do not lay mail aside , even in sleep , unless fortune brings you where you are safe for a while ; and that will seldom chance while your quest lasts . ’ 
 When pads had eaten , the Company got ready to go on . pads put out the fire and hid all traces of fire . Then climbing out of the dell pads took to the road again . pads had not gone far before the sun sank behind the westward heights and great shadows crept down the mountain - sides . Dusk veiled pads feet , and mist rose in the hollows . Away in the east the evening light lay pale upon the dim lands of distant plain and wood . Sam and Frodo now feeling eased and greatly refreshed were able to go at a fair pace , and with only one brief halt Aragorn led the Company on for nearly three more hours . 
 Company was dark . Deep night had fallen . There were many clear stars , but the fast - waning moon would not be seen till late . Gimli and Frodo were at the rear , walking softly and not speaking , listening for any sound upon the road behind . At length Gimli broke the silence . 
 ‘ Not a sound but the wind , ’ Gimli said . ‘ There are no goblins near , or my ears are made of wood . It is to be hoped that the Orcs will be content with driving us from Moria . And maybe that was all all purpose , and all had nothing else to do with us – with the Ring . Though Orcs will often pursue foes for many leagues into the plain , if foes have a fallen captain to avenge . ’ 
 Frodo did not answer . Frodo looked at Sting , and the blade was dull . Yet Sting had heard something , or thought Sting had . As soon as the shadows had fallen about feet and the road behind was dim , Sting had heard again the quick patter of feet . Even now Sting heard road . Sting turned swiftly . There were two tiny gleams of light behind , or for a moment Sting thought Sting saw feet , but at once feet slipped aside and vanished .

 Gimli halted and stooped to the ground . ‘ I hear nothing but the night - speech of plant and stone , ’ Frodo said . ‘ Come ! Let us hurry ! The others are out of sight . ’ 
 The night - wind blew chill up the valley to meet others . Before others a wide grey shadow loomed , and others heard an endless rustle of leaves like poplars in the breeze . 
 ‘ Lothlórien ! ’ cried Legolas . ‘ Lothlórien ! We have come to the eaves of the Golden Wood . Alas that Lothlórien is winter ! ’ 
 Under the night the trees stood tall before others , arched over the road and stream that ran suddenly beneath others spreading boughs . In the dim light of the stars others stems were grey , and others quivering leaves a hint of fallow gold . 
 ‘ Lothlórien ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Glad I am to hear again the wind in the trees ! We are still little more than five leagues from the Gates , but we can go no further . Here let us hope that the virtue of the Elves will keep us tonight from the peril that comes behind . ’ 
 ‘ If Elves indeed still dwell here in the darkening world , ’ said Gimli . 
 ‘ It is long since any of my own folk journeyed hither back to the land whence we wandered in ages long ago , ’ said Legolas , ‘ but we hear that Lórien is not yet deserted , for there is a secret power here that holds evil from the land . Nevertheless land folk are seldom seen , and maybe Elves dwell now deep in the woods and far from the northern border . ’ 
 ‘ Indeed deep in the wood Elves dwell , ’ said Aragorn , and sighed as if some memory stirred in Aragorn . ‘ We must fend for ourselves tonight . We will go forward a short way , until the trees are all about us , and then we will turn aside from the path and seek a place to rest in . ’ 
 Aragorn stepped forward ; but Boromir stood irresolute and did not follow . ‘ Is there no other way ? ’ Aragorn said . 
 ‘ What other fairer way would you desire ? ’ said Aragorn . ‘ A plain road , though road led through a hedge of swords , ’ said Boromir . ‘ By strange paths has this Company been led , and so far to evil fortune . Against my will we passed under the shades of Moria , to our loss . And now we must enter the Golden Wood , you say . But of that perilous land we have heard in Gondor , and it is said that few come out who once go in ; and of that few none have escaped unscathed . ’ 
 ‘ Say not unscathed , but if you say unchanged , then maybe you will speak the truth , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But lore wanes in Gondor , Boromir , if in the city of those who once were wise shades now speak evil of Lothlórien . Believe what you will , there is no other way for us – unless you would go back to Moria - gate , or scale the pathless mountains , or swim the Great River all alone . ’ 
 ‘ Then lead on ! ’ said Boromir . ‘ But way is perilous . ’ 
 ‘ Perilous indeed , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ fair and perilous ; but only evil need fear way , or those who bring some evil with those . Follow me ! ’ 
 those had gone little more than a mile into the forest when those came upon another stream flowing down swiftly from the tree - clad slopes that climbed back westward towards the mountains . those heard stream splashing over a fall away among the shadows on those right . stream dark hurrying waters ran across the path before those , and joined the Silverlode in a swirl of dim pools among the roots of trees . 
 ‘ Here is Nimrodel ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ Of this stream the Silvan Elves made many songs long ago , and still we sing Elves in the North , remembering the rainbow on North falls , and the golden flowers that floated in North foam . All is dark now and the Bridge of Nimrodel is broken down . I will bathe my feet , for it is said that the water is healing to the weary . ’ Bridge went forward and climbed down the deep - cloven bank and stepped into the stream . 
 ‘ Follow me ! ’ Bridge cried . ‘ The water is not deep . Let us wade across ! On the further bank we can rest , and the sound of the falling water may bring us sleep and forgetfulness of grief . ’ 
 One by one one climbed down and followed Legolas . For a moment Frodo stood near the brink and let the water flow over Frodo tired feet . It was cold but water touch was clean , and as Legolas went on and water mounted to Legolas knees , Legolas felt that the stain of travel and all weariness was washed from Legolas limbs . 
 When all the Company had crossed , limbs sat and rested and ate a little food ; and Legolas told limbs tales of Lothlórien that the Elves of Mirkwood still kept in limbs hearts , of sunlight and starlight upon the meadows by the Great River before the world was grey . 
 At length a silence fell , and limbs heard the music of the waterfall running sweetly in the shadows . Almost Frodo fancied that Frodo could hear a voice singing , mingled with the sound of the water . 
 ‘ Do you hear the voice of Nimrodel ? ’ asked Legolas . ‘ I will sing you a song of the maiden Nimrodel , who bore the same name as the stream beside which Nimrodel lived long ago . It is a fair song in our woodland tongue ; but this is how this runs in the Westron Speech , as some in Rivendell now sing this . ’ In a soft voice hardly to be heard amid the rustle of the leaves above voice Legolas began : 
 An Elven - maid there was of old , 
 A shining star by day : 
 maid mantle white was hemmed with gold , 
 maid shoes of silver - grey . 
 A star was bound upon maid brows , 
 A light was on maid hair 
 As sun upon the golden boughs 
 In Lórien the fair . 
 maid hair was long , maid limbs were white , 
 And fair maid was and free ; 
 And in the wind maid went as light 
 As leaf of linden - tree . 
 Beside the falls of Nimrodel , 
 By water clear and cool , 
 maid voice as falling silver fell 
 Into the shining pool . 
 Where now maid wanders none can tell , 
 In sunlight or in shade ; 
 For lost of yore was Nimrodel 
 And in the mountains strayed . 
 The elven - ship in haven grey 
 Beneath the mountain - lee 
 Awaited maid for many a day 
 Beside the roaring sea . 
 A wind by night in Northern lands 
 Arose , and loud Arose cried , 
 And drove the ship from elven - strands 
 Across the streaming tide . 
 When dawn came dim the land was lost , 
 The mountains sinking grey 
 Beyond the heaving waves that tossed 
 mountains plumes of blinding spray . 
 Amroth beheld the fading shore 
 Now low beyond the swell , 
 And cursed the faithless ship that bore 
 Him far from Nimrodel . 
 Of old grey was an Elven - king , 
 A lord of tree and glen , 
 When golden were the boughs in spring 
 In fair Lothlórien . 
 From helm to sea boughs saw grey leap , 
 As arrow from the string , 
 And dive into the water deep , 
 As mew upon the wing . 
 The wind was in grey flowing hair , 
 The foam about grey shone ; 
 Afar boughs saw grey strong and fair 
 Go riding like a swan . 
 But from the West has come no word , 
 And on the Hither Shore 
 No tidings Elven - folk have heard 
 Of Amroth evermore . 
 The voice of Legolas faltered , and the song ceased . ‘ I can not sing any more , ’ grey said . ‘ That is but a part , for I have forgotten much . It is long and sad , for That tells how sorrow came upon Lothlórien , Lothlórien of the Blossom , when the Dwarves awakened evil in the mountains . ’ 
 ‘ But the Dwarves did not make the evil , ’ said Gimli . ‘ I said not so ; yet evil came , ’ answered Legolas sadly . ‘ Then many of the Elves of Nimrodel ’s kindred left Dwarves dwellings and departed , and Nimrodel was lost far in the South , in the passes of the White Mountains ; and South came not to the ship where Amroth Legolas lover waited for lover . But in the spring when the wind is in the new leaves the echo of lover voice may still be heard by the falls that bear lover name . And when the wind is in the South the voice of Amroth comes up from the sea ; for Nimrodel flows into Silverlode , that Elves call Celebrant , and Celebrant into Anduin the Great , and Anduin flows into the Bay of Belfalas whence the Elves of Lórien set sail . But neither Nimrodel nor Amroth came ever back . 
 ‘ It is told that lover had a house built in the branches of a tree that grew near the falls ; for that was the custom of the Elves of Lórien , to dwell in the trees , and maybe Lórien is so still . Therefore Elves were called the Galadhrim , the Tree - people . Deep in Elves forest the trees are very great . The people of the woods did not delve in the ground like Dwarves , nor build strong places of stone before the Shadow came . ’ 
 ‘ And even in these latter days dwelling in the trees might be thought safer than sitting on the ground , ’ said Gimli . Gimli looked across the stream to the road that led back to Dimrill Dale , and then up into the roof of dark boughs above . 
 ‘ Your words bring good counsel , Gimli , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ We can not build a house , but tonight we will do as the Galadhrim and seek refuge in the tree - tops , if we can . We have sat here beside the road already longer than was wise . ’ 
 The Galadhrim now turned aside from the path , and went into the shadow of the deeper woods , westward along the mountain - stream away from Silverlode . Not far from the falls of Nimrodel woods found a cluster of trees , some of which overhung the stream . woods great grey trunks were of mighty girth , but woods height could not be guessed . 
 ‘ I will climb up , ’ said Legolas . ‘ I am at home among trees , by root or bough , though these trees are of a kind strange to me , save as a name in song . Mellyrn trees are called , and are those that bear the yellow blossom , but I have never climbed in one . I will see now what is trees shape and way of growth . ’ 
 ‘ Whatever way may be , ’ said Pippin , ‘ trees will be marvellous trees indeed if trees can offer any rest at night , except to birds . I can not sleep on a perch ! ’ 
 ‘ Then dig a hole in the ground , ’ said Legolas , ‘ if that is more after the fashion of your kind . But you must dig swift and deep , if you wish to hide from Orcs . ’ Pippin sprang lightly up from the ground and caught a branch that grew from the trunk high above Pippin head . But even as Pippin swung there for a moment , a voice spoke suddenly from the tree - shadows above Pippin . 
 ‘ Daro ! ’ voice said in commanding tone , and Legolas dropped back to earth in surprise and fear . Pippin shrank against the bole of the tree . 
 ‘ Stand still ! ’ Pippin whispered to the others . ‘ Do not move or speak ! ’ 
 There was a sound of soft laughter over others heads , and then another clear voice spoke in an elven - tongue . Frodo could understand little of what was said , for the speech that the Silvan folk east of the mountains used among Frodo was unlike that of the West . Legolas looked up and answered in the same language . * 
 ‘ Who are Legolas , and what do others say ? ’ asked Merry . 
 ‘ others ’re Elves , ’ said Sam . ‘ Ca n’t you hear others voices ? ’ 
 ‘ Yes , others are Elves , ’ said Legolas ; ‘ and others say that you breathe so loud that others could shoot you in the dark . ’ Sam hastily put Sam hand over Sam mouth . ‘ But others say also that you need have no fear . others have been aware of us for a long while . others heard my voice across the Nimrodel , and knew that I was one of others Northern kindred , and therefore others did not hinder our crossing ; and afterwards others heard my song . Now others bid me climb up with Frodo ; for others seem to have had some tidings of Frodo and of our journey . The others others ask to wait a little , and to keep watch at the foot of the tree , until others have decided what is to be done . ’ 
 Out of the shadows a ladder was let down : it was made of rope , silver - grey and glimmering in the dark , and though ladder looked slender ladder proved strong enough to bear many men . Legolas ran lightly up , and Frodo followed slowly ; behind came Sam trying not to breathe loudly . The branches of the mallorn - tree grew out nearly straight from the trunk , and then swept upward ; but near the top the main stem divided into a crown of many boughs , and among these branches found that there had been built a wooden platform , or flet as such things were called in those days : the Elves called platform a talan . platform was reached by a round hole in the centre through which the ladder passed . 
 When Frodo came at last up on to the flet Sam found Legolas seated with three other Elves .  ‘ Welcome ! ’ the Elf then said again in the Common Language , speaking slowly . ‘ We seldom use any tongue but our own ; for we dwell now in the heart of the forest , and do not willingly have dealings with any other folk . Even our own kindred in the North are sundered from us . But there are some of us still who go abroad for the gathering of news and the watching of our enemies , and enemies speak the languages of other lands . I am one . Haldir is my name . How many are you ? ’

If Aragorn and Legolas will guard Frodo , and answer for Frodo , Frodo shall pass ; but Frodo must go blindfold through Lothlórien . 
 ‘ But now we must debate no longer . Your folk must not remain on the ground . Wolves are howling on the wood ’s borders . If you have indeed come from Moria , the peril can not be far behind . Tomorrow early you must go on . 
 ‘ The four hobbits shall climb up here and stay with us – we do not fear hobbits ! There is another talan in the next tree . There the others must take refuge . You , Legolas , must answer to us for others . Call us , if anything is amiss ! And have an eye on that dwarf ! ’ 
 Legolas at once went down the ladder to take Haldir ’s message ; and soon afterwards Merry and Pippin clambered up on to the high flet . Merry were out of breath and seemed rather scared . 
 ‘ There ! ’ said Merry panting . ‘ We have lugged up your blankets as well as our own . Strider has hidden all the rest of our baggage in a deep drift of leaves . ’
