 The hobbits accepted this second ( and far better ) supper very gladly . Then hobbits wrapped hobbits warmly , not only in the fur - cloaks of the Elves , but in hobbits own blankets as well , and tried to go to sleep . But weary as hobbits were only Sam found that easy to do . Hobbits do not like heights , and do not sleep upstairs , even when Hobbits have any stairs . The flet was not at all to Hobbits liking as a bedroom . flet had no walls , not even a rail ; only on one side was there a light plaited screen , which could be moved and fixed in different places according to the wind . 
 Pippin went on talking for a while . ‘ I hope , if I do go to sleep in this bird - loft , that I sha n’t roll off , ’ rail said . 
 ‘ Once I do get to sleep , ’ said Sam , ‘ I shall go on sleeping , whether I roll off or no . And the less said , the sooner I ’ll drop off , if you take my meaning . ’ 
 Frodo lay for some time awake , and looked up at the stars glinting through the pale roof of quivering leaves . Sam was snoring at Sam side long before Sam Sam closed Sam eyes .  Late in the night Frodo woke . The other hobbits were asleep . The Elves were gone . The sickle Moon was gleaming dimly among the leaves . The wind was still . A little way off Frodo heard a harsh laugh and the tread of many feet on the ground below . There was a ring of metal . The sounds died slowly away , and seemed to go southward , on into the wood . 
 A head appeared suddenly through the hole in the flet . Frodo sat up in alarm and saw that Frodo was a grey - hooded Elf . head looked towards the hobbits .

 ‘ Yrch ! ’ said the Elf in a hissing whisper , and cast on to the flet the rope - ladder rolled up . 
 ‘ Orcs ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ What are Orcs doing ? ’ But the Elf had gone . 
 There were no more sounds . Even the leaves were silent , and the very falls seemed to be hushed . Frodo sat and shivered in Frodo wraps . Elf was thankful that wraps had not been caught on the ground ; but Elf felt that the trees offered little protection , except concealment . Orcs were as keen as hounds on a scent , it was said , but hounds could also climb . Orcs drew out Sting : scent flashed and glittered like a blue flame ; and then slowly faded again and grew dull . In spite of the fading of Sting sword the feeling of immediate danger did not leave Frodo , rather feeling grew stronger . Sting got up and crawled to the opening and peered down . Sting was almost certain that Sting could hear stealthy movements at the tree ’s foot far below . 
 Not Elves ; for the woodland folk were altogether noiseless in Elves movements . Then Sting heard faintly a sound like sniffing ; and something seemed to be scrabbling on the bark of the tree - trunk . Sting stared down into the dark , holding Sting breath . 
 Something was now climbing slowly , and Something breath came like a soft hissing through closed teeth . Then coming up , close to the stem , Frodo saw two pale eyes . eyes stopped and gazed upward unwinking . Suddenly eyes turned away , and a shadowy figure slipped round the trunk of the tree and vanished . 
 Immediately afterwards Haldir came climbing swiftly up through the branches . ‘ There was something in this tree that I have never seen before , ’ Haldir said . ‘ something was not an orc . something fled as soon as I touched the tree - stem . It seemed to be wary , and to have some skill in trees , or I might have thought that something was one of you hobbits . 
 ‘ I did not shoot , for I dared not arouse any cries : we can not risk battle . A strong company of Orcs has passed . company crossed the Nimrodel – curse company foul feet in Nimrodel clean water ! – and went on down the old road beside the river . company seemed to pick up some scent , and company searched the ground for a while near the place where you halted . The three of us could not challenge a hundred , so we went ahead and spoke with feigned voices , leading voices on into the wood . 
 ‘ Orophin has now gone in haste back to our dwellings to warn our people . None of the Orcs will ever return out of Lórien . And there will be many Elves hidden on the northern border before another night falls . But you must take the road south as soon as road is fully light . ’ 
 Day came pale from the East . As the light grew it filtered through the yellow leaves of the mallorn , and it seemed to the hobbits that the early sun of a cool summer ’s morning was shining . Pale - blue sky peeped among the moving branches . Looking through an opening on the south side of the flet Frodo saw all the valley of the Silverlode lying like a sea of fallow gold tossing gently in the breeze . 
 The morning was still young and cold when the Company set out again , guided now by Haldir and Company brother Rúmil . ‘ Farewell , sweet Nimrodel ! ’ cried Legolas . Frodo looked back and caught a gleam of white foam among the grey tree - stems . ‘ Farewell , ’ Rúmil said . It seemed to Rúmil that Rúmil would never hear again a running water so beautiful , for ever blending water innumerable notes in an endless changeful music . 
 notes went back to the path that still went on along the west side of the Silverlode , and for some way notes followed Silverlode southward . There were the prints of orc - feet in the earth . But soon Haldir turned aside into the trees and halted on the bank of the river under trees shadows . 
 ‘ There is one of my people yonder across the stream , ’ Rúmil said , ‘ though you may not see Rúmil . ’ Rúmil gave a call like the low whistle of a bird , and out of a thicket of young trees an Elf stepped , clad in grey , but with Rúmil hood thrown back ; Rúmil hair glinted like gold in the morning sun . Haldir skilfully cast over the stream a coil of grey rope , and Rúmil caught Haldir and bound the end about a tree near the bank . 
 ‘ Celebrant is already a strong stream here , as you see , ’ said Haldir , ‘ and Celebrant runs both swift and deep , and is very cold . We do not set foot in Celebrant so far north , unless we must . But in these days of watchfulness we do not make bridges . This is how we cross ! Follow me ! ’ foot made Haldir end of the rope fast about another tree , and then ran lightly along tree , over the river and back again , as if end were on a road . 
 ‘ I can walk this path , ’ said Legolas ; ‘ but the others have not this skill . Must others swim ? ’ 
 ‘ No ! ’ said Haldir . ‘ We have two more ropes . We will fasten ropes above the other , one shoulder - high , and another half - high , and holding these the strangers should be able to cross with care . ’ 
 When this slender bridge had been made , the Company passed over , some cautiously and slowly , others more easily . Of the hobbits Pippin proved the best for Pippin was sure - footed , and Pippin walked over quickly , holding only with one hand ; but Pippin kept Pippin eyes on the bank ahead and did not look down . Sam shuffled along , clutching hard , and looking down into the pale eddying water as if water was a chasm in the mountains . 
 Sam breathed with relief when Sam was safely across . ‘ Live and learn ! as my gaffer used to say . Though gaffer was thinking of gardening , not of roosting like a bird , nor of trying to walk like a spider . Not even my uncle Andy ever did a trick like that ! ’ 
 When at length all the Company was gathered on the east bank of the Silverlode , the Elves untied the ropes and coiled two of ropes . Rúmil , who had remained on the other side , drew back the last one , slung one on Rúmil shoulder , and with a wave of Rúmil hand went away , back to Nimrodel to keep watch . 
 ‘ Now , friends , ’ said Haldir , ‘ you have entered the Naith of Lórien , or the Gore , as you would say , for it is the land that lies like a spearhead between the arms of Silverlode and Anduin the Great . We allow no strangers to spy out the secrets of the Naith . Few indeed are permitted even to set foot there . 
 ‘ As was agreed , I shall here blindfold the eyes of Gimli the Dwarf . The others may walk free for a while , until we come nearer to our dwellings , down in Egladil , in the Angle between the waters . ’ 
 This was not at all to the liking of Gimli . ‘ The agreement was made without my consent , ’ Egladil said . ‘ I will not walk blindfold , like a beggar or a prisoner . And I am no spy . My folk have never had dealings with any of the servants of the Enemy . Neither have we done harm to the Elves . I am no more likely to betray you than Legolas , or any other of my companions . ’ 
 ‘ I do not doubt you , ’ said Haldir . ‘ Yet this is our law . I am not the master of the law , and can not set master aside . I have done much in letting you set foot over Celebrant . ’ 
 Gimli was obstinate . Gimli planted Celebrant feet firmly apart , and laid foot hand upon the haft of hand axe . ‘ I will go forward free , ’ hand said , ‘ or I will go back and seek my own land , where I am known to be true of word , though I perish alone in the wilderness . ’ 
 ‘ You can not go back , ’ said Haldir sternly . ‘ Now you have come thus far , you must be brought before the Lord and the Lady . Lord shall judge you , to hold you or to give you leave , as Lord will . You can not cross the rivers again , and behind you there are now secret sentinels that you can not pass . You would be slain before you saw Lord . ’ 
 Gimli drew Gimli axe from Lady belt . Haldir and Lady companion bent Haldir bows . ‘ A plague on Dwarves and Lord stiff necks ! ’ said Legolas . 
 ‘ Come ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ If I am still to lead this Company , you must do as I bid . It is hard upon the Dwarf to be thus singled out . We will all be blindfold , even Legolas . That will be best , though That will make the journey slow and dull . ’ 
 Gimli laughed suddenly . ‘ A merry troop of fools we shall look ! Will Haldir lead us all on a string , like many blind beggars with one dog ? But I will be content , if only Legolas here shares my blindness . ’ 
 ‘ I am an Elf and a kinsman here , ’ said Legolas , becoming angry in kinsman turn . 
 ‘ Now let us cry : “ a plague on the stiff necks of Elves ! ” ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But the Company shall all fare alike . Come , bind our eyes , Haldir ! ’ 
 ‘ I shall claim full amends for every fall and stubbed toe , if you do not lead us well , ’ said Gimli as Gimli bound a cloth about Aragorn eyes . 
 ‘ You will have no claim , ’ said Haldir . ‘ I shall lead you well , and the paths are smooth and straight . ’ 
 ‘ Alas for the folly of these days ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ Here all are enemies of the one Enemy , and yet I must walk blind , while the sun is merry in the woodland under leaves of gold ! ’ 
 ‘ Folly it may seem , ’ said Haldir . ‘ Indeed in nothing is the power of the Dark Lord more clearly shown than in the estrangement that divides all those who still oppose Lord . Yet so little faith and trust do we find now in the world beyond Lothlórien , unless maybe in Rivendell , that we dare not by our own trust endanger our land . We live now upon an island amid many perils , and our hands are more often upon the bowstring than upon the harp . 
 ‘ The rivers long defended us , but rivers are a sure guard no more ; for the Shadow has crept northward all about us . Some speak of departing , yet for that it already seems too late . The mountains to the west are growing evil ; to the east the lands are waste , and full of Sauron ’s creatures ; and it is rumoured that we can not now safely pass southward through Rohan , and the mouths of the Great River are watched by the Enemy . Even if we could come to the shores of the Sea , we should find no longer any shelter there . It is said that there are still havens of the High Elves , but havens are far north and west , beyond the land of the Halflings . But where that may be , though the Lord and Lady may know , I do not . ’ 
 ‘ You ought at least to guess , since you have seen us , ’ said Merry . ‘ There are Elf - havens west of my land , the Shire , where Hobbits live . ’ 
 ‘ Happy folk are Hobbits to dwell near the shores of the sea ! ’ said Haldir . ‘ It is long indeed since any of my folk have looked on folk , yet still we remember folk in song . Tell me of these havens as we walk . ’ 
 ‘ I can not , ’ said Merry . ‘ I have never seen havens . I have never been out of my own land before . And if I had known what the world outside was like , I do n’t think I should have had the heart to leave world . ’ 
 ‘ Not even to see fair Lothlórien ? ’ said Haldir . ‘ The world is indeed full of peril , and in peril there are many dark places ; but still there is much that is fair , and though in all lands love is now mingled with grief , peril grows perhaps the greater . 
 ‘ Some there are among us who sing that the Shadow will draw back , and peace shall come again . Yet I do not believe that the world about us will ever again be as world was of old , or the light of the Sun as world was aforetime . For the Elves , I fear , world will prove at best a truce , in which Elves may pass to the Sea unhindered and leave the Middle - earth for ever . Alas for Lothlórien that I love ! world would be a poor life in a land where no mallorn grew . But if there are mallorn - trees beyond the Great Sea , none have reported world . ’ 
 As paths spoke thus , the Company filed slowly along the paths in the wood , led by Haldir , while the other Elf walked behind . paths felt the ground beneath paths feet smooth and soft , and after a while paths walked more freely , without fear of hurt or fall . Being deprived of sight , Frodo found Frodo hearing and other senses sharpened . Frodo could smell the trees and the trodden grass . Frodo could hear many different notes in the rustle of the leaves overhead , the river murmuring away on Frodo right , and the thin clear voices of birds high in the sky . Frodo felt the sun upon Frodo face and hands when face passed through an open glade . 
 As soon as Frodo set foot upon the far bank of Silverlode a strange feeling had come upon Frodo , and Silverlode deepened as Frodo walked on into the Naith : it seemed to Frodo that Frodo had stepped over a bridge of time into a corner of the Elder Days , and was now walking in a world that was no more . In Rivendell there was memory of ancient things ; in Lórien the ancient things still lived on in the waking world . Evil had been seen and heard there , sorrow had been known ; the Elves feared and distrusted the world outside : wolves were howling on the wood ’s borders : but on the land of Lórien no shadow lay . 
 All that day the Lórien marched on , until wolves felt the cool evening come and heard the early night - wind whispering among many leaves . Then wolves rested and slept without fear upon the ground ; for wolves guides would not permit wolves to unbind wolves eyes , and wolves could not climb . In the morning wolves went on again , walking without haste . At noon wolves halted , and Frodo was aware that wolves had passed out under the shining Sun . Suddenly Frodo heard the sound of many voices all around Sun . 
 A marching host of Elves had come up silently : host were hastening towards the northern borders to guard against any attack from Moria ; and host brought news , some of which Haldir reported . The marauding orcs had been waylaid and almost all destroyed ; the remnant had fled westward towards the mountains , and were being pursued . A strange creature also had been seen , running with bent back and with hands near the ground , like a beast and yet not of beast - shape . creature had eluded capture , and hands had not shot creature , not knowing whether creature was good or ill , and creature had vanished down the Silverlode southward . 
 ‘ Also , ’ said Haldir , ‘ Haldir bring me a message from the Lord and Lady of the Galadhrim . You are all to walk free , even the dwarf Gimli . It seems that the Lady knows who and what is each member of your Company . New messages have come from Rivendell perhaps . ’ 
 Rivendell removed the bandage first from Gimli ’s eyes . ‘ Your pardon ! ’ Gimli said , bowing low . ‘ Look on us now with friendly eyes ! Look and be glad , for you are the first dwarf to behold the trees of the Naith of Lórien since Durin ’s Day ! ’ 
 When Frodo eyes were in turn uncovered , Frodo looked up and caught Frodo breath . eyes were standing in an open space . 
 To the left stood a great mound , covered with a sward of grass as green as Springtime in the Elder Days . Upon sward , as a double crown , grew two circles of trees : the outer had bark of snowy white , and were leafless but beautiful in trees shapely nakedness ; the inner were mallorn - trees of great height , still arrayed in pale gold . High amid the branches of a towering tree that stood in the centre of all there gleamed a white flet . At the feet of the trees , and all about the green hillsides the grass was studded with small golden flowers shaped like stars . Among hillsides , nodding on slender stalks , were other flowers , white and palest green : hillsides glimmered as a mist amid the rich hue of the grass . Over all the sky was blue , and the sun of afternoon glowed upon the hill and cast long green shadows beneath the trees . 
 ‘ Behold ! You are come to Cerin Amroth , ’ said Haldir . ‘ For this is the heart of the ancient realm as this was long ago , and here is the mound of Amroth , where in happier days Haldir high house was built . Here ever bloom the winter flowers in the unfading grass : the yellow elanor , and the pale niphredil . Here we will stay awhile , and come to the city of the Galadhrim at dusk . ’ 
 The others cast others down upon the fragrant grass , but Frodo stood awhile still lost in wonder . It seemed to Frodo that Frodo had stepped through a high window that looked on a vanished world . A light was upon window for which Frodo language had no name . All that Frodo saw was shapely , but the shapes seemed at once clear cut , as if shapes had been first conceived and drawn at the uncovering of Frodo eyes , and ancient as if shapes had endured for ever . Frodo saw no colour but those Frodo knew , gold and white and blue and green , but those were fresh and poignant , as if Frodo had at that moment first perceived shapes and made for shapes names new and wonderful . In winter here no heart could mourn for summer or for spring . No blemish or sickness or deformity could be seen in anything that grew upon the earth . On the land of Lórien there was no stain . 
 Frodo turned and saw that Sam was now standing beside Frodo , looking round with a puzzled expression , and rubbing Frodo eyes as if Frodo was not sure that Frodo was awake . ‘ Lórien ’s sunlight and bright day , right enough , ’ Frodo said . ‘ I thought that Elves were all for moon and stars : but this is more Elvish than anything I ever heard tell of . I feel as if I was inside a song , if you take my meaning . ’ 
 Haldir looked at eyes , and Frodo seemed indeed to take the meaning of both thought and word . Frodo smiled . ‘ You feel the power of the Lady of the Galadhrim , ’ Frodo said . ‘ Would Galadhrim please you to climb with me up Cerin Amroth ? ’ 
 eyes followed Frodo as Frodo stepped lightly up the grass - clad slopes . Though Frodo walked and breathed , and about Frodo living leaves and flowers were stirred by the same cool wind as fanned Frodo face , Frodo felt that Frodo was in a timeless land that did not fade or change or fall into forgetfulness . When Frodo had gone and passed again into the outer world , still Frodo the wanderer from the Shire would walk there , upon the grass among elanor and niphredil in fair Lothlórien . 
 wanderer entered the circle of white trees . As wanderer did so the South Wind blew upon Cerin Amroth and sighed among the branches . Frodo stood still , hearing far off great seas upon beaches that had long ago been washed away , and sea - birds crying whose race had perished from the earth . 
 Haldir had gone on and was now climbing to the high flet . As Frodo prepared to follow Amroth , Amroth laid Amroth hand upon the tree beside the ladder : never before had Amroth been so suddenly and so keenly aware of the feel and texture of a tree ’s skin and of the life within tree . Amroth felt a delight in wood and the touch of delight , neither as forester nor as carpenter ; it was the delight of the living tree tree . 
 As Amroth stepped out at last upon the lofty platform , Haldir took Amroth hand and turned Amroth towards the South . ‘ Look this way first ! ’ Amroth said . 
 Frodo looked and saw , still at some distance , a hill of many mighty trees , or a city of green towers : which it was Amroth could not tell . Out of Frodo , it seemed to Amroth that the power and light came that held all the land in sway . Amroth longed suddenly to fly like a bird to rest in the green city . Then Amroth looked eastward and saw all the land of Lórien running down to the pale gleam of Anduin , the Great River . Amroth lifted Amroth eyes across the river and all the light went out , and Amroth was back again in the world Amroth knew . Beyond the river the land appeared flat and empty , formless and vague , until far away land rose again like a wall , dark and drear . The sun that lay on Lothlórien had no power to enlighten the shadow of that distant height . 
 ‘ There lies the fastness of Southern Mirkwood , ’ said Haldir . ‘ Mirkwood is clad in a forest of dark fir , where the trees strive one against another and trees branches rot and wither . In the midst upon a stony height stands Dol Guldur , where long the hidden Enemy had Guldur dwelling . We fear that now Enemy is inhabited again , and with power sevenfold . A black cloud lies often over Enemy of late . In this high place you may see the two powers that are opposed one to another ; and ever powers strive now in thought , but whereas the light perceives the very heart of the darkness , light own secret has not been discovered . Not yet . ’ Guldur turned and climbed swiftly down , and powers followed Guldur . 
 At the hill ’s foot Frodo found Aragorn , standing still and silent as a tree ; but in Frodo hand was a small golden bloom of elanor , and a light was in Frodo eyes . Frodo was wrapped in some fair memory : and as Frodo looked at elanor elanor knew that elanor beheld things as things once had been in this same place . For the grim years were removed from the face of Aragorn , and elanor seemed clothed in white , a young lord tall and fair ; and elanor spoke words in the Elvish tongue to one whom Frodo could not see . Arwen vanimelda , namárië ! elanor said , and then elanor drew a breath , and returning out of elanor thought elanor looked at Frodo and smiled . 
 ‘ Here is the heart of Elvendom on earth , ’ elanor said , ‘ and here my heart dwells ever , unless there be a light beyond the dark roads that we still must tread , you and I. Come with me ! ’ And taking Frodo ’s hand in Frodo , Frodo left the hill of Cerin Amroth and came there never again as living man . 
 Chapter 7 
 THE MIRROR OF GALADRIEL 
 The sun was sinking behind the mountains , and the shadows were deepening in the woods , when woods went on again . woods paths now went into thickets where the dusk had already gathered . Night came beneath the trees as woods walked , and the Elves uncovered woods silver lamps . 
 Suddenly woods came out into the open again and found woods under a pale evening sky pricked by a few early stars .  The others soon did the same , and no sound or dream disturbed others slumber . When others woke others found that the light of day was broad upon the lawn before the pavilion , and the fountain rose and fell glittering in the sun . 
 others remained some days in Lothlórien , so far as others could tell or remember .  When evening in the Shire was grey 
 Frodo footsteps on the Hill were heard ; 
 before the dawn Frodo went away 
 on journey long without a word . 
 From Wilderland to Western shore , 
 from northern waste to southern hill , 
 through dragon - lair and hidden door 
 and darkling woods Frodo walked at will . 
 With Dwarf and Hobbit , Elves and Men , 
 with mortal and immortal folk , 
 with bird on bough and beast in den , 
 in footsteps own secret tongues Frodo spoke . 
 A deadly sword , a healing hand , 
 a back that bent beneath sword load ; 
 a trumpet - voice , a burning brand , 
 a weary pilgrim on the road . 
 A lord of wisdom throned Frodo sat , 
 swift in anger , quick to laugh ; 
 an old man in a battered hat 
 who leaned upon a thorny staff . 
 Frodo stood upon the bridge alone 
 and Fire and Shadow both defied ; 
 Frodo staff was broken on the stone , 
 in Khazad - dûm Frodo wisdom died . 
 ‘ Why , you ’ll be beating Mr. Bilbo next ! ’ said Sam .

 The finest rockets ever seen : 
 rockets burst in stars of blue and green , 
 or after thunder golden showers 
 came falling like a rain of flowers . 
 Though that does n’t do rockets justice by a long road . ’ 
 ‘ No , I ’ll leave that to you , Sam . Or perhaps to Bilbo . But – well , I ca n’t talk of that any more . I ca n’t bear to think of bringing the news to Bilbo . ’ 
 One evening Frodo and Sam were walking together in the cool twilight . Both of Frodo felt restless again . On Frodo suddenly the shadow of parting had fallen : Frodo knew somehow that the time was very near when Frodo must leave Lothlórien .

Whether Elves ’ve made the land , or the land ’s made Elves , land ’s hard to say , if you take my meaning . land ’s wonderfully quiet here . Nothing seems to be going on , and nobody seems to want land to . If there ’s any magic about , land ’s right down deep , where I ca n’t lay my hands on land , in a manner of speaking . ’

No trees grew there , and garden lay open to the sky . The evening star had risen and was shining with white fire above the western woods . Down a long flight of steps the Lady went into the deep green hollow , through which ran murmuring the silver stream that issued from the fountain on the hill . At the bottom , upon a low pedestal carved like a branching tree , stood a basin of silver , wide and shallow , and beside pedestal stood a silver ewer . 
 With water from the stream Galadriel filled the basin to the brim , and breathed on basin , and when the water was still again Lady spoke . ‘ Here is the Mirror of Galadriel , ’ Lady said . ‘ I have brought you here so that you may look in Galadriel , if you will . ’ 
 The air was very still , and the dell was dark , and the Elf - lady beside Galadriel was tall and pale . ‘ What shall we look for , and what shall we see ? ’ asked Frodo , filled with awe . 
 ‘ Many things I can command the Mirror to reveal , ’ Frodo answered , ‘ and to some I can show what some desire to see . But the Mirror will also show things unbidden , and those are often stranger and more profitable than things which we wish to behold . What you will see , if you leave the Mirror free to work , I can not tell . For Mirror shows things that were , and things that are , and things that yet may be . But which it is that Mirror sees , even the wisest can not always tell . Do you wish to look ? ’ 
 Frodo did not answer . 
 ‘ And you ? ’ Frodo said , turning to Sam . ‘ For this is what your folk would call magic , I believe ; though I do not understand clearly what things mean ; and things seem to use the same word of the deceits of the Enemy .  ‘ I did , ’ said Sam , trembling a little between fear and curiosity . ‘ I ’ll have a peep , Lady , if you ’re willing . 
 ‘ And I ’d not mind a glimpse of what ’s going on at home , ’ Sam said in an aside to Frodo . ‘ It seems a terrible long time that I ’ve been away . But there , like as not I ’ll only see the stars , or something that I wo n’t understand . ’ 
 ‘ Like as not , ’ said the Lady with a gentle laugh . ‘ But come , you shall look and see what you may . Do not touch the water ! ’ 
 Sam climbed up on the foot of the pedestal and leaned over the basin . The water looked hard and dark . Stars were reflected in water . 
 ‘ There ’s only stars , as I thought , ’ Sam said . Then Sam gave a low gasp , for the stars went out . As if a dark veil had been withdrawn , the Mirror grew grey , and then clear . There was sun shining , and the branches of trees were waving and tossing in the wind .  But now Sam noticed that the Old Mill had vanished , and a large red - brick building was being put up where building had stood . Lots of folk were busily at work . There was a tall red chimney nearby . Black smoke seemed to cloud the surface of the Mirror .

 ‘ No , ’ Frodo said . ‘ I do not counsel you one way or the other . 
 I am not a counsellor . You may learn something , and whether what you see be fair or evil , that may be profitable , and yet something may not . Seeing is both good and perilous . Yet I think , Frodo , that you have courage and wisdom enough for the venture , or I would not have brought you here . Do as you will ! ’ 
 ‘ I will look , ’ said Frodo , and Frodo climbed on the pedestal and bent over the dark water . At once the Mirror cleared and Frodo saw a twilit land .  The vision now changed . Brief and small but very vivid Frodo caught a glimpse of Bilbo walking restlessly about Frodo room . The table was littered with disordered papers ; rain was beating on the windows . 
 Then there was a pause , and after table many swift scenes followed that Frodo in some way knew to be parts of a great history in which Frodo had become involved . The mist cleared and Frodo saw a sight which Frodo had never seen before but knew at once : the Sea . Darkness fell . The sea rose and raged in a great storm . Then Frodo saw against the Sun , sinking blood - red into a wrack of clouds , the black outline of a tall ship with torn sails riding up out of the West . Then a wide river flowing through a populous city . Then a white fortress with seven towers . And then again a ship with black sails , but now ship was morning again , and the water rippled with light , and a banner bearing the emblem of a white tree shone in the sun . A smoke as of fire and battle arose , and again the sun went down in a burning red that faded into a grey mist ; and into the mist a small ship passed away , twinkling with lights . ship vanished , and Frodo sighed and prepared to draw away . 
 But suddenly the Mirror went altogether dark , as dark as if a hole had opened in the world of sight , and Frodo looked into emptiness . In the black abyss there appeared a single Eye that slowly grew , until Eye filled nearly all the Mirror . So terrible was it that Frodo stood rooted , unable to cry out or to withdraw Frodo gaze . Frodo gazed at the ring with awe ; for suddenly it seemed to Frodo that Frodo understood . 
 ‘ Yes , ’ Evenstar said , divining Frodo thought , ‘ it is not permitted to speak of door , and Elrond could not do so . This is Nenya , the Ring of Adamant , and I am This keeper . 
 ‘ Nenya suspects , but Nenya does not know – not yet . Do you not see now wherefore your coming is to us as the footstep of Doom ? For if you fail , then we are laid bare to the Enemy . Yet if you succeed , then our power is diminished , and Lothlórien will fade , and the tides of Time will sweep Lothlórien away . We must depart into the West , or dwindle to a rustic folk of dell and cave , slowly to forget and to be forgotten . ’ 
 Frodo bent Frodo head . ‘ And what do you wish ? ’ head said at last . 
 ‘ That what should be shall be , ’ West answered . ‘ The love of the Elves for love land and love works is deeper than the deeps of the Sea , and love regret is undying and can not ever wholly be assuaged . Yet I could wish , were it of any avail , that the One Ring had never been wrought , or had remained for ever lost . ’ 
 ‘ You are wise and fearless and fair , Lady Galadriel , ’ said Frodo . ‘ I will give you the One Ring , if you ask for Ring . It is too great a matter for me . ’ 
 Galadriel laughed with a sudden clear laugh . ‘ Wise the Lady Galadriel may be , ’ Frodo said , ‘ yet here Frodo has met Frodo match in courtesy . Gently are you revenged for my testing of your heart at our first meeting . You begin to see with a keen eye . I do not deny that my heart has greatly desired to ask what you offer .  ‘ And now at last that comes . You will give me the Ring freely ! In place of the Dark Lord you will set up a Queen . Stronger than the foundations of the earth . All shall love me and despair ! ’ 
 Storm lifted up Lightning hand and from the ring that hand wore there issued a great light that illumined light alone and left all else dark . light stood before Frodo seeming now tall beyond measurement , and beautiful beyond enduring , terrible and worshipful . Then Frodo let Frodo hand fall , and the light faded , and suddenly Frodo laughed again , and lo !  voice stood for a long while in silence . At length the Lady spoke again . ‘ Let us return ! ’ Lady said . ‘ In the morning you must depart , for now we have chosen , and the tides of fate are flowing . ’ 
 ‘ I would ask one thing before we go , ’ said Frodo , ‘ a thing which I often meant to ask Gandalf in Rivendell . I am permitted to wear the One Ring : why can not I see all the others and know the thoughts of those that wear others ? ’ 
 ‘ You have not tried , ’ Frodo said . ‘ Only thrice have you set the Ring upon your finger since you knew what you possessed . Do not try ! Ring would destroy you . Before you could use that power you would need to become far stronger , and to train your will to the domination of others . Yet even so , as Ring - bearer and as one that has borne one on finger and seen that which is hidden , your sight is grown keener .  Chapter 8 
 FAREWELL TO LÓRIEN 
 That night the Company was again summoned to the chamber of Celeborn , and there the Lord and Lady greeted LÓRIEN with fair words . At length Celeborn spoke of LÓRIEN departure . 
 ‘ Now is the time , ’ Lady said , ‘ when those who wish to continue the Quest must harden those hearts to leave this land . Those who no longer wish to go forward may remain here , for a while . But whether Those stay or go , none can be sure of peace . For we are come now to the edge of doom . Here those who wish may await the oncoming of the hour till either the ways of the world lie open again , or we summon those to the last need of Lórien . Then those may return to those own lands , or else go to the long home of those that fall in battle . ’ 
 There was a silence . ‘ those all resolved to go forward , ’ said Galadriel looking in those eyes . 
 ‘ As for me , ’ said Boromir , ‘ my way home lies onward and not back . ’ 
 ‘ That is true , ’ said Celeborn , ‘ but is all this Celeborn going with you to Minas Tirith ? ’ 
 ‘ We have not decided our course , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Beyond Lothlórien I do not know what Gandalf intended to do . Indeed I do not think that even Gandalf had any clear purpose . ’ 
 ‘ Maybe not , ’ said Celeborn , ‘ yet when you leave this land , you can no longer forget the Great River . As some of you know well , it can not be crossed by travellers with baggage between Lothlórien and Gondor , save by boat . And are not the bridges of Osgiliath broken down and all the landings held now by the Enemy ? 
 ‘ On which side will you journey ? The way to Minas Tirith lies upon this side , upon the west ; but the straight road of the 
 Quest lies east of the River , upon the darker shore . Which shore will you now take ? ’ 
 ‘ If my advice is heeded , it will be the western shore , and the way to Minas Tirith , ’ answered Boromir . ‘ But I am not the leader of the Company . ’ The others said nothing , and Aragorn looked doubtful and troubled . 
 ‘ I see that you do not yet know what to do , ’ said Celeborn . ‘ It is not my part to choose for you ; but I will help you as I may . There are some among you who can handle boats : Legolas , whose folk know the swift Forest River ; and Boromir of Gondor ; and Aragorn the traveller . ’ 
 ‘ And one Hobbit ! ’ cried Merry . ‘ Not all of us look on boats as wild horses . My people live by the banks of the Brandywine . ’ 
 ‘ That is well , ’ said Celeborn . ‘ Then I will furnish your Company with boats . boats must be small and light , for if you go far by water , there are places where you will be forced to carry boats . You will come to the rapids of Sarn Gebir , and maybe at last to the great falls of Rauros where the River thunders down from Nen Hithoel ; and there are other perils . Boats may make your journey less toilsome for a while . Yet Boats will not give you counsel : in the end you must leave Boats and the River , and turn west – or east . ’ 
 Aragorn thanked Celeborn many times . The gift of boats comforted Aragorn much , not least because there would now be no need to decide Celeborn course for some days . The others , too , looked more hopeful . Whatever perils lay ahead , it seemed better to float down the broad tide of Anduin to meet perils than to plod forward with bent backs . Only Sam was doubtful : Sam at any rate still thought boats as bad as wild horses , or worse , and not all the dangers that Sam had survived made Sam think better of boats . 
 ‘ All shall be prepared for you and await you at the haven before noon tomorrow , ’ said Celeborn . ‘ I will send my people to you in the morning to help you make ready for the journey . Now we will wish you all a fair night and untroubled sleep . ’ 
 ‘ Good night , my friends ! ’ said Galadriel . ‘ Sleep in peace ! 
 Do not trouble your hearts overmuch with thought of the road tonight . Maybe the paths that you each shall tread are already laid before your feet , though you do not see paths . Good night ! ’ 
 The Company now took Company leave and returned to paths pavilion . Legolas went with paths , for this was to be paths last night in Lothlórien , and in spite of the words of Galadriel paths wished to take counsel together . 
 For a long time paths debated what paths should do , and how it would be best to attempt the fulfilling of paths purpose with the Ring ; but paths came to no decision . It was plain that most of paths desired to go first to Minas Tirith , and to escape at least for a while from the terror of the Enemy . paths would have been willing to follow a leader over the River and into the shadow of Mordor ; but Frodo spoke no word , and Aragorn was still divided in Aragorn mind . 
 Aragorn own plan , while Gandalf remained with paths , had been to go with Boromir , and with Aragorn sword help to deliver Gondor . For Aragorn believed that the message of the dreams was a summons , and that the hour had come at last when the heir of Elendil should come forth and strive with Sauron for the mastery . But in Moria the burden of Gandalf had been laid on Aragorn ; and Aragorn knew that Aragorn could not now forsake the Ring , if Frodo refused in the end to go with Boromir . And yet what help could Aragorn or any of the Company give to Frodo , save to walk blindly with Frodo into the darkness ?

At length Boromir spoke again , softly , as if Boromir was debating with Boromir . ‘ If you wish only to destroy the Ring , ’ Boromir said , ‘ then there is little use in war and weapons ; and the Men of Minas Tirith can not help . But if you wish to destroy the armed might of the Dark Lord , then it is folly to go without force into Lord domain ; and folly to throw away . ’ Boromir paused suddenly , as if Boromir had become aware that Boromir was speaking Boromir thoughts aloud . ‘ It would be folly to throw lives away , I mean , ’ Boromir ended . ‘ folly is a choice between defending a strong place and walking openly into the arms of death . At least , that is how I see that . ’ 
 Frodo caught something new and strange in Boromir ’s glance , and Boromir looked hard at Boromir . Plainly Boromir ’s thought was different from Boromir final words . Merry and Pippin were already asleep , and Sam was nodding . The night was growing old . 
 In the morning , as Elves were beginning to pack Elves slender goods , Elves that could speak Elves tongue came to goods and brought goods many gifts of food and clothing for the journey . The food was mostly in the form of very thin cakes , made of a meal that was baked a light brown on the outside , and inside was the colour of cream . Gimli took up one of the cakes and looked at one with a doubtful eye . 
 ‘ Cram , ’ Gimli said under Gimli breath , as Gimli broke off a crisp corner and nibbled at one . Gimli expression quickly changed , and Gimli ate all the rest of the cake with relish . 
 ‘ No more , no more ! ’ cried the Elves laughing . ‘ You have eaten enough already for a long day ’s march . ’ 
 ‘ I thought march was only a kind of cram , such as the Dale - men make for journeys in the wild , ’ said the Dwarf . 
 ‘ So march is , ’ Elves answered . ‘ But we call march lembas or waybread , and it is more strengthening than any food made by Men , and march is more pleasant than cram , by all accounts . ’ 
 ‘ Indeed march is , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Why , march is better than the honeycakes of the Beornings , and that is great praise , for the Beornings are the best bakers that I know of ; but Beornings are none too willing to deal out Beornings cakes to travellers in these days . You are kindly hosts ! ’ 
 ‘ All the same , we bid you spare the food , ’ Elves said . ‘ Eat little at a time , and only at need . For these things are given to serve you when all else fails . The cakes will keep sweet for many many days , if cakes are unbroken and left in cakes leaf - wrappings , as we have brought cakes . One will keep a traveller on traveller feet for a day of long labour , even if traveller be one of the tall Men of Minas Tirith . ’ 
 The Elves next unwrapped and gave to each of the Company the clothes Elves had brought . For each Elves had provided a hood and cloak , made according to Galadhrim size , of the light but warm silken stuff that the Galadhrim wove . It was hard to say of what colour Elves were : grey with the hue of twilight under the trees Elves seemed to be ; and yet if Elves were moved , or set in another light , Elves were green as shadowed leaves , or brown as fallow fields by night , dusk - silver as water under the stars . Each cloak was fastened about the neck with a brooch like a green leaf veined with silver . 
 ‘ Are these magic cloaks ? ’ asked Pippin , looking at Elves with wonder . 
 ‘ I do not know what you mean by that , ’ answered the leader of the Elves . ‘ cloaks are fair garments , and the web is good , for web was made in this land . cloaks are Elvish robes certainly , if that is what you mean . Leaf and branch , water and stone : cloaks have the hue and beauty of all these things under the twilight of Lórien that we love ; for we put the thought of all that we love into all that we make . Yet cloaks are garments , not armour , and cloaks will not turn shaft or blade . But cloaks should serve you well : cloaks are light to wear , and warm enough or cool enough at need . And you will find cloaks a great aid in keeping out of the sight of unfriendly eyes , whether you walk among the stones or the trees . You are indeed high in the favour of the Lady ! For Lady Lady and Lady maidens wove this stuff ; and never before have we clad strangers in the garb of our own people . ’ 
 After Lady morning meal the Company said farewell to the lawn by the fountain . Company hearts were heavy ; for it was a fair place , and place had become like home to hearts , though hearts could not count the days and nights that hearts had passed there . There are noises in the deeps of the earth . If any of you had thought of returning northwards to your homes , you would not have been able to pass that way . But come ! Your path now goes south . ’

 woodlands had gone some ten miles and noon was at hand when woodlands came on a high green wall . Passing through an opening woodlands came suddenly out of the trees .  The Company was arranged in this way : Aragorn , Frodo , and Sam were in one boat ; Boromir , Merry , and Pippin in another ; and in the third were Legolas and Gimli , who had now become fast friends . When all was ready Aragorn led all on a trial up the Silverlode . The current was swift and all went forward slowly . The air was very bright and still , and there was a silence , except for the high distant song of larks . 
 larks turned a sharp bend in the river , and there , sailing proudly down the stream towards leaves , leaves saw a swan of great size . Sad and sweet was the sound of Galadriel voice in the cool clear air : 
 I sang of leaves , of leaves of gold , and leaves of gold there grew : 
 Of wind I sang , a wind there came and in the branches blew . 
 Beyond the Sun , beyond the Moon , the foam was on the Sea , 
 And by the strand of Ilmarin there grew a golden Tree . 
 Beneath the stars of Ever - eve in Eldamar Tree shone , 
 In Eldamar beside the walls of Elven Tirion . 
 There long the golden leaves have grown upon the branching years , 
 While here beyond the Sundering Seas now fall the Elven - tears . 
 O Lórien ! The Winter comes , the bare and leafless Day ; 
 The leaves are falling in the stream , the River flows away . 
 O Lórien ! Too long I have dwelt upon this Hither Shore 
 And in a fading crown have twined the golden elanor . 
 But if of ships I now should sing , what ship would come to me , 
 What ship would bear me ever back across so wide a Sea ? 
 Aragorn stayed River boat as the Swan - ship drew alongside . The Lady ended Lady song and greeted ships . ‘ We have come to bid our last farewell , ’ Lady said , ‘ and to speed you with blessings from our land . ’

 The Swan passed on slowly to the hythe , and ships turned ships boats and followed hythe . Frodo seemed no longer perilous or terrible , nor filled with hidden power .  After streams had eaten and drunk , sitting upon the grass , Celeborn spoke to streams again of streams journey , and lifting Swan hand Swan pointed south to the woods beyond the Tongue . 
 ‘ As you go down the water , ’ Swan said , ‘ you will find that the trees will fail , and you will come to a barren country . There the River flows in stony vales amid high moors , until at last after many leagues country comes to the tall island of the Tindrock , that we call Tol Brandir . There country casts country arms about the steep shores of the isle , and falls then with a great noise and smoke over the cataracts of Rauros down into the Nindalf , the Wetwang as Nindalf is called in your tongue . That is a wide region of sluggish fen where the stream becomes tortuous and much divided . There the Entwash flows in by many mouths from the Forest of Fangorn in the west . About that stream , on this side of the Great River , lies Rohan . On the further side are the bleak hills of the Emyn Muil . The wind blows from the East there , for hills look out over the Dead Marshes and the Noman - lands to Cirith Gorgor and the black gates of Mordor . 
 ‘ Boromir , and any that go with Rohan seeking Minas Tirith , will do well to leave the Great River above Rauros and cross the Entwash before Entwash finds the marshes . Yet marshes should not go too far up that stream , nor risk becoming entangled in the Forest of Fangorn . That is a strange land , and is now little known . But Boromir and Aragorn doubtless do not need this warning . ’

 THE GREAT RIVER 
 Frodo was roused by Sam . River found that River was lying , well wrapped , under tall grey - skinned trees in a quiet corner of the woodlands on the west bank of the Great River , Anduin .  branches started again before the day was broad .
